summary: Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend on Twitter after Townsend played only seven minutes in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. The conflict began when Merson wrote in his Sky Sports column that Townsend's England selection meant the team was open to anybody. Townsend responded by scoring a stunning equaliser for England against Italy in a 1-1 draw, after which Merson admitted he was wrong and praised the goal. Merson had based his original opinion on Townsend being substituted after thirty minutes at Manchester United in front of England manager Roy Hodgson. Townsend mocked Merson on Twitter after his England goal, but Merson took another jab at him following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. The Japan international, who has 11 caps and scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo, would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the transfer is completed. Ogane states the interest is not connected to Chelsea's £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber signed in February. A £4million deal has been suggested, though Muto has not yet decided whether to accept the offer. He recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree and would be Chelsea's first Japanese player if he joins.

A Finnish study of over 12,000 children found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with those who received antibiotics as young babies particularly affected. Repeated prescriptions before age two increased the risk, with boys especially prone to weight gain and slightly increased height. Researchers suggest antibiotics may contribute to childhood obesity by killing gut bacteria that normally consume food, freeing up more calories for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study, published in Pediatrics, emphasizes the need for careful antibiotic use in infancy, as their overuse may be contributing to the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic alongside other concerns like antibiotic resistance and increased risk of eczema and digestive problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, dropping his rifle and knocking his bearskin hat on his sentry box. The incident occurred on Thursday afternoon in front of hundreds of tourists and was captured on video by David Meadwell, 50, from Newcastle-upon-Tyne, who was visiting London with his family. The embarrassed soldier quickly got back on his feet while his colleagues continued marching. The slip is believed to have been caused by metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The 1977 miniseries "Roots," which drew over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016. The miniseries tells the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery on a Virginia plantation. A&E, Lifetime, and History will simulcast the remake, which will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and consult scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce alongside Mark Wolper, son of the original producer. The remake aims to introduce the story to a new generation unfamiliar with the original while also reaching fans of the 1977 version.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims he was pinned to a chair and groped by male staff members during his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 when he was 27. He alleges he walked into a bedroom looking for a pen when several men, including a senior staff member, offered him a drink before one man began performing a sex act and others attempted to remove his trousers. Lawler says he escaped but was followed and threatened to stay quiet. His complaint that day allegedly received an angry response, prompting him to leave immediately. After hearing about investigations into historical child abuse cases, he contacted palace officials last year but was initially rebuffed twice before his complaint was passed to Scotland Yard months later. A retired royal aide in his 80s was interviewed but denied involvement, claiming he was at Balmoral at the time. Police are currently investigating the claims.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" theme song. The video, filmed in their car, has received over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the parody, they rap about living in Happy Valley, Oregon, buying their first house, and facing family pressure about having children. Melissa raps about discovering her pregnancy after realizing she was late and seeing a positive test. The couple reveals they conceived after two months of trying, faster than expected. The video concludes with them sharing a sonogram. It took five takes to film, and they created it primarily to inform distant family and friends about the baby. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. The couple expressed surprise at the video's viral success and may create another video to reveal the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt with black zigzag applique, which appeared in several key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack, has faded from its original slate blue-gray color. The dress was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film owned by James Tumblin, former head of Universal Studios' hair and makeup department, who purchased it for $20 in the 1960s when it was about to be discarded by Western Costume Company. Other notable sales included a Leigh straw hat for $52,500, Clark Gable's suit for $55,000, and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, featured Hattie McDaniel, who became the first African-American to win an Academy Award for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday around 3pm after his mother, who was holding him and another child, dangled him over the railing and he slipped. The parents rescued the child before emergency responders arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, and was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition. The cheetahs did not approach or attack the boy or his parents. Eyewitness accounts indicate the child was dangled over the railing. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham has been turned around and is now pointing directly at a house's front door. The camera, which previously monitored the 30mph speed limit, has been non-operational for over two years, part of approximately 300 cameras switched off across the West Midlands in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Speed enforcement has since been handled by mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrol officers. It's unclear who repositioned the camera, but Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and will send an engineer to assess it, with possible removal. The council is developing a pilot program using digital technology for a limited number of sites, but this Wellington Road camera will not be included.

Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, according to the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. The six-time Olympic gold medallist stated he is fit, healthy and ready to run, noting that Jamaica has a long and successful relay tradition and he always does his best to represent his country. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure that the world's fastest man will be competing for Jamaica, anticipating sprint magic at the event. The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid on Thursday night, accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella. Barcelona won 85-80, though Real Madrid remained top of their division on points difference. Neymar had recently helped Brazil defeat Chile 1-0 at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday in a physical match. Before the international break, Barcelona won their football El Clasico to move four points clear at the top of La Liga. Neymar and Barcelona return to La Liga action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants may be missing from a capsized ship that reportedly carried 550 people and sank about 80 miles off Libya's coast, though the Italian coast guard cannot confirm this incident as search operations found no survivors, bodies, or evidence. Italy registered over 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first three months of 2015, with most coming from West African countries, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler vessels, and crews abandoning ships.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger does not know why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool last summer, but is pleased with the decision. The £32million Chile forward, who was courted by multiple elite clubs after Barcelona decided to sell him, has scored 19 goals this season and made an instant impact in English football. Wenger was aware of Liverpool's interest in Sanchez, which he believed could have been used as leverage in negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger praised Sanchez's qualities including efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, noting his ability to revitalize the team. Ahead of their Premier League clash, Wenger dismissed speculation about a potential move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commended Brendan Rodgers for finding solutions after losing Suarez and dealing with Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner will try to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at age 35. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February after the UCI reformed regulations. Wiggins, who has three Olympic gold medals in track cycling, finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix and will ride the Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for the hour record attempt. He is targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the team pursuit. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with tickets going on sale April 19 priced at £49, £39 and £29. Briton Alex Dowsett will also attempt the record on May 2 in Manchester.

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in Fed Cup singles on Sunday, maintaining her 8-0 career record against the Italian, but called the difficult match an 'eye-opener' for the claycourt season. The world No 1 admitted she was playing like she was on hard court and needed to adjust her game. Despite Williams' singles victory, the US lost 3-2 overall after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated 6-0 6-3 in doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. The doubles loss was Williams' first Fed Cup defeat, and US captain Mary Joe Fernandez acknowledged the team needs to work harder to return to the World Group.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, with vice president Matias Patanian stating the club dreams of the striker and the doors are open for his return. The 29-year-old Colombia forward previously played for River Plate from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Falcao is currently on a season-long loan at Manchester United from Monaco, where he has struggled with only four Premier League goals. It is uncertain whether United will exercise their option to keep him or if he will return to Monaco. Despite his club struggles, Falcao recently scored three goals in two games for Colombia, equaling the national team's all-time scoring record with 24 goals. River Plate acknowledge that any potential deal would be complicated.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson, 19, has been announced as the official face of Batiste dry shampoo's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features images of Henderson against a vibrant city background displaying various hairstyles, including wavy locks worn down and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership between the platinum award-winning artist and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand was arranged by the MILES agency. The international campaign launched with a TV advertisement featuring Henderson's single, Mirror Man. Henderson has expressed excitement about working with Batiste, stating she regularly uses the product.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, 26, are upset after a billboard featuring officer Pablo Torres and his dog was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. Torres fatally shot Siler on March 14 after Siler armed himself with a weapon during a confrontation. Torres is on leave pending investigation. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, reads "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." Siler's family considers it disrespectful and wants it removed. The police association states the billboard was intended to thank the community for support during recent incidents, not to cause offense. Siler was wanted on a felony warrant and was shot following a vehicle and foot pursuit. Torres had also shot another person, Terry Knight, 10 days earlier in a separate incident that was ruled justified. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in southeastern Iran's Sistan-Baluchestan province on Monday. Three militants died in the fighting in Negur after crossing from Pakistan. Jaish al Adal, a Sunni Muslim anti-Iranian group operating in Pakistan's Balochistan province, claimed responsibility. The group targets Shiites and opposes Iranian influence in Pakistan, and has previously attacked Iranian territory, including killing 14 border guards in October 2013. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling terrorists who flee back across the border after attacks. Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and stated its security agencies are investigating and will apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistani territory.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told parliament that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO. The statement came in response to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, a former professional wrestler who entered Japan's Upper House in 2013. Nakatani explained that while fighter jets are scrambled to investigate unidentified flying objects that could violate Japanese airspace, they have only found birds or other earthly flying objects. Inoki, known for his wrestling career including a 1976 fight with Muhammad Ali and founding New Japan Pro Wrestling, claims to have seen a UFO himself but admits uncertainty about alien existence. This is not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed extraterrestrial matters; in 2007, a defense minister considered the constitutional implications of defending against a space invasion.

A 35-year-old passenger at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on collapsed and shattered. Jin Pai had been standing on the toilet rim because he was concerned about cleanliness. The porcelain toilet broke, leaving him bleeding on the floor. He called his traveling companions for help due to embarrassment and was taken to hospital where he received several dozen stitches. He initially admitted to squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities ruled it an accident and reminded people that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested and faces multiple charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. A 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera under the sink in her bathroom in March. She reported that Rebbie had been watching her undress for years and sexually abused her in her bedroom from ages nine to thirteen while she was sleeping. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera showing the girl and other victims, including juveniles, using the bathroom, with 34 videos capturing them showering. Some videos included close-up images of children's genitalia. The footage was recorded over three to four years, and Rebbie uploaded the videos to his computer. He admitted to filming multiple victims and purchasing the camera specifically to record the 15-year-old victim. Rebbie is being held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of father-daughter portraits featuring teenagers standing po-faced while their fathers leap dramatically into the air beside them. The images are from the 37-year-old's latest book, roughly translated as Daughter and Salary Man, with fathers wearing sharp suits while daughters dress casually. According to the photographer's website, the concept allows fathers who typically must act serious to express their fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky." The photographs show fathers of various ages pulling energetic poses, with some older fathers appearing slightly pained, and are set against various Japanese landmarks. The unusual series has generated significant online interest.

Kevin Pietersen displayed mixed emotions during Surrey's team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of the County Championship season. The 34-year-old batsman appeared in deep thought at times but was otherwise jovial, joking with photographers and teammates. The event follows the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director on Wednesday, which has opened the door for Pietersen's potential return to the international team after being controversially dropped in 2014. Pietersen last played for England during the disastrous 2013-14 Ashes tour in Australia, which ended in a whitewash defeat. He has rejoined Surrey to force his way back into the Test setup as England prepares to face Australia this summer. Surrey begins their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19, with a MCC University match against Oxford MCCU scheduled for Sunday.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in one week. The former Brazil defender, who earned 25 caps and played for Inter Milan and Parma, was initially fired Wednesday following poor results, then reinstated Thursday by owner Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday, he was sacked again. The defeat left Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who became the club's third coach this season in January, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao moved from Monaco to Manchester United on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled, scoring only four goals all season and failing to reach his pre-knee injury form. United are unlikely to pay the £46million required to make the transfer permanent. His former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets the move, suggesting he would have been better staying at Monaco where he could have played regularly and competed in the Champions League, though Falcao was unhappy in France.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday around 12.30pm. The offender, described as very tall, demanded cash from the owner's daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled with the till drawer and approximately $1,500. The daughter ran from the shop screaming. Police report no weapons were used and the robber remains at large. Authorities are appealing to the public for information to help identify the suspect through Crimestoppers or online messaging.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with students. She was first arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail and suspended from teaching. Days later, a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January across from another Dallas school. She was arrested again on Monday and released after posting $50,000 bail. The school district placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being on school property.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The dog, wearing a red collar, belonged to a local bike shop owner and reportedly approached the water's edge out of curiosity before being attacked. New Zealander Tim Weston, who was on holiday and witnessed the incident, said the crocodile held the dog in its mouth for hours without moving. The crocodile came from a nearby sanctuary located 200 meters up a river that connects to the marina. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, as the Mexican beach resort is built among mangroves where the creatures have lived for centuries. American Crocodiles in Mexico can reach lengths of 6 meters and are living closer to humans due to urbanization. The video sparked horror among social media users.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid Premier League relegation despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton that leaves them battling to stay up with six games remaining. Hull, who have won only six matches this season compared to Bruce's initial target of 10 wins, now sit just two points clear of the drop zone and face difficult fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic and Robert Snodgrass. In the Southampton match, James Ward-Prowse scored a penalty and Graziano Pelle added a late goal, moving Southampton to fifth place. The match also saw an incident where Sadio Mane attempted to take the penalty instead of designated taker Ward-Prowse, prompting manager Ronald Koeman to intervene and promise a team discussion about following rules.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury to change their SATs exam answers after the test session ended. The 31-year-old also altered some answers himself before submitting the papers. Following a tip-off and investigation by the local education authority in June, it was confirmed that changes were made outside exam conditions. This resulted in the Department for Education annulling all SATs results for the entire school for 2014. Guffick left his position and admitted the allegations constituted unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only asked pupils to make answers more legible. The conduct panel found his actions dishonest but not fraudulent, noting he showed remorse and cooperated with investigations. The prohibition order was deemed appropriate given the serious impact on the school, and Guffick has 28 days to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's goalkeeper, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year, and the couple have a son together. They have been dating since 2012. The 31-year-old Danish international joined United from Norwegian side Aalesunds in 2010 but has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons. He is now third-choice goalkeeper at Old Trafford behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, and has been told he can leave the club. A January move to FC Midtjylland fell through when the clubs could not agree on a price. Lindegaard shared photos with Beqiri on Instagram, while she regularly posts modelling pictures to her over 17,000 followers.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once hung above Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday, receiving no legitimate bids despite estimates of $300,000 to $600,000. The letters are currently owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased them for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. The 10-feet-tall letters had been displayed atop the stadium since 1976. Jackson, 68, attended the auction and had stated he wanted a new generation to own this Yankees and New York City icon. He admitted buying the letters "on a lark" and joked about being surprised by their size. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s sold for $112,500, far exceeding its $20,000 to $30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed incidents involving Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after Sterling was exposed inhaling nitrous oxide and both players were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to both players in his office on Thursday but will not discipline them, reminding them about their professional responsibilities as elite sportspeople. Sterling will lead Liverpool's line at Wembley on Sunday against Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final, with Daniel Sturridge injured. Steven Gerrard is available after completing a three-match suspension, though Rodgers has not confirmed whether he will start. Rodgers emphasized that experiencing near-misses, like last season's title race and the Capital One Cup semi-final, is part of the journey toward success, noting that most winners in sport have previously fallen short before achieving victory.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil posted a photo on social media relaxing at home with his dog after returning to London from international duty. The German performed well in Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying victory over Georgia on Sunday and is preparing for Arsenal's upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil, who joined Arsenal from Real Madrid for £42.5million in 2013, missed the Newcastle game due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. Since returning from injury, he has contributed four assists and three goals since January. The playmaker says he is now adjusting well to English football, stating he enjoys the frequent match schedule and fits in "perfectly" despite the demanding nature of having no winter break and limited recovery time between games.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has dismissed speculation about replacing manager Luis Enrique, stating the club is "very happy" with him. Enrique, who joined last summer on a two-year contract, is six games away from winning La Liga. Bartomeu praised the manager's work ethic and noted Barcelona remains in contention for three trophies heading into the season's final stretch. Enrique's contract runs until 2016, and Barcelona recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool worth around £100,000 per week, running until 2020. The 24-year-old vice-captain had 14 months left on his existing deal, and negotiations with his advisors have been ongoing since the start of the season. Henderson is the third key player to sign an extension under Brendan Rodgers, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Since joining from Sunderland for £16 million in 2011, Henderson has developed significantly, contributing seven goals and 13 assists this season. He is being considered as a potential replacement for Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy.

Filipe Luis has stated he wants to remain at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. The full back joined Chelsea from Atletico on a three-year deal last July but has struggled to secure the left back position. Luis played for Brazil during the international break and is now focused on Chelsea's Premier League title run-in. Manager Jose Mourinho is keeping his league-leading team focused, emphasizing the need to win every match. Luis acknowledges the difficulty of the remaining nine games but believes the team is prepared for the challenge.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after being initially suspended for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee while scoring a try for Northampton on March 27. Hughes was shown a red card and deemed 'reckless' by the original disciplinary panel, despite no intent being found. The decision sparked widespread criticism, with many defending Hughes including teammates and former players who called the ban a 'joke'. The appeal panel heard fresh evidence and concluded no foul play occurred as the incident was accidental, officially rescinding the red card. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon but is now free to return. North was left unconscious in what was his third head blow in two months and has been advised to take at least a month off.

A fiery, deep reddish sunset was observed in Washington on Sunday, with Seattle native Tim Durkan photographing aerial shots of the phenomenon. The stunning sunsets resulted from wildfires in southeastern Siberia that started on April 14 when farmers burning grass lost control of flames due to strong winds. The fires destroyed dozens of villages before rescue crews extinguished them. Atmospheric winds carried lingering smoke across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red color occurs because smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors like greens, blues, yellows, and purples, allowing red and orange to penetrate unfiltered. The effect is especially intense during sunrises and sunsets due to increased atmosphere the light travels through. As smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the red hue will fade.

A Missouri woman, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway in St. Louis just over a month after purchasing it. Police recovered the vehicle on April 1 after receiving a tip from a man who recognized it. The car was returned with modifications including red spray-painted rims, red side detailing, and orange steering wheel accents. Rather than being upset, Schoenig responded positively on Facebook, joking that the thieves had "pimped out" her vehicle. However, she is having the car professionally cleaned due to strong cigarette and marijuana odors. She is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, named after Mick Sexton, the man who helped locate her car.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League. The Premier League title holders use incentivised contracts for star players including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Toure to comply with financial fair play requirements, with approximately £12million total at stake for the squad. After losing to Manchester United in the derby, City sit fourth, potentially just four points ahead of Liverpool. The top three Premier League finishers qualify automatically for the Champions League, while fourth place requires winning a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team has performed poorly in recent months, losing seven times including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. The uncertain Champions League qualification could also affect City's ability to attract world-class players like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in their youth derby at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with 13 of 22 starting players being English and 10 from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick just before the hour mark after drawing a foul on the edge of the box. The match, played before nearly 1,000 spectators with free entry, saw United manager Paul McGuinness deploy a three-at-the-back formation similar to the first team's setup. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson hit the crossbar late on, while City's attempts to equalize, including efforts from Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun, were unsuccessful. The victory gives United two wins in this year's derby meetings and leaves them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italy's Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after the Italian earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw on Tuesday night. Hart, who won his 50th cap in the match, said he is still learning from watching Buffon at 37 years old and considers him an inspiration. The Manchester City goalkeeper, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed pride in reaching 50 caps at his age and stated his desire to continue playing well for club and country to accumulate more appearances.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer food delivery in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion delivery market. The service will include a nine percent service charge plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Chipotle previously declined collaboration offers from third-party delivery services before approving Postmates, which uses independent contractors driving their own vehicles similar to Uber. Other major chains including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also launching or testing delivery services. Recent notable Chipotle customers include presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty from Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's sentencing in exchange for life imprisonment without parole or appeal rights. Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son was killed and 7-year-old daughter severely injured in the attack, attended the trial where Tsarnaev was convicted on all 30 charges. They acknowledge the brutality of the crimes but argue that pursuing the death penalty would bring years of appeals, prolonging their family's pain and forcing their remaining children to grow up with constant reminders of the tragedy. The sentencing phase was set to begin Tuesday and last four weeks. The bombing killed three people and wounded over 200 when two bombs exploded at the finish line on April 15, 2013.

A custom-built Boeing 747 has been converted into a luxury private residence for an unidentified billionaire at a cost of £400million over three years. The aircraft, which normally carries up to 600 passengers, has been redesigned for a single owner plus dozens of guests. Features include multiple bedrooms, a master suite, an aeroloft with eight full beds on the top deck, several lounges, a state room, a dining room with adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and office space. The interior resembles a luxury hotel rather than a traditional aircraft cabin, with plush furnishings throughout. The project was completed by Greenpoint Technologies.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station on Tuesday. The company attempted to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge but failed, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. This was SpaceX's second unsuccessful attempt at sea landing, following a January explosion. The company aims to master rocket reusability to reduce space access costs by up to a hundredfold. The Dragon spacecraft successfully reached orbit and will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the station, including research equipment and an espresso maker. After approximately five weeks, the Dragon will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and materials, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This marks SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station as the first private contractor to dock with it.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23. The 69-year-old collaborated with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for one couple to win the wedding, with the winners to be announced the following Monday. The prize includes a free wedding reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. The Westgate, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, is where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. Priscilla, who married Elvis in 1967, insisted the chapel be first-class with no impersonators. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside Memphis, Tennessee. Couples must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve to win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League race for Champions League qualification despite being four points behind. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in Liverpool's 2-0 win over Newcastle United on Monday night, equalling the appearance record for any player in Europe's top five leagues this campaign. Raheem Sterling scored in the ninth minute and Joe Allen added a second goal with 20 minutes remaining, his first at Anfield. The victory was crucial for Liverpool after disappointing performances and results against Manchester United and Arsenal in recent weeks. Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez, which Allen acknowledged looked legitimate, but it was not given.

Roma ended their four-month winless home streak by defeating Napoli 1-0 in Serie A. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute from a counter-attack, while goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made crucial saves throughout the second half. The victory moved second-place Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, ending a seven-match home winless run since November 30. Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place. Security was heightened for the match, with residents of the Campania region barred from purchasing tickets and 1,000 police officers deployed, following a fatal shooting incident involving a Napoli fan before last season's Italian Cup final. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne returned from a knee injury sustained in November.

Doncaster Rovers' League One match against Fleetwood Town ended in a goalless draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The match was so uneventful that the club's media team posted highlights lasting just 27 seconds, containing only 14 seconds of match action showing the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle. Both teams are experiencing disappointing seasons, with Doncaster in mid-table and Fleetwood's play-off hopes nearly gone.

Roland Giroux has developed a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid fish, regularly stroking and massaging it by placing his hand in the tank. The fish responds by relaxing in his hand, staying still during the massage, and repeatedly returning to his fingers after swimming away. It also swims up his arm and buries its face in his hand, appearing to enjoy the interaction. When Giroux removes his hand, the fish follows it to the surface, seemingly saddened. Giroux began this interaction after removing two other fish that were bullying his pet, initially hand-feeding it frozen blood worms. The fish became increasingly sociable and now expects daily play sessions of at least 15 minutes, becoming frustrated without them. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes returned to the Kensington Oval in Barbados where he previously broke his wrist punching a locker after being dismissed. Despite his fiery reputation, demonstrated through clashes with opponents like Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson during the Ashes, Stokes has fought his way back into the England team after a turbulent year. England coach Peter Moores spoke with Stokes after the Samuels incident, and his subsequent response was positive. While Stokes requires careful man-management to channel his aggression appropriately, England values his natural exuberance and character in a sport sometimes perceived as producing robotic players. The team wants him to play as much as possible alongside Chris Jordan to develop their international careers, as both can deliver runs and wickets when their aggression is properly controlled. A slight back niggle was the only potential obstacle to his participation in Barbados.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out all 33,000 tickets. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points from five games, with Belgium top on goal difference despite being ranked fourth in the world. Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel has heightened expectations that Chris Coleman's team can secure automatic qualification for the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales reported overwhelming ticket demand following the Israel performance. The match will remain at Cardiff City Stadium rather than the larger 74,500-capacity Millennium Stadium, partly due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days and because the Wales squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff venue, where they haven't played since a Euro 2012 qualifier against England in March 2011. This represents Wales' best opportunity to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria next month. England are defending champions after beating Holland on penalties in last year's final and qualified with a 100 per cent record. The squad has been placed in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland, opening their campaign against Italy in Burgas on May 7. The 18-player squad includes players from Premier League clubs such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold. England will also face Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, considered one of the club's best youth talents. The Belgian teenager has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, having previously rejected Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. City have held talks with Anderlecht's chairman about a compensation package for the player.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead in a Fulham flat on March 28, having been strangled and beaten with injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. She worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, and had described herself as visiting London from Miami. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and seeking information about why the killing occurred.

A woman named Dawn, who experienced seven miscarriages, discovered that £207 she had saved toward a £500 gravestone for her buried baby Daniel James had been stolen. She suspected her housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, and his girlfriend Carol, who were the only ones who knew where the money was kept. After Jamie initially denied taking it, a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show proved he had stolen the cash. Jamie also sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft but blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed feeling betrayed after trying to help them by letting them live in her home.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis in northern Iraq on Wednesday, mostly women, children, ill or elderly individuals, according to Kurdish officials who reported counts of 217 and 228. Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though the motivation remains unclear. The Yazidis, a Kurdish-descended minority following a pre-Islamic religion drawing from Christianity, Judaism and Zoroastrianism, suffered severe persecution when ISIS overtook their towns in northern Iraq last summer, killing hundreds, enslaving and raping women, and forcing hundreds of thousands to flee. The attack on Sinjar particularly trapped many in mountains without supplies, prompting international humanitarian airdrops, rescues, and subsequent U.S.-led airstrikes against ISIS. ISIS has previously released other Yazidi captives, mainly children and elderly. An estimated 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, representing less than 1% of the population.

Harry Kane is nominated for both PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards following his breakthrough season with Tottenham and England. A new animation video produced by Copa90 showcases Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, using still photographs layered to create an animated effect. The video features notable goals including a long-range strike against Chelsea, a header against Arsenal, and his goal on his England debut. The animation was released ahead of Sunday's awards ceremony, where Kane competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the main award.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain as Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and likely finish outside the top four. The former Liverpool defender stated that Rodgers' future shouldn't be determined by one game and noted that many new signings haven't settled in yet. Liverpool are seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand, set to miss Champions League qualification. Carragher emphasized that the success of future signings will be crucial for Liverpool's improvement. He made these comments after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, where his 23 Foundation provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas. The 37-year-old, who played 737 games for Liverpool, expressed his commitment to helping youngsters in his hometown of Bootle and the wider Liverpool community.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun, which fires sponge darts, confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport before a flight to Lanzarote. The brightly colored toy was in his hand luggage and detected by X-ray machines. Security officers performed a pat-down inspection of the child and required him to surrender the toy. His father Phil criticized the security measures as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous," though the family complied to avoid missing their flight. The £6 toy was replaced after their 10-day Easter holiday. East Midlands Airport apologized but defended the decision, stating they offered to post the toy to the family's home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire. The airport cited government regulations prohibiting items resembling prohibited items through security, with UK hand luggage restrictions set by the Department of Transport including "replica or model guns" on the prohibited list.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. His requirements include a non-drinker and non-smoker who is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, skilled with their hands, a good cook, and great in bed. The successful candidate must love pets, enjoy the outdoors, and be "a princess when need to be." Rich describes himself as having an athletic build, heavily tattooed, 175cm tall, well-endowed, non-drinking, non-smoking, drug-free, and owning property with successful income. He offers accommodation, possibly a company car, phone, laptop, free gym membership, and promises to spend money on his partner. Former partners are excluded from applying.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has received support from five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—for his proposed reforms to increase home-grown players in Premier League squads. Dyke wants to raise the minimum number of home-grown players from eight to 12 and change the definition to require three years of training in England before age 18 rather than 21. The Premier League opposes these proposals. In a letter, the former managers warn that blocking these changes risks England falling further behind leading football nations and makes winning the World Cup harder. They note that only 36.8 percent of recent Premier League starters were eligible for England selection, indicating a shrinking pool of English talent at the top level. While acknowledging England's failure to win major honours since 1966 and the recent emergence of promising young players like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane, they argue the key issue is lack of opportunity for English talent.

In tomorrow night's episode of Poldark, Demelza gives birth to a baby daughter within ten minutes of the show's start, despite barely showing signs of pregnancy last week. The episode begins with Demelza at eight months pregnant, then quickly moves to the birth without acknowledging the passage of time. Ross Poldark demonstrates his love for his wife, telling her she makes him a better man. The compressed pregnancy timeline mirrors a previous instance where another character, Elizabeth, also went to full term between episodes. Fans have commented on social media about the unrealistic speed of pregnancies in the show, noting that characters appear to give birth within minutes of announcing their pregnancy.

Leicester, currently bottom of the Premier League but only three points from safety, will host Swansea on Saturday following consecutive victories. Manager Nigel Pearson is urging his team to concentrate solely on their own performance rather than monitoring relegation rivals after their 3-2 win at West Brom, where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Pearson emphasizes that Leicester's survival fate remains in their own hands and warns against excessive optimism despite their recent improvement.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest recorded mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean to Baja, Mexico. This surpassed the previous record of 10,190 miles set by a humpback whale. During her journey, Varvara visited three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, leading researchers to believe she may actually be an eastern gray whale rather than an endangered western gray whale as initially thought. This finding suggests some whales classified as western grays might actually be eastern grays, potentially reducing the population of western gray whales, currently estimated at only 150. The discovery indicates a need to reexamine genetic differentiation between the two species.

Approximately 1,000 feet of seabed suddenly emerged overnight along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Japan's Hokkaido Island, rising 30 to 50 feet above sea level and measuring roughly 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Geologists believe a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area upward. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds during the emergence, and marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the exposed ocean floor. Authorities do not expect further expansion and confirmed the event is unrelated to earthquakes, including the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Kathmandu.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied he plans to leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. The Dutch full back recently had a disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea. Despite this, Van der Wiel insists he is happy at PSG and wants to sign a new contract, saying he is ready to play whenever called upon. However, the club continues to be linked with Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could affect Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez has indicated he wants to leave Juventus this summer to return to Boca Juniors in Argentina, despite his contract running until 2016. Boca president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to completing a deal but stated Tevez must first terminate his Juventus contract. The 31-year-old striker, who came through Boca's youth academy and scored 26 league goals for them before leaving in 2005, is currently Serie A's top scorer with 17 goals this season. Juventus have accepted his desire to leave and are seeking replacements. Argentina manager Tata Martino said any move would not affect Tevez's international career, noting that both Juventus and Boca are great teams.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, overturning a 3-1 deficit from the first leg to advance to the semi-finals. During the match, manager Pep Guardiola tore his grey trousers, exposing his underwear, and joked afterwards that he would need to buy new ones. Bayern led 5-0 at half-time, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski securing the dominant victory.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a three-vehicle collision on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. A 40-year-old man and five-year-old boy with chest injuries were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and six-year-old girl with arm and abdominal injuries. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped and freed by rescue crews using hydraulic cutting equipment. The highway was closed for several hours with diversions in place.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil visited an Apple store on Thursday and received an Apple Watch, which he showed off on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. The 26-year-old, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to start in Arsenal's crucial Premier League match against Chelsea on Sunday at 4pm. Arsenal trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining. The team has been boosted by Jack Wilshere's return after five months out injured, though he was on the bench for their FA Cup semi-final win over Reading on April 18. Arsenal legend Ray Parlour praised Wilshere as a quality player and the future of the club, but expressed concern about his fitness record, noting he hasn't had a full season without long-term injury in three or four years.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby on Sunday at Old Trafford, having sent off three players from both clubs this season. Vincent Kompany received two yellow cards during Belgium's 1-0 win over Israel on March 31, suspending him for Wales in June. Clattenburg has issued only two Premier League red cards this season, both to United players: Tyler Blackett in a 5-3 loss to Leicester and Luke Shaw in a 1-1 draw with West Ham. The match carries significance as United sit one point above City following City's 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace, with second place behind Chelsea potentially at stake. United have won five consecutive league games while City have struggled since the new year. Simon Beck and Jake Collin will assist, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official.

Bob Katter, federal MP for Kennedy, released a statement accusing the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon like 'a little black puppet on a string' after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and admitted to a criminal past. Gordon quit the Queensland Labor Party but announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, affecting the Government's slim majority. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, questioned why Gordon's resignation was assumed when similar cases in federal parliament didn't prompt such expectations, suggesting racial attitudes were at play. The statement drew social media criticism for his terminology. Katter defended his language, citing his own background and experiences with racism, and stated he deliberately used the phrase to highlight what he perceived as racial overtones in the Government's treatment of Gordon.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy and creates dancing videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Despite being bullied and stared at, she wants people to understand that she is essentially the same as everyone else, just doing things slightly differently. She has made multiple videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," aiming to show that people shouldn't judge based on disability. Although doctors warned her parents she might never walk, Dayna now dances, drives, attends college, and has begun motivational speaking at local schools. Her goal is to turn negativity into positivity and change how people with disabilities are represented.

Orlando City have expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid. The Mexico international would appeal to Orlando's large Latin-American fanbase. However, Hernandez has attracted interest from eight European clubs including Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan, plus four Premier League sides: Southampton, Stoke, West Ham and Everton. Manchester United are willing to sell for approximately £8million. Separately, United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial proposal, with Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord all having contacted his father about a potential move.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and set it on fire at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. The incident occurred after the driver got into an argument with the suspects while pumping gas. According to the driver's grandmother, the suspects attempted to carjack her grandson at gunpoint, and when he ran away, they sprayed gasoline from the pump and ignited the vehicle while two passengers were still inside. No one was injured, but the car's front end was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel of Lamoni, surrendered his state license after the Iowa Board of Chiropractic detailed charges against him. Manuel signed an agreement admitting to accepting sex as payment for services, performing exorcisms on patients, and recommending patients stop taking prescribed medication. He pledged not to apply for license reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove the circumstances surrounding the revocation no longer exist before resuming practice. Despite these violations, Manuel received perfect patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com based on three survey responses.

The United States is filing a diplomatic complaint with Moscow after a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea north of Poland on Tuesday. The Pentagon deemed the Russian pilot's actions "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers performed at close proximity and high speed in international airspace. Russia's Defense Ministry claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, prompting the Russian jet to circle the aircraft for identification purposes. The U.S. European Command denied the transponder was off. This follows a similar incident a year ago when a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, which U.S. officials called one of the most dangerous close passes in decades. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft occur regularly in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot on March 27, days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains inside the agent's vehicle at the Marriott Springhill Suites. Police believe the thief broke the rear window, attached a rope to the case, and used another vehicle's momentum to rip it through the window, damaging the window frame. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. Evidence including skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken case handle were found at the scene. Some items were recovered at a nearby hotel, but the rifle remains missing. The rifle's serial number was entered into a national database, and the Secret Service was notified before the presidential visit. Police are uncertain whether the agent's vehicle was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra, by stomping on his head, cutting his throat and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time, with evidence showing his mental state had been declining in the lead-up to the incident. Mullen cited Costa's fluctuating mood during triple 0 calls made during the attack and a trail of faeces suggesting confusion as indicators of his compromised mental state. The prosecutor suggested Costa feigned memory loss, which Mullen denied. Costa's mental state is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines being on the pitch with a record of 15 successful penalties from 16 Premier League attempts. Barkley's 10th minute penalty, awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon, was saved by goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Martinez stated that Romelu Lukaku would normally take penalties when on the pitch, but otherwise he allows three or four players to decide based on how they feel in the moment. The incident recalled a previous controversy in January when Kevin Mirallas took the ball from Baines to take a penalty and missed against West Brom. Barkley's miss did not prove costly as Mirallas scored the winning goal after 29 minutes.

Two passengers were found dead inside their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday in Puerto Rico. The cruise line indicated the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured and authorities including the FBI were notified and are investigating. Cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin door. The ship had departed Tampa, Florida on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico at the time of the discovery.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has begun his role as coach of Curacao with a victory in World Cup qualifying. The Caribbean island team advanced to the second CONCACAF qualifying round for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg, winning 4-3 on aggregate following a 2-1 first-leg victory. Former Holland Under 21 international Charlton Vicento scored the decisive goal in the 87th minute as a substitute. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup semi-finalist as a player in 1998 and as assistant to Louis van Gaal in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won all major European competitions during his career, says keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would feel like winning a trophy. Leicester are seven points from safety with eight games remaining and haven't won since January. The Argentine midfielder, who won 15 trophies at Inter Milan and titles with River Plate and Real Madrid, signed a one-year deal with Leicester in the summer after leaving Italy. Despite many believing Leicester's relegation is inevitable, Cambiasso insists the team has chances to win matches and stay up, comparing the objective to winning cups with previous clubs. He is happy in the East Midlands and may extend his stay beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old woman named Gemma has two children under five by different fathers, both of whom she gave to her 52-year-old mother Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie stepped in to care for the children after social services threatened to take them away. Debbie is now threatening to ban Gemma from seeing the children due to her daughter's drinking, partying, and use of legal high MKat. Debbie also suspects Gemma of stealing an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle, and Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother previously. According to Debbie, Gemma went off the rails at age 13 with drinking and underage sex, and while excited about pregnancy, gave up on motherhood four months after each birth. The children call Debbie "mum" rather than grandma, and Debbie says Gemma doesn't care about her children or put them first.

During Chelsea's 1-0 victory over Manchester United at Stamford Bridge, Eden Hazard scored following a controversial build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, sending him to the ground near the half-way line. Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball and passed to Oscar, whose back-heel found Hazard to score. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness unanimously agreed during half-time analysis that Terry's tackle was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness described it as a forearm smash with an elbow to the back of Falcao's head, Henry said he would have wanted a foul called in that position, and Redknapp acknowledged that while Falcao could have been stronger, the challenge from behind should have been penalized.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas, Texas on Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out. Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were all safely evacuated before the bus burst into flames. The fire destroyed everything in the back lounge except Scott's Bible. Band members Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space-based lasers that would convert sunlight into energy and beam it back to Earth. The satellites would orbit Earth with mirrors to harvest sunlight, convert it to laser light using semi-conductors, and transmit the energy to solar panels on the ground. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to move testing to Portugal. The technology could make solar power viable in Scotland and restore power to disaster areas. The lasers would not be powerful enough to cause harm, unlike fictional depictions, though Dr Quarterman acknowledges concerns about control of the satellites. This differs from a separate Tokyo research proposal to use lasers on the International Space Station to clear small space debris by pushing it into Earth's atmosphere.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has absconded from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6:15pm on Tuesday. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction in August for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus by stroking her hand. He also admitted ten offences involving indecent images of children and was found to have children's clothes, books, and dolls at his home. Munden, who suffers from autism and learning difficulties, was sentenced to a hospital order. He is approximately 5ft 8ins tall, heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard before leaving. Police have launched a manhunt and are urgently seeking information about his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back more than $2.6 million in gifts to Rochelle Sterling, wife of former NBA team owner Donald Sterling. Shelly Sterling sued Stiviano, claiming she targeted wealthy older men and that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to buy Stiviano luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued the gifts were legitimate and she didn't take advantage of Sterling. The ruling allows an injured spouse to recover damages from recipients of such gifts. Donald Sterling lost ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers in 2014 after racist remarks were recorded, in which he criticized Stiviano for associating with African-Americans on social media. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banned Sterling from the league, fined him $2.5 million, and terminated his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry has criticised Arsenal's transfer activity and stated the club needs to sign four top players in the summer - a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder and striker - to compete for the Premier League title. Speaking after Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea, Henry specifically questioned whether Olivier Giroud, despite scoring 14 league goals this season, is good enough to lead Arsenal to the title. Henry cited Chelsea as an example, noting they won the league after purchasing Courtois, Matic, Fabregas and Costa, and argued Arsenal must make similar quality signings to create competition within the squad. Arsenal are currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim kept the abuse secret for years until learning Van Ryn had been caught. She told the court she didn't understand the abuse was wrong as a child and didn't know it was illegal. She expressed fear about future relationships, stating Van Ryn stole her right to share her body with someone for the first time. The woman has suffered depression since age 14, been hospitalized for self-harm, and attempted suicide. She worries about when Van Ryn, currently in custody, will be released and how the abuse will affect her relationships with men. Van Ryn sat calmly in court and did not look at the victim during her testimony.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that has kept him out for over a year since March 2014. After impressing last season, his progress was halted by the injury sustained after the Champions League last-16 second leg against Bayern Munich. The Germany Under-21 international recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21s against Reading, marking his second full match in a week, and reports feeling "better and better" as he nears a full return to action.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70 feet down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, in December. After a night out drinking in Cardiff with friends, Phillips caught a taxi home but didn't have enough money to pay the fare. He and his companions attempted to flee from the taxi driver, who gave chase but stopped when visibility became poor. Phillips ran into the darkness, became disoriented, and leapt over a fence, unaware of the cliff edge ahead. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker on the rocky beach below the disused Northern Promenade. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting Phillips had no way of knowing the danger in the dark. Phillips had grown up in Barry, studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham, and worked for Pretty Green clothing label.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay crisis have not received compensation, with only 2,191 compensation applications approved between April last year and January this year, totaling £203,066 in payouts. The problems began when HM Passport Office struggled to process 3.6 million applications, resulting in over half a million passports stuck in the system by mid-June. Ministers refused blanket refunds to families who paid extra for rushed documents or missed trips, stating it would create a precedent, despite the Home Affairs Committee's calls for compensation. Meanwhile, the passport agency made a £42 million profit during the chaos, and managers received bonuses up to £3,500. Many affected travelers, including those who applied weeks in advance and paid for upgrades, lost money on canceled trips and received no reimbursement.

A 1930s semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol, has remained unchanged for over 80 years and is being auctioned with a guide price of £200,000-£250,000. The three-bedroom property retains original features including stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom with original tiles and wooden floor, wood-panelled hallway, 1930s kitchen cupboards, and vintage food tins from brands like Cadbury's Marvel, Tate and Lyle, and Colman's Mustard.
