Near Naples are culturally significant sites including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum. Famous ruins exist worldwide, including ancient sites in China, the Indus valley, Judea, Zimbabwe, Greek and Roman sites in the Mediterranean, Egyptian sites, and Incan and Mayan sites in the Americas.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin. It follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran in the desert landscape of 1980 West Texas. Tommy Lee Jones plays Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in the film. Jones has had numerous other notable roles including a former Texas Ranger in Lonesome Dove, Agent K in Men in Black, Two-Face in Batman Forever, and various other characters in films and television series.

Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, located in the San Francisco Bay Area. The name means "tall tree" in Spanish, derived from "palo" (stick/tree) and "alto" (tall).

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born Albert Lawrence Einstein on July 22, 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author and comedian. Finding Dory was directed by Andrew Stanton with co-direction by Angus MacLane, and the screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code transmits text information through on-off tones, lights, or clicks that skilled individuals can understand without special equipment. The code's character lengths vary inversely with their frequency in English to increase communication speed. Morse code is less sensitive to poor signal conditions than voice communication and remains comprehensible to humans without decoding devices. It can be sent using improvised methods that are easily keyed on and off, making it one of the simplest and most versatile telecommunication methods, useful in emergencies and for identification purposes such as on amateur radio repeaters.
Alexandra Anna Daddario is an American actress born on March 16, 1986.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 21:47 UTC with a magnitude of 6.5. The Hindu Kush is an 800 km mountain range extending along the Afghan-Pakistan border from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, known in Ancient Greek as the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae. The range features numerous high snow-capped peaks, with its highest point being Tirich Mir at 7,708 meters, located in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan.
Ripon College in Wisconsin had approximately 840 students as of 2015, with most students residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand name for sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and other media worldwide that are controlled or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch's family. Murdoch served as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate, which split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013. Murdoch and his family own both companies through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a US-based women's apparel company that specializes in tomboyish-style clothing.
Bessie Smith was an American blues singer who lived from April 15, 1894 to September 26, 1937.

Speech recognition is an inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It incorporates knowledge and research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering fields.
Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and died 1 December 1947, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that first aired on BBC One on 8 March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge was released on 20 October 1995, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol. The film was shot in India, London and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

The passage describes two different people named Tim/Timothy Roth. Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director. Tim Roth, born December 6, 1975, is a guitarist and backing vocalist who is the only remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is an actor who has won two Academy Awards for Best Actor, for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008). He made his film debut in Taps (1981) and appeared in various films throughout the 1980s, including Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982). He received critical recognition for crime dramas like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). Penn earned his first Academy Award nomination for Dead Man Walking (1995), which also won him Best Actor at the Berlin Film Festival. He received additional Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001) before his two wins. He also directed Into the Wild (2007), which received critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

The passage describes Earth's formation and evolution. Volcanic outgassing created the primordial atmosphere and ocean, though the atmosphere lacked oxygen and would have been toxic to most modern life. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed and liquid water appeared on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape Earth's oceans, continents, and living species. The biosphere, now dominated by human activity, produces significant effects on the atmosphere and Earth's surface systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, soil conditions, and air and water quality. Water covers 71% of Earth's surface.
Nuuk, also known as Godthåb, is the capital and largest city of Greenland and is part of the municipality of Sermersooq.

How to Train Your Dragon 2 is written and directed by Dean DeBlois. The voice cast includes Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig, all returning from the first film. New additions to the cast are Cate Blanchett voicing Valka, Djimon Hounsou voicing Drago, and Kit Harington.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson and David Hyde Pierce. The film is a pastiche of sex comedies from its era, particularly the three Doris Day and Rock Hudson films: Pillow Talk (1959), Lover Come Back (1961), and Send Me No Flowers (1964). Down with Love is also a TV series that first broadcast in Taiwan on China Television from January 31, 2010 to May 23, 2010 on Sundays at 22:00-23:30, and on Gala Television Variety Show from February 2, 2010 to May 30, 2010 on Sundays at 20:00-21:30.
The album "Paris" by Paris Hilton incorporates elements of multiple genres including reggae, soul, and pop rock in its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman, starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. The film featured several actors in their first significant roles, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, as well as early career appearances by Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song "Love or Lust" from the film Deep Cover, and for performing choruses on classic West Coast rap songs including Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride."

The University of Mississippi draws approximately 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent of its total student body from Mississippi. Minorities comprise 23 percent of the student population, and international students represent 90 different nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet-Kerner Productions, with distribution handled by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, she co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime series Unreal. She also stars as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren (1782-1862) was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. A Democratic Party member, he previously served as eighth Vice President (1833-37) and tenth Secretary of State (1829-31) under Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a key supporter and organizer for Jackson's 1828 presidential campaign and briefly served as Governor of New York for two months before resigning to become Secretary of State. After resigning as Secretary of State in 1831, which helped Jackson resolve the Petticoat affair, Van Buren received a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.

Camden, New Jersey is home to two educational institutions: Rutgers University-Camden, originally founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state located in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. It ranks as the tenth most populous state and has the 11th most extensive total area, making it the largest state by total area east of the Mississippi River. Michigan is unique as the only state composed of two peninsulas, which contributes to its status as one of the leading U.S. states for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive paperbacks priced at sixpence, sold through mainstream retailers like Woolworths, making high-quality fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film "Australia" was produced in four locations: Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

The passage describes three different subjects: Billy Ray Cyrus, an American country music singer, songwriter, actor and philanthropist who helped popularize country music globally; Excuse My French, the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana; and Excuse My French, a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama about his experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia, which faced censorship issues due to its themes of religious discrimination but was adjusted to preserve its core concept.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 film Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean-American independent dance film.

The passage describes "Bad Romance," a song by Lady Gaga from her 2009 extended play The Fame Monster. After an illegal demo leak, Gaga premiered the final version at Alexander McQueen's Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009, followed by the cover art release. The song achieved worldwide chart success, selling 12 million copies globally and becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. The passage also mentions "Bad Romance" is a 2011 independent drama film (titled "Les Mauvais Romans").

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including franchises such as Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, as well as other films like Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. The studio also produced Trollhunters, a computer-animated fantasy television series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix in collaboration with Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks, known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer born on 8 August 1966 who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr., born 18 September 1989, is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, previously holding the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

The passage describes the Murdoch family's leadership roles in major media companies. Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and has full control as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate, which split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013. His younger son, James Murdoch, born December 13, 1972, is an Australian, British, American businessman who serves as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/model in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with most of her income derived from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR) was an American rock band that was active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are typically detected through radiographic examination, commonly known as an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield is a large region in south Wales characterized by abundant coal deposits, with particular concentration in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental football club competition organized by CONCACAF for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was originally called the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when first organized in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 after her husband George's death and her eldest son Edward's ascension to the throne. Edward abdicated that same year to marry Wallis Simpson. Mary then supported her second son Albert, who became George VI and reigned until 1952. She died in 1953 during her granddaughter Elizabeth II's reign, before Elizabeth's coronation.
The film Poseidon earned $181,674,817 in worldwide box office revenue against a production budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was established in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton are tied for the most wins in this category, with three awards each.

Human trafficking involves trading humans for forced labour, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that forced labor alone generated $150 billion in profits annually as of 2014. Of the victims, 68% (14.2 million) were exploited for labor, 22% (4.5 million) for sexual exploitation, and 10% (2.2 million) in state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 film that received a sequel titled Rio 2, which was released on April 11, 2014.

The passage describes two historical figures named Francis I. The first was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany from 1708-1765, though his wife held the real power. The second was King of France from 1515-1547, the first from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois. Known by nicknames including "Francis of the Large Nose" and "Knight-King," he personally fought wars against his rival Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain. When unsuccessful, he controversially formed an alliance with Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian war of 1536-1538 was fought between Francis I of France and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU or Běidà) is a major Chinese research university in Beijing and member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it was China's first modern national university, replacing the ancient Imperial Academy. Initially, it also functioned as China's highest education administration. PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for three main characteristics: his appearance, particularly his friendly mutton chops; his distinctive gravelly voice; and his distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant threats to humans, primarily through reduced crop yields that endanger food security and rising sea levels that force the abandonment of populated coastal areas.
Australia is a 2008 epic historical romantic adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. It is an Australian-American-British production.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mainly with the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses various cultural expressions including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, and superstitions. It also involves traditional practices such as food-making and craft-making. Folklore more broadly consists of oral traditions including tales, proverbs, and jokes.

The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. The unit additionally created training films and provided training for combat cameramen.

The passage describes two different people named James Jones. James Jones the author won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel "From Here to Eternity," which was adapted into a film and later a television series. James Jones the basketball player averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He won three NBA championships (two with the Heat, one with the Cavaliers), reached the NBA Finals for seven consecutive years with LeBron James in 2017, finished third in three-point percentage in 2007-08, and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999 as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, with the resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, the longest tenure of any actor in that role, and for narrating Little Britain. He has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site contains a cleanup project, a commercial nuclear power plant called the Columbia Generating Station, and scientific research and development centers including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the executive branch, particularly regarding the President, senior executives, and policies. The position is appointed directly by the President without requiring Senate confirmation, and despite not being a Cabinet position, it remains highly prominent due to frequent media briefings that inform the public.

Kentucky is nicknamed the "Bluegrass State" due to bluegrass in its pastures from fertile soil. The Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky contains the major cities of Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also starred in The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper who was formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of "Despacito" were released: an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). Initially broadcast via closed-circuit television from 1983-1986, it transitioned to pay-per-view in 1987, becoming the first NWA event to do so. This change occurred after WWF scheduled their own pay-per-view event, Survivor Series, and demanded exclusivity from cable providers. In 2014, WWE Network made all Starrcade events (1983-2000) available in their pay-per-view section, rating them TV-MA due to violent content, particularly the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director who works in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created specifically for its streaming service and marks the first new Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played football as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also played for Rhein Fire in the World League of American Football.

The passage provides information about three separate entertainment-related topics: French Montana's debut studio album titled "Excuse My French," a 2014 Egyptian comedy film also called "Excuse My French" directed by Amr Salama and based on his personal school experiences, and Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (Plan B), a British hip hop artist, actor, and filmmaker born in 1983.

A floppy disk (also called floppy, diskette, or disk) is a type of disk storage consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic storage disk sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure. The enclosure is lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. Between 1960 and 1996, the country endured a bloody civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, which included genocidal massacres of the Maya population carried out by the military.

Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments designed for grasping and holding objects. The term "forceps" is primarily used in medical contexts, while outside medicine, similar tools are commonly called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after its sixth season concluded as the highest rated drama on cable television.

Dr. Jack Shephard, played by Matthew Fox, is the fictional protagonist of the ABC television series Lost. The show aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons with 121 total episodes. The first season averaged approximately 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey is an American actor born November 4, 1969. Since 2011, he has focused on dramatic roles in films including The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. The 2012 film Mud stars McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer best known for his books including Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine, his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 – January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author and engineer who oversaw the completion of Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father Gutzon Borglum's death in March 1941. Gutzon Borglum created the sculpture's design and led the project from 1927-1941 with his son Lincoln's help, before Lincoln assumed leadership to complete the construction.

The film Underdog was directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens who are among the first people from a space habitat called "The Ark" to return to Earth after a devastating nuclear apocalypse. The main characters include Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke's mother), Marcus Kane (a council member on the Ark), and Thelonious Jaha (the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father).

The Concert for Bangladesh was a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project that generated awareness and considerable funds, despite later financial problems due to its pioneering nature. It provided valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent projects, notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is considered one of India's influential filmmakers who revolutionized the Tamil film industry and altered the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas on August 27, 1858, during the second of seven debates with Abraham Lincoln in Freeport, Illinois. These Lincoln-Douglas Debates were part of the 1858 United States Senate race in Illinois, with Lincoln as the Republican candidate challenging incumbent Democratic Senator Douglas. The debates, particularly those in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted large crowds from neighboring states due to the national significance of the slavery issue.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. The film stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She launched her professional writing career in 1976 with Interview with the Vampire while living in California, and continued with sequels in the 1980s. Though initial critical reception was mixed, she gained popularity with both critics and readers during the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 recorded in the 2010 United States Census. It ranks as the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population consisted mostly of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for The Canyons, a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader. The film was an original work and received critical derision.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, were seven debates between Abraham Lincoln (Republican candidate for U.S. Senate from Illinois) and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas (Democratic Party candidate). The debates took place in seven Illinois towns.

Homer is the name given by ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are central works of ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who lived from April 8, 1974 to February 2, 2013. He was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas on February 2, 2013.

The passage describes the band memberships and history of Brad Wilk, a drummer who played in multiple rock bands. Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Chris Cornell from Soundgarden and three Rage Against the Machine members: Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Wilk began drumming for Greta in 1990, then co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Morello and de la Rocha in August 1991. He played with Rage Against the Machine from 1991-2000 and 2007-11, and with Audioslave from 2001-07. As of 2016, Wilk was playing in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consisted of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel written by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town and parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. The University of Mississippi has approximately 55 percent of undergraduates and 60 percent overall enrollment from Mississippi, with 23 percent minority students and international students from 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with a scheduled premiere date of June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in multiple political positions throughout his career. He was elected to the New York State Assembly twice (1784-1785 and 1798-1799), appointed as New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), served as a U.S. Senator from New York (1791-1797), and achieved the highest point of his career as vice president.

The Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s for the Soviet space program and remains in service today. It was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with 8 unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned launches. The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up when de la Rocha quit due to tensions over the band's direction. De la Rocha pursued a solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, recording three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella in April 2007, marking their first performance together in seven years. Renegades, their fourth studio album, was released on December 5, 2000 by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of the constituent companies of the BSE SENSEX index and is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country and ninth-most-populous Asian country. It is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the highest economic growth rates in the world, achieving the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. Vietnam is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary who died on 23 March 1931 at age 23. He committed two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India, and his execution made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement. He became a popular folk hero after his death.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," which was directed by Nitesh Tiwari and featured Aamir Khan. The film's title refers to a wrestling competition.

James VI and I, born 19 June 1566 and died 27 March 1625, became King of Scotland as James VI on 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death. Scotland and England remained individual sovereign states with separate parliaments, judiciary, and laws, but were ruled by James in personal union. He strongly advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland and faced many difficulties with Parliament during his English reign.

Danielle Cormack, born 26 December 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was part of the original core cast of Shortland Street and is known for roles including Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her other work includes the 2009 film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her most notable recent role was Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, which she starred in for four years before leaving in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer who is best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who starred and co-starred in multiple films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales and 757,000 total US copies sold. It was Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the United States and became the ninth best-selling album of 2013 globally with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, in 2006. He departed from the band in 2009, making Stadium Arcadium the group's last album to feature him as guitarist.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister and implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, regarded by some as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, while debates about Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who has written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has performed acting roles and also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and Spain's third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative centre. It is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community is an autonomous community of Spain.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in a television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended with its third season being the final season, as announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It incorporates knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search functions, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft voice input. The field has advanced significantly through deep learning methods, with major industry players like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and Nuance adopting these technologies as the core of their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf was an American businessman and comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman starting in 1970. The convention was originally founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention. Alf lived from January 26, 1952 to January 4, 2012.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl share the lead at 16 under par after Dubuisson shot 67. McIlroy is one shot behind at 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat, having carded his third consecutive 67. McIlroy's round featured an eagle on the 12th after being level par through 10 holes, where he had dropped shots at the third and 10th. The 26-year-old four-time major winner, who hasn't won a title since May and recently recovered from an ankle injury sustained in July, is pursuing a third Race to Dubai title in four years and currently leads Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining. English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland are positioned at fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman of al-Wefaq stated that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer concrete solutions and representation from the royal family, specifically the Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, viewed as a reformist. Hardliners, including the Prime Minister since 1971, oppose dialogue, fearing concessions will encourage further demands. Sheikh Salman acknowledged young protesters have lost faith in opposition parties but believes working with royal family reformists is necessary. He referenced a seven-point agreement with the crown prince in March 2011 that was abandoned when GCC troops intervened. He expressed hope that US Secretary of State John Kerry would pressure Bahrain harder on human rights than his predecessor, and criticized the UK for only privately urging reform rather than speaking publicly. Al-Wefaq will continue calling for peaceful demonstrations despite a ban on public gatherings, and demands the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders and activists, whose participation Sheikh Salman considers essential for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a several-month illness. A highly influential figure in the early-music movement, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it across six continents for 30 years and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah was named among the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held positions with various prestigious institutions, including serving as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, while also teaching at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Colleagues remembered him as extraordinarily generous, a natural academic with an amazing capacity for knowledge, and a great ambassador for historically informed music who helped launch the careers of many leading musicians.

In 2015-16, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure from nine years prior, with only one case remaining unresolved as of March 2016. Sharp instruments, predominantly knives, were the most common killing method, accounting for 51% of cases. Of those accused where status was known, 31% were identified as being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the continued decline in homicides and violent crime, emphasizing ongoing efforts in education, enforcement, and supporting at-risk communities. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned that previous year's figures were revised upward, and noted that sexual crime reached a 45-year high while attempted murder and serious assault increased by 27%.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland on Saturday, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win of the season. Despite Dan Gosling giving Bournemouth the lead with their first goal in three games, Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe's penalty secured victory for Sunderland. Manager Howe expressed frustration at his team's inability to convert chances, noting they had scored six against Hull two weeks prior but failed to capitalize on numerous opportunities in this match, even after Sunderland's Steven Pienaar was sent off.

Mr Abbott defended Australia's policy of detaining migrants attempting to reach its shores by boat and sending them to offshore processing camps, arguing this approach prevents deaths at sea. The New York Times criticized the policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and of "dubious legality" in a Thursday editorial. Abbott cited the death of three-year-old Syrian Alan Kurdi as evidence that stopping boats prevents drownings, claiming Australia has successfully stopped illegal boats. He also sparked controversy by stating Islamic State was worse than the Nazis because IS "boasts about their evil" while Nazis tried to hide it. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry criticized this comparison as "injudicious and unfortunate," noting the fundamental difference between terrorism and systematic state-implemented genocide. Abbott stood by his comments but said he was not ranking evil.

Washington blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians and suspended bilateral talks with Russia aimed at sustaining the cessation of hostilities in Syria. The US accused Russia of failing to uphold commitments and being unwilling or unable to ensure Syrian regime compliance, citing targeting of hospitals and the September 19 attack on a humanitarian convoy. Aleppo has faced heavy aerial bombardment since a ceasefire ended two weeks prior, with hundreds killed including children, and 250,000 people trapped in eastern Aleppo. Russia denied involvement in the convoy strike and accused the US of failing to fulfill agreements, particularly regarding humanitarian conditions and separating jihadist groups from moderate opposition. The US withdrew personnel dispatched for a planned Joint Implementation Centre in Geneva, though both sides agreed to continue counter-terrorism discussions to avoid clashes.

Downing Street supported a Policy Exchange report proposing that councils sell high-value social housing properties when they become vacant, which could raise £4.5bn annually and fund construction of 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. The think tank defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the regional average, representing 21.8% of total social housing stock (816,000 properties worth up to £159bn). With 3.5% of stock becoming vacant yearly, approximately 28,500 properties could be sold annually. Policy Exchange argues this would create the largest social house building programme since the 1970s and reduce the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by 500,000. The prime minister's spokesman said councils should use housing stock efficiently and consider such sales. Labour opposed the plan, calling it a failed policy that would break up mixed communities and drive out low-wage families from neighborhoods. Critics, including the National Housing Federation and Labour MPs, warned it would push less well-off residents out of expensive areas, creating segregated communities. Housing Minister Grant Shapps defended the government's £19.5bn affordable housing programme expected to deliver up to 170,000 homes.

A 25-year-old man named Gareth Colfer-Williams died at his home in Swansea during a measles epidemic that has affected 942 people since November, with 83 requiring hospitalization. He had recently been hospitalized for asthma, then developed a rash covering most of his body and saw a GP before being found dead the next morning. A post-mortem examination could not determine if measles was the primary cause of death. Laboratory tests confirmed measles, but an inquest has been scheduled to allow further testing. His family is unsure how he contracted the disease as no close relatives have it.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16 that allegedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in a National League match between two in-form sides. Guiseley took the lead on 15 minutes when James Hurst's throw-in found Jake Lawlor who scored into an empty net. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute through Wesley York, who curled a shot into the top-right corner after a slip by substitute Derek Asamoah. Gateshead were unbeaten in nine matches while Guiseley were unbeaten in five going into the game.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at the football club to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed by a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed work will begin, following Bristol City Council's approval in November. After signing the section 106 agreement, there is a six-week judicial review period, and if no review occurs by March, redevelopment will start in May.

Cuadrilla suspended shale gas drilling operations in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude tremor occurred, the second earthquake in two months. The company will examine data from the British Geological Survey before deciding whether to resume fracking. A previous 2.3 magnitude tremor on 1 April had a similar location and mechanism near the Preese Hall drilling site. The BGS confirmed that injecting pressurized water during fracking can cause rocks to fracture and produce earthquakes, noting this is well known in oil extraction and geothermal engineering. Both earthquakes occurred approximately 2km from the drill site at a depth of about 2km. Cuadrilla's chief executive stated the analysis and consultation would take several weeks. The process remains controversial, with US environmentalists raising concerns about shale gas contaminating drinking water, though a Commons committee suggested UK environmental problems could be managed through tight regulation.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool bagpiper who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud out of three charges. In April 2015, he played bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner displayed, giving the impression he was collecting money for the charity. While the campaign chairman had given Carpenter permission to display the banner, he had explicitly stated it should not be used to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter, who denied the charges, claimed he was simply busking and the banner was a tribute to victims, not an attempt to deceive. He was cleared of two other fraud counts and will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in a Championship match. Grant Ward scored first with a scuffed shot, then Luke Varney capitalized on QPR goalkeeper Alex Smithies' clearance error to roll into an empty net. Tom Lawrence added the third from a long-range Cole Skuse shot. Despite Ipswich having failed to score in seven of their previous 10 games, they dominated throughout, with QPR offering little attacking threat except Sandro's late header against the post. The victory moved Ipswich up four places to 14th, while QPR dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, while QPR boss Ian Holloway expressed disappointment with his team's mental toughness after the second goal.

Wells, 23, performed well in the T20 Blast last season with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club's direction and praised the elite performance environment created by the coaches, which motivates players to be involved.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for their second consecutive win. Churcher praised front row players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams for leading the team, noting the front five made over 70 tackles. The team faces seven lower-ranked opponents in their next eight games, plus league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher acknowledged the Chinnor performance was emotionally strong but not complete, emphasizing the need to build on the result.

Police arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, at a Kolkata railway station for the rape of a 74-year-old nun. He is the sixth arrest in the case, with two of eight identified suspects still untraced. The five previously arrested accused have named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on intelligence that he had fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage but was returning to Kolkata. The attack occurred on 14 March in Ranaghat town, where money was stolen from a convent school, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped. The incident sparked outrage and street protests across India.

This passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, who explains key reasons behind changes in consumer purchasing behavior. Major factors discussed include the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports, which influenced the types of products available and popular among UK consumers. The video also examines shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. A non-interactive version is available for older browsers that cannot support the interactive format.

Two women in Scotland, a 71-year-old from Sandyhills and another from Stranraer, were scammed by callers falsely claiming to be from BT or BT technical support. The fraudsters reported problems with internet or phone services and gained remote access to the victims' computers to steal money. The incidents occurred on 15 September and 22 September. Police warn that criminals can easily gain computer access through cold calls and urge people never to give banking details or account numbers over the phone, as legitimate banks and businesses never request this information.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions, where he was head coach. The Scotland assistant coach will lead the third-placed Championship side in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's work at Swinton under difficult circumstances. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes and Salford, has been replaced at Swinton by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

A horse rider was found unconscious with head injuries on Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. The rider was very cold from lying on wet sand. Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded. The rider received treatment at the scene before being airlifted to University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global satellite-based flight tracking system. Representatives from over 160 countries at the World Radiocommunication Conference set aside a radio frequency enabling satellites to receive ADS-B transmissions from aircraft, allowing real-time tracking worldwide. The decision addresses weaknesses exposed by the March 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 with 239 people aboard, which vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing and is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean. The current ground-based radar system leaves approximately 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The International Civil Aviation Organisation has set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines requiring aircraft to transmit their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez disappeared at age five in August 2002 when his father, Bobby Hernandez, claimed to be taking him to pre-school but fled. Now 18 and living in Cleveland with his father, Julian was identified after encountering problems applying for college, prompting an FBI tip on 30 October. The FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed his identity, and his mother has been notified. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on $250,000 bail, charged with kidnapping and tampering with records to obtain a 2012 driver's licence. Authorities suspected the father at the time of disappearance.

Firefighters responded to a fire on 2 March at a waste site in Duncan Street operated by Asset and Land Group for Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. Following the fire, the Environment Agency suspended and later revoked the company's environmental permit, with the decision taking effect 7 August unless appealed. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the site nine times in the previous year and raised concerns to the EA in February about potential fire impacts on residents, transport and the environment, though the operators were found broadly compliant with fire safety legislation. The company must remove all waste from the site and will no longer be able to operate there after the revocation date. The fire's cause remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills related to Ukraine. The first would allow Russia to accept territory from a disintegrating neighboring state based on a referendum or request from local leaders, bypassing the current requirement for a treaty with the neighboring state. The second bill would fast-track Russian passport applications for Ukrainians, eliminating fees, residency requirements, financial prerequisites, and reducing processing time from one year to two months. The bills are linked to the crisis in Crimea, where many residents already hold Russian passports, particularly in Sevastopol where Russia's Black Sea Fleet is based. Russian MPs cite the situation as similar to Russia's 2008 intervention in Georgia, which resulted in Moscow's control over Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

McLaren, a team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, as drivers. Their decline began in 2013 with chassis design issues, and while the car has improved, Honda power-unit problems persist. This contrasts sharply with their dominant McLaren-Honda era, particularly 1988 when they won 15 of 16 races with Senna and Prost. Their last constructors' title was in 1998 with Mika Hakkinen. The team was excluded from the 2007 constructors' championship despite scoring the most points, due to possessing illegal Ferrari technical information and receiving a $100m fine. Another scandal in 2009 involved Lewis Hamilton and Dave Ryan misleading stewards. McLaren's history shows cycles of triumph and decline across five decades since Bruce McLaren founded the team. Ron Dennis, who previously built the team to dominance in the 1980s, returned after the disastrous 2013 season. Dennis insists McLaren will break Mercedes' current dominance and become the next title winners, which is why Alonso rejoined in 2015 despite their difficult 2007 relationship.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January after leaving Phoenix Gym and getting into his car. Three Liverpool men aged 29, 29, and 32 have been arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the attackers waited outside the gym for approximately an hour before the shooting. Detectives are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene at speed through several roads including Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road, and are appealing for witnesses captured on CCTV who have not yet come forward.

This passage outlines five ways to experience Christmas spiritually online. Everyday Church Online runs virtual services with streaming sermons for a global congregation from 61 countries, featuring Star Wars-themed Christmas sermons called "The Hope Awakens." Guardians of Ancora is a free fantasy game for 8-11 year-olds with 45,000 players, where children complete Bible-themed quests including finding baby Jesus at Christmas. Various nativity videos have gained online popularity, including "The Digital Story of Nativity" told through social media updates (six million views) and the Churches Advertising Network's video showing a modern couple transforming into Mary and Joseph (250,000 views). Next Manga has released Bible stories in Japanese cartoon form as apps and e-books in 33 languages, including 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees. Finally, churches use social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to share spiritual messages and connect with communities during Christmas, with religious leaders viewing these as effective communication tools.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers including Blaenau Gwent council offering around 320 hectares as replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting expert testimony regarding potential habitat and plant life damage from a proposed circuit development. Natural Resources Wales stated it was difficult to conclude the replacement land was of equal value but is not opposing the development overall. Developers presented an ecology report claiming a net gain in biodiversity through habitat enhancement work, which Gwent wildlife trust disputed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation following the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers making the final decision.

Novaya Gazeta reported on 1 April that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. Chechen Muslim clerics met two days later, declaring the report insulted their faith and dignity, with their resolution stating "retribution will catch up with the true instigators." The newspaper views this as a call for reprisals against journalists. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy and said detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, with his spokesman claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya. Novaya Gazeta's editor stated journalists would continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee and accuses Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses, threatening to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, has received substantial housing benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men over 35. The company profits by placing multiple unrelated people in one house and claiming individual housing benefit for each person, which exceeds the rent paid to landlords. In one example, the company claimed £2,114 monthly in benefits while paying the landlord £1,150, generating £11,568 annual profit per property. The company shares premises with Fresh Start Housing charity, both established by Samir Patel, which refers homeless clients to Investing Solutions. While neither organization acts illegally, tenants report unsuitable living conditions including lack of heating, rats, and damp. Wandsworth Council has paid the company over £2.1m in two years. A homeless charity representative called the arrangement "a new low," though Investing Solutions maintains it passes most rents to private landlords and Fresh Start states it refers clients to multiple housing providers.

Great Britain lost to the Netherlands in their final warm-up match before Eurobasket qualifying. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 for GB, who led for most of the first three quarters before the Dutch scored 10 unanswered points early in the fourth quarter to take control and win. The Netherlands were led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points. Coach Joe Prunty used his strongest lineup before cutting the roster for the six-game qualifying campaign, which begins in Hungary midweek. Prunty emphasized the need to compete on every play during the qualifiers and praised Gordon's performance despite noting the team lost some intensity at times.

The Nevada Athletic Commission received a waiver from Floyd Mayweather requesting to use 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves for his 154lbs bout against Conor McGregor. The NAC will debate this request on 16 August, as regulations typically require 10oz gloves at this weight, though exceptions can be made between 135-147lbs if justified and both fighters agree. NAC executive director Bob Bennett approved McGregor's boxing debut after reviewing extensive information, citing factors including McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz, who was rated as an outstanding boxer by trainer Virgil Hunter. Bennett noted McGregor's advantages in age (29 vs 40), size, and chin durability, while observing Mayweather hasn't scored a knockout in a decade. McGregor, the UFC lightweight champion, has been training with Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, though sparring partner Paulie Malignaggi left the camp after controversial images emerged. The fight could be the richest in boxing history despite criticism from major boxing figures.

The Sunday Post's London office on Fleet Street closes Friday, marking the departure of its last two journalists and the end of Fleet Street's era as Britain's newspaper hub. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith worked there for 32 and 25 years respectively. Fleet Street, home to the first British daily newspaper in 1702, was once the center of national journalism, with nearly every major paper operating within a half-mile radius. The street was famous for its pubs and bars frequented by journalists, and its newsrooms filled with typewriters and smoke. At its peak, newspapers provided 85% of public information. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping, triggering a bitter union dispute. By 1988, most national newspapers had relocated, adopting computerized printing technology. Former newspaper buildings now house businesses like Sainsbury's headquarters. Following redundancy, Smith becomes freelance while Sherriff plans to write his memoirs.

J.K. Rowling addressed abusive comments she received on Twitter, stating that supportive responses reminded her there are more decent people in the world. The Harry Potter author said she believes in standing up to bullies and that being a famous woman on Twitter isn't always enjoyable. She faced criticism after donating £1m to the Scottish independence referendum No campaign in 2014, having previously donated the same amount to Labour in 2008. Rowling revealed she was called "a traitor" for her political views and blocked some abusive users she believed were SNP supporters, though she noted she had positive exchanges with other SNP supporters with whom she shared political common ground. She refused to stay silent about abusive behavior to protect any political party's image. The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in Thursday's election, becoming the UK's third largest party.

The passage describes two University of Edinburgh studies examining links between poverty and crime in Scotland. The first study, tracking 4,300 young people since 1998, found children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children committing the same crime, and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Poverty increased the likelihood of violence for both boys and girls, even when accounting for other risk factors. Police contact was the strongest predictor of young people not being in education, employment or training by age 18. The second study found that despite falling crime rates in Scotland, victims experiencing the most crime remain in the most deprived communities. Half of the highest crime areas were in the top 20% for chronic health problems, and a third were in the top 20% for unemployment. Researchers concluded that contact with juvenile justice systems inadvertently reproduces conditions where violence flourishes, and questioned whether inequality is being adequately addressed. The Scottish government responded that Scotland is becoming safer with recorded crime at a 41-year low and cited investments to tackle poverty.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate, Kilkee, in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August. It is alleged Walsh was one of three people who entered the estate after 01:00 Sunday looking for Mr Haugh. A fight ensued involving weapons when they encountered Mr Haugh and another man, with additional individuals joining the altercation. Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene. Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Two other arrested men were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted in May 2014 questioning whether Tom Elliott would reveal "how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR." Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years between 1982 and 1992 and has a clear MoD record. He is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The High Court ordered Flanagan to issue an apology accepting the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation." The apology must be posted on Twitter. Judgment on compensation was reserved. The insurance firm indemnifying MLAs refused to cover Flanagan for any compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Elliott stated he was vindicated and disappointed the matter took 19 months to resolve.

Hawick Knitwear, a company dating back to 1874 with over 230 employees, has increased its weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 units to meet rising demand. The production boost follows better than expected sales of its own branded range launched in January and growth in its established private label business. The company was purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year. Hawick Knitwear sells to multiple European countries including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain, as well as to the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributes the success to increased orders from domestic and international markets for both private label and own-brand products, crediting dedicated staff and expressing confidence in continued future success.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving after his VW Golf struck 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright failed to stop at a red light, hitting Mrs Blackburn as she escorted a woman and child across the road while on duty. He claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot remember if the lights were red or green. Mrs Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court, saying he has thought of nothing else since the incident. The sun was approximately 10 minutes from setting at the time.

This passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose" involving 10 warships, including USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, hunting for German U-boat U33. The exercise is a response to increased Russian submarine activity near Sweden, Finland, and the UK. Russia has invested heavily in a fleet of approximately 60 technologically advanced submarines, described as the "quietest and most challenging adversary in the world," while European nations have cut defense spending. The exercise employs warships, helicopters, and for the first time, underwater drones to locate submarines. Significantly, the exercise exposes a critical gap in British defenses: the UK lacks maritime patrol aircraft previously provided by Nimrod, forcing reliance on NATO allies when Russian submarines appear near British waters. This vulnerability means Russian submarines could potentially track Britain's nuclear deterrent leaving Faslane naval base undetected. Experts warn Britain is seen as a "soft touch" and should address this deficiency in its upcoming defense review.

Since July, 340,000 South Sudanese have fled to Uganda, exceeding Syria's 2016 refugee numbers, with an average of 2,500 arriving daily. The violence, which began as a civil war between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, spread to previously peaceful southern Equatoria states. UN officials warn of potential genocide and ethnic cleansing, as refugees report killings, rape, and ethnic targeting of civilians, particularly Equatorians and Nuer by Dinka forces. Refugees describe fleeing through the bush from Yei and other areas, witnessing murders and sexual violence. Uganda has responded by allocating land and resources to refugees within 36 hours of arrival, transforming Bidi Bidi village into one of the world's largest refugee settlements with over 250,000 people. However, Uganda, now hosting nearly a million refugees, is struggling with water supply and other resources. Approximately half the refugees are children, with many orphaned by the violence.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. The former Norwich and Peterborough footballer turned professional boxer in 2013, two years after leaving football, and has a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition government has allocated funding as part of a £330m investment for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital in England, costing £33m in total with the remainder funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new facility will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, has become cramped, outdated, and requires constant maintenance with poor temperature control. Three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have already been replaced in the past five years. The new hospital is planned for land at Bowers Lane, subject to planning permission, with completion targeted for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre at approximately 13:35 GMT. The victim, who was in or near a black Mercedes he had been driving, was transported to Northern General Hospital where he died from his injuries. Local residents reported he was a member of a family living nearby who were gathering for a celebration when the attack happened. Armed police sealed off the area. This incident follows several recent shootings in Sheffield, though previous ones occurred in the north of the city, including a serious shooting in Shiregreen on Monday, shots fired through an elderly couple's window in Southey Green earlier this month, and two separate shooting incidents in High Green in January.

The passage describes three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukraine conflict. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct pro-Ukrainian operations including hacking Russian government servers, launching DDoS attacks on rebel websites, disrupting separatist funding through payment systems, and hijacking CCTV cameras and printers. They claim independence from government but share intelligence with Ukrainian security services. Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western group supporting separatists that hacks Ukrainian government websites, claims to have obtained confidential US military assistance documents during Biden's Kiev visit, disrupted electronic billboards and voting systems, and leaked Ukrainian defense data. Anonymous International, also known as Shaltay Boltay, publishes leaked Kremlin documents of unclear origin, including materials about Russian fighters in Ukraine and communications from rebel commander Igor Girkin. All three groups present themselves as independent activists rather than government-sponsored entities.

The Scottish Parliament held valedictory speeches for departing MSPs ahead of the May 5th election. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional during addresses by Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, both standing down after years of service. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007-2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity rather than division and welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill, though he claimed it fell short of referendum campaign pledges. He concluded by calling service in parliament the greatest honor in public life, ending with "goodbye from me... for now." McNeil, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must improve accountability and scrutiny, suggesting it should learn from Westminster's committee system. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also delivered a farewell speech.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is launching a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their friends and families to share their experiences, which will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner has observed both high quality care and unacceptable variations in care across Wales, having received increasing correspondence about care quality in the past year. The review will examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships and care home environments, with input from residents, care providers, social care staff and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but has expressed disappointment that no provider expert with direct care home experience is included on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company manufacturing and supplying animal feeds for various livestock sectors, reported pre-tax profit of £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, an increase of £800,000 despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew in Europe and new markets. The Turriff-based firm operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland serving farming and rural communities. The company acknowledged challenging conditions over the previous 12-18 months and uncertainty around Brexit's impact, but expressed confidence in being well positioned for future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, and another man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and urgently seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the offense, warning the public not to approach him. McLoughlin is described as white, approximately 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair and average build, believed to be wearing sunglasses, jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt. Police are conducting additional patrols in the area and asking anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers.

The IMF's David Lipton stated that the global economy shows a weakening baseline and is at a delicate juncture, speaking to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington on Tuesday. His comments followed China's weaker-than-expected trade figures showing exports dropped by a quarter year-over-year. The IMF indicated it will likely downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in its April release. This situation has ongoing implications for businesses and industries that relied on China's growth.

The council leader announced free ferry crossings at Cowes until 2 July following problems with a new chain ferry vessel, and ordered an audit review of the project. Since its late launch on 14 May, the ferry has experienced multiple breakdowns, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency for training issues, and damaged vehicles during boarding. A local shopkeeper requested business compensation, citing nearly six months of lost trade. The transport councillor stated compensation is under discussion, defended the vessel as a prototype with expected teething problems, and said issues including electrical faults, vehicle scraping, and groundings have been or are being addressed through repairs, ramp extensions, and improved seamanship.

A 32-year-old man died in a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London temp agency for "beautiful and talented people," advertised for a personal assistant specifying physical attributes including "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup." The Equality and Human Rights Commission condemned this as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and said it would write to the agency about its hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners called the ads "straight out of the 1970s." Employment lawyers stated the adverts were clearly unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on protected characteristics, and noted that rejected applicants could sue for unlimited compensation. The agency's founder defended the practice, saying clients' preferences are important and citing specific client requests, including an "older gentleman" wanting someone to fit a Christian Dior outfit. The EHRC urged the company to modernize its practices and end such sexism.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, a school office assistant, allegedly shot two students. He shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head with a pistol and injured another student, Sirisha, who survived. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. The motive for the shooting is unclear. Gun crime at Indian schools and colleges is very rare, despite strict gun control laws in the country.

The advocacy group Glaad analyzed television shows from June 2016 to May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters increasing from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington in Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth.
