The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, appearing in shows like Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president acknowledged progress but stated that numbers alone don't tell the complete story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his deselection was expected. This follows controversy over a £10.25m loan from Northampton Borough Council to Northampton Town FC that has gone missing. The loan, approved when Mackintosh was council leader, was intended to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, but the stand remains half-built. The missing funds are subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. Mackintosh has denied wrongdoing but acknowledged it was time for constituents to have a new representative. A majority of his local party executive had indicated they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was indicted for murder after firing a rifle into a car of teenagers leaving a party in Balch Springs, Texas in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. He was also charged with four counts of aggravated assault for endangering the other four teenagers in the vehicle. Oliver was fired days after the incident for policy violations. Police initially claimed the car reversed aggressively toward the officer, but video footage showed it driving forward away from him. Officers had responded to reports of underage drinking and heard what they thought were gunshots outside. Oliver faces 5 to 99 years in prison and would be the first officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973 if found guilty. He is currently free on bail with no trial date set.

Melania Trump plans to delay moving to the White House with 10-year-old son Barron until after he finishes the school year, drawing both criticism and support on social media. Only two previous First Ladies have not lived in the White House: Martha Washington before it was built, and Anna Harrison whose husband died before she could move in. However, historians note that delayed moves for school-age children are not unusual, citing examples like Grover Cleveland's wife who spent most time at a separate residence, and John Tyler's children who didn't move immediately. Recent presidential children like Chelsea Clinton and the Obama daughters moved in on inauguration day, with the Obamas relocating early to avoid mid-term school changes. The First Lady's role is ceremonial as White House hostess, though modern First Ladies have championed causes like Michelle Obama's Let Girls Learn initiative. Melania Trump has indicated Barron will be her priority and has expressed interest in tackling cyber-bullying. While presidential daughters have occasionally assumed First Lady duties when presidents were widowers, Ivanka Trump could potentially take on some responsibilities. Previous presidential families have successfully balanced official duties with normal family life, with both the Clintons and Obamas maintaining regular family dinners and protecting their children's privacy.

A 72-year-old man died at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service to investigate the initial police response to a call from the man before his death. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report will be submitted to COPFS upon completion.

A yellow wind warning has been issued for seven Welsh counties (Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys), with gusts up to 75mph expected, particularly west of mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction may increase impact, with travel disruption likely on roads and at sea. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall on Telford Road in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing the main route for most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants and Panthers played a hockey match with the Giants taking an early lead through Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal for a 2-1 lead, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais extended the lead to 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling scored. The teams will play again on Saturday in the second match of their double-header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the grid at the Chinese Grand Prix, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, made five pit stops, and finished behind championship leader Nico Rosberg, who won the race. Hamilton now trails Rosberg by 36 points with 18 races remaining. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth. The collision occurred when Raikkonen moved into Vettel's path as Vettel avoided Daniil Kvyat's aggressive overtaking move. Hamilton was also hit by Felipe Nasr while avoiding Raikkonen's damaged car. Daniel Ricciardo initially took the lead from pole-sitter Rosberg but suffered a puncture on lap three. The chaotic opening laps led to a safety car period on lap four. Hamilton's car sustained aerodynamic and suspension damage that hindered his recovery drive. No driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to win the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, stating he wanted to advance discussion of a topic "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement received widespread support from former teammates, football administrators, and public figures. Former German FA president Theo Zwanziger praised his courage, while Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball called it a huge step in fighting homophobia. The announcement is viewed as a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football remains problematic. Current Germany captain Philipp Lahm had previously discouraged gay footballers from coming out, citing safety concerns. The last German footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality was Marcus Urban in 2007. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck both praised Hitzlsperger's decision, expressing hope it would encourage others and break down taboos surrounding homosexuality in football.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season helping Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at the end of the campaign, he wants to sign a new deal and be part of the team next season. Brighton confirmed promotion with a recent win over Wigan and lead second-placed Newcastle by four points as they pursue the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell initially joined Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016. He has previously played in the Premier League for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke. Sidwell believes he has exceeded expectations by playing more games than anticipated and performing well, earning himself the opportunity for a new contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso's chip found Jamille Matt, who scored from three yards. Colchester equalized after 17 minutes through Kurtis Guthrie following a corner and goalmouth scramble. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made crucial saves, denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie hit the bar before half-time. Tom Aldred missed a chance to win it for Blackpool, heading wide from eight yards with 15 minutes remaining. Colchester's Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The 29-year-old Reid made 37 appearances for Coventry City last season during their relegation from League One. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid could debut for Colchester United in their EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss at Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer's murder outside the Houses of Parliament in March increased emphasis on creating a permanent memorial for fallen police officers. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for £1.5m towards constructing the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The memorial will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died over the past 250 years. It will feature a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts given to families of fallen officers bearing their loved ones' names. The government committed £1m towards the total £4m cost, with completion expected by 2019.

Manchester United extended their Premier League lead to 15 points with a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, having won 25 of their first 30 matches. Manager Ferguson stated the team is focused only on upcoming games, particularly the Manchester derby where they hold a 15-point advantage over City. The team has won 50 of 54 possible points in their last 18 league games and has eight matches remaining to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record from 2005. Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea sustained injuries during the match. Ferguson plans squad changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, with Giggs and Hernandez available, while Rooney's participation depends on his recovery from international duty fatigue. Ferguson praised United's first-half performance and credited Sunderland's second-half effort, highlighting his team's determined defending.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Chairman Eric Schmidt defended this, stating the company did what was legally required and that taxes are not optional - companies must pay what the law demands. He said if the UK changes its tax laws, Google will comply accordingly. Google routes most UK sales through Ireland. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggested establishing a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements with the ability to hear confidential evidence. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt has previously argued corporate taxes should be levied where companies conduct economic activity rather than where products are consumed, and called for politicians to set clearer tax rules with companies following them.

The NHS spent £3.6bn on agency staff last year, and regulator NHS Improvement aims to reduce this by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October limits payments to 55% above normal shift rates for most staff and has saved £600m so far. However, NHS trusts are 10% behind target. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of trust performance and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff, as some hospitals are being quoted double the capped rates. Examples include surgeons quoted at £130 per hour versus a £76 cap, and junior doctors at £70 versus £35. The regulator states more progress is needed as the NHS cannot afford expensive agency staff costs.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's Celtic Tiger economy, now represents its economic crash. Local traders report business is slowly improving after years of decline, with Matt O'Brien's clothing shop seeing increases after being 30% down during the recession. Opposition party Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, noting the Industrial Development Authority hasn't brought potential clients to Longford in over four years. The government points to Center Parcs' planned tourism development in Ballymahon, expected to employ 1,000 people when opening in 2019, though planning permission is still needed. Local traders believe additional measures like free parking would help boost business. The region is beginning to see economic recovery, but consensus is that more needs to be done.

The passage describes a cricket tournament ending on 29 May, featuring eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to play-offs. Current statistics show Warner leading run-scorers with 294, followed by Kohli (267) and De Villiers (249). Warner and De Villiers share the lead for most sixes with 12 each. De Kock holds the highest individual score of 108. McClenaghan leads wicket-takers with 9. Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The passage includes a complete fixture list from 25 April through the final on 29 May, with matches typically scheduled at 15:30 BST. BBC Sport provides coverage of scores, fixtures and results.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. These bags cannot be recycled and are often discarded after single use, ending up in rubbish dumps and rivers, causing environmental problems. From October, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags to encourage reuse, following Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland where similar charges have reduced bag usage. Campaigners hope this will decrease waste and help the environment.

Strong winds across Wales on Friday caused significant disruption, including part of a school roof being torn off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon and power cuts affecting hundreds of homes. A yellow wind warning was in force until midnight. The severe weather led to Irish Ferries cancelling six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, train delays and speed restrictions on Arriva Trains Wales services, and temporary closures of Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Speed and lane restrictions were imposed on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge before being lifted as winds eased in the evening. The highest wind gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey. The disruption coincided with one of the busiest travel days as the Christmas getaway began. Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to 27 December due to the continuing blustery forecast.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about joining Black Panther, reuniting with Creed director Ryan Coogler. He did not reveal his specific role but mentioned wanting to put a different spin on it. The film will also star Lupita Nyong'o, who won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, who currently plays Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously appeared in Fantastic Four, while Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875, is being restored as part of a £26.6m east wing renovation project to transform the venue into a cultural destination. The theatre and BBC studios will be repaired for performances, cinema, comedy and live music, with a planned 2018 reopening. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m and Haringey Council £6.8m, while Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust must raise the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades, retains its original decor and stage machinery and historically hosted opera, musicals, plays and early cinema screenings. The glazed east court will become a public exhibition space.

James Milner, 30, a former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his 2009 debut. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances from 2004, and scored one international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifying. He cited common sense as the reason for his decision and wished the team future success under Sam Allardyce.

Marcy Smith and her family's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador was destroyed by fire after rubbish burned in their wood stove ignited the blaze. Her son David, who was awake on FaceTime with his father, spotted the flames and woke the family, enabling them to escape. The fire spread rapidly, engulfing the kitchen within seconds while they were still in it. The fire alarm failed to activate. The family's dog and cats perished in the fire, and they escaped with only their pyjamas. Mrs Smith credits David with saving her and her daughter's lives, though he doesn't yet fully comprehend his heroic actions. The community has supported the family by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike.

West Ham United's co-owners Sullivan and Gold, who purchased a majority stake in 2010 valuing the club at £105m and now own over 85%, were subject to a potential £200m takeover bid from energy drinks giant Red Bull. Since relocating to London Stadium in August, the club has attracted interest from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan previously indicated a minority stake might be sold to clear debts, though he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards ceremony featured fan-voted categories including best kiss and best shirtless performance. The Fault in Our Stars was the biggest winner, taking best movie, with star Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance in American Sniper, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep for best villain in Into the Woods. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award, while Robert Downey Jr was presented the Generation Award by his Avengers co-stars. The ceremony also served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters including Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron.

The Dons loaned 21-year-old Smith to Dundee United in July, where he has scored five goals this season. The Scotland Under-21 player made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has four goals in 89 appearances for them. St Mirren manager Jack Ross has now acquired Smith, calling him a really good player he didn't expect to get while Smith was at Dundee United. Ross says Smith is a mature player who provides another attacking option for Championship bottom side St Mirren, who face Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes now that weather conditions permit. The council plans to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additional staff will repair rain-damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to alpha radiation while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland. The workers were removing pipework when exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) without proper protective equipment, allegedly because the equipment was assumed to be clear. They claim they were informed of the problem two-thirds through their work after readings were taken. The workers now face cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests. Innes alleges EnQuest failed in its duty of care and says he has struggled to find work since raising concerns. EnQuest confirmed the incident involved exposure below 1% of HSE reportable levels, stated they have appropriate control measures, and have taken additional precautionary steps following an investigation. Wood Group said they downmanned employees for medical assessments and prioritized worker health. Unite union criticized the workers' treatment and called for transparency. HSE confirmed awareness but conducted no investigation as the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum in Singapore purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this bronze, during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, southern India. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India, and after receiving an official return request in May, the museum agreed to return the sculpture. While acknowledging no conclusive proof of theft exists, the museum cited the confession of Aaron Freedman, Art of the Past's manager, regarding dealing in looted Indian antiquities and criminal possession of 150 stolen objects. The sculpture was one of 30 objects the museum purchased from the dealer, though the others are not believed to be stolen. The museum plans to pursue legal action for compensation.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt across multiple cities including Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, though phone lines went down and power was cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. Several aftershocks followed. Italy experiences frequent earthquakes; in 2009, nearly 300 people died in L'Aquila, and in May of the previous year, two earthquakes killed over 20 people. Following the L'Aquila disaster, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of manslaughter in 2012 for providing misleading information about earthquake risks before the deadly 2009 tremor.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, successfully grew fruit on a plant despite doubts about South Yorkshire's climate suitability. The fruit, still attached to the plant on 8 September 2016, was not yet ripe enough to eat, but the achievement delighted him greatly.

Rockstar has delayed the PC release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March, citing the need for additional testing and polish. The company stated the delay serves the game's and fans' best interests. Online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch. The PC version will feature enhanced detail, supporting 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specifications have been published. GTA V became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever when originally released on 17 September 2013, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days.

The 76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. He was previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times. The approximately 7ft painting depicts a leper squint - holes in medieval church walls that allowed undesirables to view services. Judge Ansel Krut described it as "quite extraordinary" and technically subtle, comparing it to a tone poem that builds gradually. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art materials including stretches, canvas, and quality paints. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked almost simultaneously early Thursday by masked assailants. Four attackers targeted the Yeni Safak building, causing a fire that firefighters extinguished, while the Yeni Akit offices, located 20km away, were also struck. Both buildings sustained shattered windows from gunfire, and numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. No casualties were reported. Police have cordoned off the area and are searching for the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility. Both newspapers support President Erdogan's governing AK Party.

A 24-year-old player has been signed by the Mariners on a free transfer from the Stags, where he was under contract. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. The ex-Burton player will officially join on 1 January and is Marcus Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsene Wenger, whose Arsenal contract expires in the summer, has been linked with the England manager position currently held by interim boss Gareth Southgate. The 66-year-old Frenchman praised Southgate's experience and competency, stating he deserves the opportunity to prove himself through upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain. Wenger said he remains focused on his Arsenal role. Additionally, Wenger confirmed Arsenal will offer defender Hector Bellerin a new contract despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, expressing surprise at transfer speculation surrounding the 21-year-old. Midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the inquiry.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union claimed some workers on the Hellier and Hildasay vessels were paid less than £4 an hour. These ships were operated by Seatruck, contracted by Serco Northlink, which argued minimum wage laws didn't apply to the crew, many of whom were non-UK residents. Under the new arrangement taking effect next month, the contracted services will return to Serco Northlink, ensuring all crew members receive at least minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds a six-year £243m contract awarded in 2012 to operate three ferries and two cargo boats on the heavily subsidised Scottish government route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park holiday site in Poole on 7 May. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, who had been in a relationship with Mr Dickie for several years. After drinking at the park bar, Mitchell and Mr Dickie had a confrontation outside. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault related to the fight. He and his mother Samantha Mitchell, 57, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about the events, before Mitchell later stated he had tried to push the couple apart, causing what he called a "tragic accident". A jury at Winchester Crown Court delivered a verdict, and both will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter, died in London at age 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Born in Cleethorpes, he worked in a frozen food factory before joining disco group Heatwave in the 1970s, writing hits like Boogie Nights and Always & Forever. Producer Quincy Jones recruited him to write for Michael Jackson, resulting in three songs for Off The Wall including Rock With You, and three for Thriller including the title track. Thriller became the best-selling album in US history with 32 million copies sold. Temperton won a Grammy in 1990 for Birdland and received two Oscar nominations in 1986 for The Color Purple soundtrack. Known as The Invisible Man for his low profile, he also wrote for artists including Aretha Franklin, Donna Summer, and Anita Baker. Musicians including Nile Rodgers, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan paid tribute to his work.

Researchers from Swansea, Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities discovered over 450 large geometrical earthworks called "geoglyphs" in Brazil's Acre state, possibly 2,000 years old, previously hidden by rainforest until modern deforestation. These ditched enclosures are unlikely to be villages or defensive structures due to few artifacts and their layout; instead they may have been ritual gathering places used sporadically. Analysis of soil samples, including phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes, revealed the geoglyphs were built among tall vegetation, making them invisible above the forest canopy unlike other ritual sites. The research challenges assumptions that pre-16th Century Amazonian forests were pristine, showing humans transformed the environment over 6,000 years by cultivating economically valuable trees like palms rather than burning large forest areas, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful products. Evidence suggests this ancient agroforestry may still influence the region's biodiversity today.

The 21-year-old Australian tennis player Kyrgios defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes at the Shanghai Masters, advancing to the second round. Currently ranked 12th in the world after winning the Japan Open on Sunday, Kyrgios explained his subdued demeanor during the match was due to fatigue from recent travel and competition. He cited poor sleep, late arrival, and the hour-long commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium as contributing factors. Last year at the same tournament, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a profanity-laced outburst in which he called the event a "circus".

Scientists and charities are calling on the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination programme to boys aged 12 and 13 to protect them from head and neck cancers. Currently, only girls in this age group receive the vaccine to prevent cervical cancer. Charities including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are delivering a letter urging the rollout. Medical professionals report increasing cases of head and neck cancer, particularly among younger men around age 55 who are mostly non-smokers, with three-quarters of those affected being male. HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden. Since 2008, 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil, died from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare form of blood cancer. Diagnosed in August, he documented his treatment journey on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey" with his family, attracting over 28,000 Likes. The Rangers FC fan maintained a positive attitude throughout, meeting former and current players and receiving visits from various sports teams and performers during hospital stays in Edinburgh and Glasgow. On January 23rd, doctors informed the family that cancer had spread throughout his body and ceased treatment. Despite this, Jak attended his school prom for 10 minutes on Saturday, where he received his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. His mother Allison announced his death on Facebook. The family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with a charity football match planned at Livingston FC.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in their Africa Cup of Nations Group D match, with Abdallah El Said scoring in the 89th minute after being set up by Mohamed Salah. The game was largely uneventful on a deteriorating Port-Gentil pitch, with Uganda's Joseph Ochaya having a goal disallowed for offside. Uganda goalkeeper Denis Onyango made several saves before El Said's late winner. The victory means Egypt will face Ghana on Wednesday with top spot in the group still to be decided, while Uganda are eliminated from their first tournament since 1978. Ghana had already secured their quarter-final place with a 1-0 win over Mali earlier that day. Uganda will play Mali in their final group match, with Mali needing a win and a favorable Egypt-Ghana result to qualify.

Lancashire County Council has selected land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station. Both sites are currently unused, with the sports college having closed in August and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus no longer in use. The decision followed a Network Rail comparative study of these sites and one near the Concourse shopping centre. Skelmersdale's original station closed in 1956, and the town, designated as a new town in 1961, is one of the largest in northwest England without a railway station. The plans, developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, aim to provide two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land, with the chosen location offering sufficient space for future expansion and good transport connectivity.
Police discovered cannabis plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, later turned himself in to authorities and is now in custody. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

A study of 4,600 workers by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women ask for pay rises as often as men but are less likely to receive them. When comparing like-for-like workers (full-time with full-time, part-time with part-time), men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The research found no evidence supporting the theory that women are reluctant to ask due to fear of upsetting bosses or deviating from female stereotypes. The study used 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey data, with researchers accounting for employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. However, workers under 40 showed equal rates of asking for and receiving pay rises regardless of gender, suggesting negotiating behavior may be changing among younger generations.

Oxford City Council has spent £54,000 searching for a new cemetery site but has been unable to find suitable land. The city's two remaining cemeteries, in Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021 respectively. Ground investigations of potential council-owned sites have ruled them out due to issues including size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. Once current cemeteries are full, only family plot reopenings, reserved plots, and ash interments will be possible. Oxford has not added burial space since 1932, and the council continues exploring options despite the land shortage.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer visitors an augmented reality app that triggers online content like videos and band interviews from signs and posters on site. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. The app will allow both festival-goers and people worldwide to access information, interviews, and purchase tickets, with content updated before and during the event.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across all equestrian disciplines. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, causing overheating and wobbling, but displayed no such symptoms on Saturday and had never collapsed before. The horse had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Despite questions about whether his previous overheating condition was linked to his death, the report concluded he died from a rare haemorrhage. Trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the "horse of a lifetime."

A person named David Ayrton, now 34 and called Davina, was convicted of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004. The defendant, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, denied the charge but will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded the defendant into custody at a male prison in Winchester, citing risks of self-harm and failure to attend. The victim testified she shouted at Ayrton to stop the attack while two friends slept nearby, and she clearly remembered the events despite drinking alcohol. Ayrton changed her name in 2012 and has not made physical changes to her body or taken medication. In 2014, Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

The Serbs, including world number one Djokovic, lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This followed Djokovic's singles elimination by Juan Martin del Potro. The 29-year-old, 12-time Grand Slam winner had previously suffered a surprise third-round Wimbledon defeat to Sam Querrey in July, but rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US are participating in a chainsaw carving competition on Saturday in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms. Participants must use only chainsaws to carve logs into shapes of animals and people, with all other carving tools banned. Last year's winner Pete Bowsher from Moffat is returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, 27, has not played since suffering a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He is now back running and progressing through a pre-season stage, aiming to return in late January or early February ahead of Wales' Six Nations opener against Ireland on 7 February. The 16-times capped Wales international has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region where he debuted in 2007.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks containing 58lb of ecstasy five miles east of Sumas, Washington. One man fired at agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately arrested. The fugitive, Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was captured in British Columbia on Wednesday after a search involving Canadian and US police. Authorities also arrested Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who was to be paid $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco. The three US defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service counselled more than 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year, up from about 2,400 in 2011-12, with some victims as young as seven. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, warned that cyber-bullying follows children home and becomes inescapable persecution. She emphasized that bullying worsens without intervention and called on parents, teachers, and schools to take the problem seriously and protect children. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which works with parents, schools, and organizations to combat bullying. One young person described being told to kill themselves by an online gaming group, expressing how upsetting it was and how their parents didn't understand the difficulty of the situation.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, angering Prime Minister Netanyahu who accused Washington of helping draft the resolution. Israel responded by summoning ambassadors, recalling envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, and cutting aid to Senegal. The resolution declared settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem illegal under international law and obstacles to peace. A planned vote on 492 new settlement homes in Jerusalem was postponed at Netanyahu's request to avoid further tensions before US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Over 500,000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since 1967. Palestinians view the resolution as supporting the two-state solution, with East Jerusalem as their future capital.

Prince William paid tribute to the Queen ahead of her 90th birthday in a BBC interview, describing her as a "guiding example" of good monarchy. The Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens as part of birthday celebrations. A commemorative stamp featuring four generations of royals - the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince George - was released. William addressed criticism of being "work-shy," stating he takes duty seriously but believes in developing into the role at the right time, with support from his father and grandmother. On her actual birthday, the Queen will walk around Windsor, unveil a plaque for The Queen's Walkway marking her record-breaking reign, and light a beacon triggering over 900 beacons worldwide. President Obama will join her for lunch on Friday. The Queen celebrates two birthdays annually - her actual birthday on 21 April and an official birthday in June.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup third round. Diafra Sakho scored his first goal since November from Sam Byram's pass, followed quickly by Andre Ayew's goal in the same corner, giving West Ham control before half-time. Cheltenham had chances through Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but failed to test West Ham goalkeeper Adrian sufficiently. West Ham made seven changes following recent Premier League defeats and could have won by more, with Kyle Storer clearing Angelo Ogbonna's header off the line and goalkeeper Jonathan Flatt stopping Sakho. The result eliminated League Two's last representative from the competition before the next round's draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to see the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner, a father-of-four staying near Bala with his family, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family accepted it was a momentary lapse and saw no value in Werner being jailed. Werner was remorseful and could not explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, left the UK in January to fight in Syria with Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated to Islamic State. Using the name Abu Daigham al-Britani, he posted videos and images online, including a gruesome picture holding a bag containing a head. The group produced slick propaganda appealing to young British Muslims. In June, Khawaja faked his own death online and attempted to sneak back into the UK with help from his cousin Tahir Bhatti, a taxi driver from Watford who drove to Bulgaria to collect him. Police arrested both men at Dover. Police describe Khawaja as one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from conflict, noting his exact activities and reasons for returning remain unknown. He was held in Belmarsh prison's high-risk terrorism unit and has admitted four offences including preparing terrorist acts and attending a terrorist training camp, facing possible life imprisonment. Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, who finished eighth. He has signed for Barnsley as their third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday, after turning down a contract offer from Wrexham. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and attacking ability, saying he will suit their style of play.

Sealed bottles of Vanish detergent have been washing up on beaches around the Lizard in Cornwall since Sunday, with National Trust volunteers clearing them due to wildlife risks. Though some bottles have leaked, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there is only circumstantial evidence linking them to a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean near Land's End in May. Multiple coves have been affected, and Cornwall Wildlife Trust has expressed concern about impacts on marine life. Authorities are monitoring the beaches, and the public is advised to keep children and dogs away from any bottles and not attempt to recover them.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 14:00, resulting in several people receiving minor injuries. The road was closed with diversions implemented via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland confirmed that inquiries into the incident are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers after making 14 appearances last season and helping the team finish second in League One to secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances total. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his excellent contribution late in the campaign. Dervite joins David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in signing new deals following promotion.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour clashed over Brexit strategy in the House of Lords, with Lib Dems accusing Labour of conceding everything while Labour claimed Lib Dems were giving false hope. The parties had previously cooperated to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for Brexit deals, but this alliance collapsed when MPs rejected those amendments. Labour chose to defer to the Commons while Lib Dems insisted on maintaining their position. Labour sources accused the Lib Dems of grandstanding for campaign purposes, while Lib Dems criticized Labour for supporting a hard Brexit. Despite their history of successful collaboration on other issues including higher education and housing, the dispute has created tensions that may affect future cooperation between the opposition parties.

Defence ranks low among voter priorities in this election, with parties providing minimal detail in their manifestos. Despite agreement that the world is becoming more dangerous, UK armed forces face significant cuts - the regular Army reduced from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy down to 19 warships, and capability gaps like no Maritime Patrol Aircraft. The UK has dropped from fourth to sixth place globally in defence spending. Most major parties avoid committing to NATO's 2% GDP spending target, with projections suggesting UK spending could fall to 1.5-1.7% by decade's end - requiring an additional £25bn over five years to maintain 2%. Further cuts of £2bn-£3bn annually appear likely, though Conservative commitments on Trident, equipment budgets, and army size may limit options. Trident renewal remains contentious, with parties divided on replacing four submarines or maintaining continuous patrols, potentially consuming a quarter of equipment spending. The two new aircraft carriers face manning shortages and reduced F-35 complement (12 instead of 36 aircraft), raising concerns about a "hollow force" that undermines Britain's claim to punch above its weight militarily.

Barcelona paid an additional £10m in tax to Spanish authorities related to Neymar's transfer from Santos, though the club insists no offence was committed. The payment aims to cover potential interpretations of contracts in the signing. Barcelona originally stated they paid £48.6m for the 22-year-old striker, with £34m going to his parents, but the total cost including fees, wages, and tax payments has reached £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating money in the deal, and a Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax-related crime but made the payment to protect its reputation, maintaining the original tax payment was adequate. It remains unclear if the case will be dropped following the payment.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died when the van he was traveling in was hit by a car driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, on the southbound carriageway. Luciw's family and the van driver, Andy Harrington, who survived with serious injuries, are calling for mandatory driving tests for retired people, arguing that older drivers' reactions slow down. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must complete a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but no medical or driving test is required. The DVLA states evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents and has no plans to restrict licensing based on age. Age UK emphasizes the importance of older people maintaining their driving independence for as long as safely possible.

An independent expert will examine the process behind a review of transvaginal mesh implants after two patients quit the review group in protest, claiming the report was watered-down. Professor Alison Britton will investigate how the review reached its conclusions and identify lessons for the future. The original report recommended that mesh procedures not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, that patients receive information for informed choices, and that adverse event reporting be mandatory. Despite campaigner calls for a ban, the health secretary confirmed recommendations would be implemented but stated the Scottish government lacks power to ban the procedures, as this falls under UK regulatory authority. The review's chairwoman apologized for failing to unite panel members, describing her task as "almost mission impossible." Over 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh implants in the past 20 years, with more than 400 currently taking legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds at Glasgow's Emirates Arena, recording 14 minutes 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned whether the record met UK Athletics criteria, noting Muir was the only athlete completing 5K in a mixed 3K race and querying drug testing requirements. British Athletics confirmed the time would be ratified as official, stating no drug tests are required when doping control is absent at the event. McColgan praised Muir as world class with potential to run 14.30 and win world medals, though she needs improved race tactics. McColgan noted similarities to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago, where she also ran alone and lapped competitors including Paula Radcliffe. Muir previously broke the British 1500m record and reached the Olympic 1500m final at Rio 2016.

Michael Jung won gold in equestrian eventing aboard Sam, a late replacement horse. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after leading following the dressage phase but dropping to 21st after time penalties in the cross-country phase, which ended his medal hopes despite a faultless show-jumping performance. Fox-Pitt was competing 10 months after being in an induced coma from a fall. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray, 30, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes to reach the Wimbledon fourth round for the 11th time. After taking the first and third sets, Murray faced five set points while trailing 5-2 in the fourth set as light faded on Centre Court, but won five consecutive games to secure victory and avoid playing a fifth set under the roof or returning Saturday. Fognini received a point penalty for a visible obscenity during the tense match. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the next round on Monday, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police found people still present and till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, and James Thomas faced one count of the same charge. A defence solicitor acknowledged licensing laws were not strictly followed and the premises operated improperly into the morning. The judge noted O'Neill had an appalling record and expressed concern about lacking power to impose a custodial sentence, calling it one of the worst cases encountered. The court ordered the bar's closure for three months, fined O'Neill £3,000, and fined Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionist Party manifesto, stated he would transfer votes to the SDLP over Sinn Féin, sparking controversy and public distancing from senior colleague Danny Kennedy. Nesbitt defended his comments, expressing no regrets and saying he received support while canvassing. The Ulster Unionists want the election to focus on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, which costs £85,000 daily, and criticize 10 years of DUP-Sinn Féin governance. Their manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', includes commitments on healthcare waiting lists, increasing police numbers to 7,500, the York Street interchange, LGBT rights, and Brexit protections. The party frames the election as a referendum on "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption" at Stormont.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the Northern Ireland assembly to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, bringing Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales. The proposals, dubbed 'Turing's Law' after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing, will provide posthumous pardons and allow living gay and bisexual men convicted of such offences to apply for pardons. Sugden secured executive agreement for the legislative consent motion and stated arrangements would be implemented as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment with England and Wales, describing it as an opportunity to right past wrongs.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, broke the Scottish 1500m record with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second behind Kenya's Faith Kipyegon. This surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who finished fifth in last year's World Championships, now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She recently won an 800m race in France and will compete in Stockholm before attempting to qualify for the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham in June. Muir balances her athletic career with veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
I am unable to summarize this text.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC told an inquiry that the Russian state was likely behind the 2006 murder of Alexander Litvinenko, though this did not necessarily implicate President Putin directly. Litvinenko, 43, died nearly three weeks after drinking tea laced with polonium-210 during a meeting with suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi in London. Horwell stated the suspects had no personal motive and left a "trail of polonium" behind, but they deny wrongdoing and remain in Russia after extradition attempts failed. Possible motives included Litvinenko's 2000 defection to the UK after accusing the FSB of corruption and murder, and his personal attacks on Putin. Horwell noted the long-term radiation risk to Londoners remains unknown and that Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death.

Smith, 26, has been appointed as Australia's Test captain on an ongoing basis, replacing the retired Michael Clarke. He already captains the one-day side and will also lead the Twenty20 team while Aaron Finch is injured. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues. Smith previously captained Australia in three Tests against India when Clarke was injured, and has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith as the right successor to Clarke, while noting Warner has matured into an important senior figure. Both will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval starting 20 August.

Tim Farron, who recently became leader after defeating Norman Lamb, refused to directly answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin when asked three times on Channel 4 News, instead stating "we are all sinners". On the BBC's Andrew Marr Show, he declared himself "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and said defending equal marriage would be a top priority. He explained his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill was due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties" after a Liberal Democrat amendment was defeated. Farron stated he supports extending marital rights for transgender people, specifically addressing the spousal veto issue that currently prevents equal access to marriage for those who have changed gender.

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now use the plant for pharmaceutical production, with hopes that many positions will be filled by former Sanofi employees. Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes welcomed the announcement as positive for the local economy and the region's science and healthcare sector reputation. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority is losing three senior staff members: Richard Ellis (former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive) is leaving Friday as his contract ends, while Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive's office) and Ewan Sutherland (head of human resources and customer services) are departing through voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn criticized the departures as evidence of the council's failure to retain senior staff and predicted more exits ahead. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their service.

Militants attacked Sardar Daud hospital in Kabul, entering after detonating explosives at the gate and opening fire on staff and patients. Four attackers wearing white coats and carrying Kalashnikovs were killed by commandos after several hours of fighting. More than 50 people were wounded. Islamic State claimed responsibility while the Taliban denied involvement. This marks IS's first direct engagement with security forces in the capital, representing a tactical shift from their previous targeting of civilian gatherings. President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attack as violating human values. IS announced its presence in Afghanistan in 2015 and has conducted multiple attacks since, including a July 2016 rally bombing that killed 80 people and a Supreme Court attack last month killing 22.

The English rider Guy Martin crashed at this year's TT, and his Fireblade bike suffered mechanical problems. He initially told MCN he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he has no plans to do more road racing on Hondas this year. Martin didn't race at the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness crashed in practice and won't compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a disaster, saying he essentially became a test rider. After testing at Cadwell, he told the team the bike wouldn't be competitive at Ulster Grand Prix, and they withdrew him from the event without informing him. Martin stated he wants to race classics and oddball motorcycles instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in Saturday's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP lost key northern states including Katsina and Kaduna for the first time, as well as Adamawa, though it retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east. One result remains outstanding and one election was declared inconclusive. The APC's victory follows Muhammadu Buhari's presidential win last month, with his inauguration scheduled for 29 May. The elections experienced 66 violent incidents, higher than the presidential poll, mostly in Rivers and southern states. The APC also retained Lagos state, meaning the party of the president will control the commercial capital for the first time since 1999. The PDP's decline is attributed to defections to the APC, corruption allegations, and failure to adequately address the Boko Haram insurgency in the north-east.

US environmental group Mighty accuses agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned Temasek, of enabling unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to regional haze caused by slash-and-burn agriculture fires in Indonesia. Mighty claims Olam created a secretive market allowing purchases from unknown sources, though Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties and represents less than 1% of the global market. Olam's CEO denies the allegations, citing a zero-tolerance policy for burning and deforestation, though verification of suppliers will take years to complete. The company released names of its 14 suppliers after initially resisting. Mighty also accuses Olam of bulldozing rainforests for palm oil plantations in Gabon, which Olam defends as responsible development of a small percentage of forested land. Both Olam and Temasek reject the allegations. The palm oil industry, projected to be worth $88bn by 2022, faces ongoing criticism for environmental damage and labor practices, with disputes between green groups and industry executives over responsibility for third-party supplier practices.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters on 27 August 2016 following a new law that permitted dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they dined outdoors.

Sheffield Wednesday forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful with a knee injury, having been limited to substitute appearances in the last two matches. Derby County striker David Nugent may return from a groin injury that kept him out of Monday's draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is seeking a starting position after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute against Huddersfield.

Pakistan lifted its three-year ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed internet service providers to restore access, with the government stating Google provided a process for blocking objectionable content for Pakistani users. YouTube clarified that government removal requests would not be automatically granted and would follow their community guidelines and be recorded in their Transparency Report. The ban was imposed in 2012 after the film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded, which sparked deadly protests in Pakistan where more than a dozen people died. Some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms agreed between Google and the Pakistani government.

Liberian FA boss Musa Bility is threatening to take Fifa to the Court of Arbitration for Sport unless Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, withdraws by Thursday due to a conflict of interest. Bility argues that Scala, who is Swiss-Italian, shares nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino and should step aside as he did in the 2015 elections when Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter was running. Scala's spokesman counters that sharing nationality with a candidate does not constitute a conflict of interest under Fifa regulations, and that Scala withdrew in 2015 only as a voluntary precautionary measure because the Swiss candidate was the incumbent president. Five candidates are competing to replace Blatter as Fifa president in elections taking place in 18 days in Zurich, with Fifa's 209 members voting. Bility, who was denied participation in the election after failing an eligibility check, has pledged his support to Prince Ali.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. The company manufactures buckets for diggers. Evidence suggests a flashover explosion occurred, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, creating a fire-ball effect. Bodies were removed Tuesday afternoon, and forensic searches have been conducted. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf during the 2015 tournament, but avoided disqualification by apologizing. The dispute stemmed from Tunisia's quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, where they contested a controversial 90th-minute penalty that led to their 2-1 extra-time defeat. Tunisia wrote a letter criticizing the referee appointment but denies accusing anyone of corruption. Morocco was also banned from the 2017 tournament after refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced their fine from $1 million to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea replaced Morocco as hosts with only 64 days' preparation. Both nations have now resolved their issues with Caf and participated in the 2017 qualifying draw, with Tunisia drawn in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

The passage describes a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a match between Manchester City and Chelsea at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. Manchester City had two players sent off: Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct following a late challenge on David Luiz (his second such dismissal this season), and Fernandinho received a three-match ban after clashing with Cesc Fabregas in the subsequent scuffle. Both clubs have been charged and have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond. City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's involvement, while Chelsea's Fabregas will face no further action.

Mae Cymru a rhannau eraill o'r DU yn cael rhai o'r cyfraddau goresgyn canser gwaethaf yn y byd datblygedig. Mae cynllun peilot newydd yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd yn canolbwyntio ar gleifion y mae eu meddygon teulu yn amau sydd â chanser ond heb arwyddion neu symptomau brys. Ar hyn o bryd dim ond 35% o gleifion â symptomau sy'n "peri pryder" sy'n cael diagnosis yn ardal Cwm Taf. Bydd clinig tebyg yn cael ei sefydlu yn Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot. Os bydd y cynllun peilot chwe mis yn llwyddiannus, bydd gweddill byrddau iechyd yr ardal yn cynnig yr un gwasanaeth.

England defeated Pakistan by 330 runs at Old Trafford to level the series, winning with a day to spare. England declared on 589-8 and 173-1, while Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, also taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan batted for only 63 and 70 overs respectively on a pitch offering little assistance to bowlers. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged his team's poor shot selection and lack of confidence, with only he and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. The third Test begins at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with interim coach Rob Howley on his backroom team. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde for the summer tour, with announcements expected the following week. WRU officials believe the involvement of Welsh coaches with the Lions will benefit the national team, providing opportunities for coach development in different environments and mental stimulation from the challenging New Zealand tour.

Southampton took an early lead through Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida. Hull lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries, but substitute Robert Snodgrass transformed the match after coming on for Keane. Snodgrass scored Hull's equalizer in the 61st minute from Sam Clucas' cross, then delivered a free-kick that Michael Dawson headed in for the winner. Southampton pressed for an equalizer but Hull goalkeeper David Marshall made several saves and Clucas produced a crucial goalline clearance in stoppage time. The 2-1 victory was Hull's first league win since 20 August, ending a six-game losing streak, though they remain in the bottom three. Southampton had beaten Inter Milan in the Europa League on Thursday before this match.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at approximately 14:15 BST. The victim was a local resident whose identity has not been released. The tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses, and the B1191 was closed between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

Macedonia's President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings released in 2015, stating he wanted to end the crisis before June elections. The decision was condemned by both opposition and EU officials as undermining rule of law and jeopardizing Macedonia's EU membership prospects. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who has been releasing recordings since February 2015 allegedly showing government wiretapping of 20,000 people and revealing high-level corruption including vote-rigging and murder cover-ups, called the president's move illegal and organized protests in Skopje. The government denies the accusations and claims Zaev is attempting to destabilize the country.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. The club wants to quickly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as first choice. Curtis emphasizes the urgency of avoiding relegation, noting the Championship has become stronger and promotion is not guaranteed, unlike well-resourced clubs like Newcastle. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after nearly facing bankruptcy and Football League relegation in 2003, established themselves as a well-run club playing possession-based football. Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure due to constant managerial changes and inadequate player replacements, diluting the "Swansea Way" established under Martinez, Rodgers, and Laudrup. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad can survive relegation and ensures foreign players understand the club's history and the importance of staying up for the entire area.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet's winner sealed their fate after Orient had taken a 2-0 lead through Jay Simpson. The Daggers, who first reached the Football League in 2007 and League One in 2010, return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously guided them up through the divisions. The club struggled this season with League Two's worst goal difference, conceding 20 more goals than the previous year and scoring fewer, with Cureton netting only nine compared to 20 in 2014-15. Still, in his third spell at the club since December, has committed to seeking promotion next season. The victory keeps Orient's play-off hopes alive, leaving them two points from the play-off spots, four days after Kevin Nolan was removed as player-manager.

Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp has welcomed Steven Gerrard's appointment as a youth coach at the club, starting in February. The 36-year-old former Liverpool captain, who retired in November after a 19-year playing career, told Klopp he wants to become a manager in the future. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left in 2015 after winning multiple trophies including the Champions League, Uefa Cup, and FA Cup. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League, and previously declined the MK Dons manager position as it came too soon.

Morton defeated Alloa with McManus scoring from close range after 15 minutes, followed by Ross Forbes' deflected strike to make it 2-0. Kyle McAusland pulled one back for Alloa before half-time, but McManus added a second goal and Denny Johnstone scored late to secure a comfortable victory for Morton.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in squalid conditions at three locations in Birmingham, which have now been closed. A total of 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw expressed concern that children are at risk of abuse or radicalization, calling the cases the "tip of the iceberg." Any place teaching children more than 20 hours weekly must register as a school, but some establishments are exploiting home education laws to operate illegally. Those running illegal schools face up to 51 weeks imprisonment. The government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups, including Muslim, Jewish, and Christian communities. The Education Secretary has requested Ofsted prepare prosecution cases and is consulting on plans for increased regulation of places teaching more than 6 to 8 hours weekly.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders in nearly 200 years. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes operates one of the UK's smallest production stills from a cowshed, using local wild botanicals from the Teviot valley to create a gin reflecting the Borders' local flavour. The distillery complements the Scottish Borders Brewery already on site. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary female figure who fought at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545 to avenge her lover's death, with the battle site located near the distillery. Several whisky distillery proposals are also in development for the region.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than twice the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. The incident occurred at about 09:15 on 9 August when Green backed the tractor into Whitlam, who was walking in a closed-off area of the farm. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting failing to ensure the safety of others. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law because the incident occurred on private land. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, who worked at the farm's cafe, said her family had been "changed forever" and expressed hope that Harry's life would be remembered for more than the day of the accident. The Health and Safety Executive described Green's behaviour as "reckless".

Luis Suarez's four-month ban from all football activity for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup has been partially lifted by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). While the overall sanctions were confirmed, Cas ruled that preventing him from any football activity was excessive. The 27-year-old Uruguay striker can now train with Barcelona and play in friendly matches, though he remains banned from competitive fixtures. His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October, and he must still serve eight remaining games of his nine-match international ban. Suarez's legal team argued Fifa's punishment was disproportionate, while Cas determined that prohibiting training would unfairly impact the player beyond the suspension period. The £75m Barcelona signing had previously been suspended twice for biting incidents and once for racial abuse.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a wife-carrying competition on 18 March 2014, defeating Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene. The pair trained for a week running around an athletics track. The 380-metre course included obstacles such as haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Marriage is not required for participation, with various gender combinations competing. The winners will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government plans to replace the paper car tax disc system with an electronic system in October 2014, allowing monthly direct debit payments. Stephen Hammond, the minister, addressed concerns about potential job losses at the DVLA's Swansea centre, which employs 5,000 workers. He stated that while the changes may reduce refund processing work and alter job roles, requiring new training, any workforce reductions would be managed through redeployment to growing business areas rather than redundancies. Local AM Mike Hedges expressed relief at this commitment, acknowledging the system's advantages while noting disappointment about reduced job opportunities.

Hungary's Foreign Minister told Reuters the EU should not interfere with domestic issues regarding three controversial laws. He confirmed Poland would veto any attempt to strip Hungary of EU voting rights, which requires unanimous approval. The EU objects to Hungary's asylum seeker controls, restrictions on NGOs, and a higher education law that critics say could close Central European University, founded by George Soros. The minister stated Hungary would not backtrack on these laws, arguing they fall under national competence. Hungary is currently housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers, raising EU law compatibility questions. The higher education law signed in April could force closure of the world-ranked CEU, while draft NGO legislation would label rights groups as "foreign-backed." The EU Commission's deputy head warned of action if no positive developments occur.

The live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast has cast Emma Thompson as Mrs Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice. Emma Watson will star as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the film, which begins shooting at Shepperton Studios in May and releases in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a Sunday Times columnist since 1993, died following a cancer diagnosis he had publicly disclosed the previous month. The journalist, known for his wit and distinctive writing style despite dyslexia, dictated his copy over the telephone. His final column about his diagnosis will appear in the Sunday Times. Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens described him as "a giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill began his career with art reviews in the 1980s before joining Tatler and then the Sunday Times.
