His writing, while popular, frequently sparked controversy, including articles about shooting a baboon, disparaging comments about Wales and various UK locations, and remarks about Clare Balding that led to censure. He had been married twice previously and was engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he had twin children. He also had two children from his second marriage to Amber Rudd, now Home Secretary.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomatic official in Ulan Bator after performing while wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika. He was reportedly hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, spending about 10 days in a coma with serious brain injuries. The swastika is a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Nazi Germany by centuries, representing eternity. The Russian embassy said it was investigating but called local reports "distorted." The suspect has not been arrested, with police citing the injury as "not serious," though they denied diplomatic immunity was the reason. Sukhbaatar's family and lawyer emphasized the swastika's cultural significance in Mongolia and denied social media claims he shouted "Heil Hitler." They are demanding the suspect be investigated under Mongolian law regardless of diplomatic status.

Activists from Plane Stupid protested on Monday against airport expansion plans by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. Multiple men and women were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome, with court appearances scheduled for 19 August. The Metropolitan Police announced that airport security would be reviewed following the incident.

Nick Selman scored a mature 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, to dominate Glamorgan's total of 220 against Gloucestershire. After being dropped on eight, the Brisbane-born opener returned to form following a string of low scores including four ducks. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions in Cardiff, with Taylor hitting the stumps three times. Aneurin Donald contributed 36 off 30 balls as the next best score, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten helped Glamorgan reach a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire struggled in reply as bowlers remained on top throughout the day, leaving the match evenly balanced. Michael Hogan led Glamorgan for the first time in Jacques Rudolph's absence due to a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making threats during online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He stated he planned to make a false police report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary where he would shoot them. The threats were made twice, late at night while Hughes was drunk. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and will be sentenced next week. Hughes has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was remanded in custody. His legal team said he had not intended to carry out the threats. North Wales Police were particularly concerned as he was on bail for firearms offences at the time, though he was subsequently cleared of those charges.

Yorkshire were bowled out for 236 chasing Surrey's 255-7 in a semi-final match, falling short of reaching Lord's for the first time since 2002. Surrey recovered from 8-2 through a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase collapsed when Stuart Meaker took three wickets in nine balls, dismissing Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire couldn't maintain the required run rate in the final overs. Matthew Waite dropped Davies on 43, who went on to score significantly. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees acknowledged his team wasn't good enough when it mattered, while Surrey skipper Gareth Batty praised the Davies-Foakes partnership as magnificent.

A 56-foot converted trawler experienced flooding 6 miles west of South Stack at 07:00 BST when its onboard pump failed to manage incoming water. The crew contacted coastguards, and an RNLI lifeboat crew responded by providing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner who finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final year veterinary medicine exams in May. Despite being disappointed to miss one of the few opportunities to represent Scotland, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m in London, her fifth race in 10 days, and is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. She believes she has at least two or three more Olympics ahead of her.

Liverpool are struggling to replicate last season's title challenge, sitting far from the level required and needing to work hard just to reach the top four. Their main problems stem from losing Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's 52 goals, with replacements Balotelli, Lambert and Borini lacking quality and work-rate. The team has dropped from 59 first-half goals last season to just four in their first 10 games this campaign, with fewer runners from midfield and dramatically reduced set-piece effectiveness. Despite spending heavily on defenders including Lovren (£20m) and Sakho (£18m), Liverpool's defense remains problematic and lacks leadership, while goalkeeper Mignolet doesn't command his area sufficiently. Manager Brendan Rodgers faces criticism over transfer decisions, though last season's overachievement raised expectations unrealistically. For the Chelsea match, a 4-3-3 formation is suggested with Toure replacing the underperforming Lovren. Steven Gerrard, despite uncertainty over his contract and the lingering impact of his costly slip against Chelsea in April, remains one of Liverpool's most important players at 34, though he faces physical and mental challenges to extend his career in defensive midfield.

A £45m educational facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after William McIlvanney, the renowned writer who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, who became an English teacher before turning to full-time writing in 1975, gained recognition for novels including Remedy Is None and the Laidlaw trilogy, earning him the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir". He was also a poet, journalist and broadcaster who contributed to Scottish political and sporting life. The novelist died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near a swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon after a sea mine, believed to be British from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted on Monday in the river. Three streets were evacuated and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors. An exclusion zone of about half a mile was established at sea, affecting small boats and causing some disruption to Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services between Gourock and Rothesay. The Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit determined the mine's deterioration made it impossible to assess remaining explosive content, so it was decided to move it to a safer location. Authorities emphasized the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger to the community.

UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than Rio funding. Badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby have lost all funding, while cycling faces a £4m cut to £25.98m. Badminton England expressed shock at the decision, noting they won bronze in Rio and met performance targets. Team GB is set a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals, compared to 67 and 147 respectively in Rio. UK Sport's CEO stated they must prioritize medal potential, though the decision to cut funding wasn't taken lightly. Basketball, handball and volleyball criticized UK Sport for ignoring team sports despite a previous review recommending performance pathway development. Funding for five new Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added to Tokyo 2020, including baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing and surfing, remains undecided with £9m still to be allocated.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. Despite strong objections from English Heritage regarding the scale of development and its impact on the conservation area, councillors approved the plans seven to three, citing benefits to tourism and housing for older residents. The development on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments in nine-storey and seven-storey buildings. The East Cliff Project LLP will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View hotels. The council received 246 letters of support and 49 objections, with opponents arguing the buildings retain historic character despite alterations.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was found unconscious in Brecon on 8 May and died after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, while off-duty during training exercises. CCTV showed Vallely attacking Boyd outside The Cellar bar, beating him until he stopped moving, then dragging his body away. Vallely, who had been drinking for seven hours and boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon," was convicted of manslaughter and will be sentenced on 8 December. His friend Aaeron Evans was cleared as he had left before the violence began. Boyd's family described him as loving and caring with a promising career cut short, while police called it a despicable act that shocked the Brecon community.

Andrew Travers left his position as Barnet Council chief executive by mutual agreement following an election day error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations because names were missing from the poll list. At one station, only three of the first 30 voters were registered. The council apologised and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. Travers, who served for three and a half years, blamed electoral registration lists for the problems. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. An independent investigation has been launched, with findings to be presented to the General Functions Committee by the end of May, and will examine arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a football match. Josh Gillies scored first for Gateshead with a free-kick, before Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with another set-piece before half-time. Ryan Bowman headed the winner for Gateshead in the second half from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improved second-half passing and credited Wrexham's strong first-half performance. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half display, noting they were too open and failed to convert chances despite not conceding many opportunities.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of people over 60 across 96 countries. Norway ranks first while Afghanistan ranks last, with Mozambique second to last.

OneWeb is building a satellite constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially exceeding 2,000, to provide global broadband internet access, particularly targeting schools. Airbus has developed new assembly line manufacturing methods in Toulouse to produce three satellites per shift at under a million dollars each, a significant departure from traditional satellite production costing hundreds of millions and taking months. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April next year, with over 20 Soyuz rockets booked to deploy clusters into orbit 1,200km above Earth. The project aims for nearly 300 satellites operational by end of 2020/early 2021, over 600 a year later, and more than 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb has raised $1.7bn in equity and is seeking additional loans. The company is registered in the UK Channel Islands and licensed by the UK Space Agency. To address space debris concerns, OneWeb commits to de-orbiting defunct satellites within two years and has included hardware to enable retrieval of failed spacecraft. Two additional assembly lines will open in Florida, and the venture hopes to manufacture satellites for other companies.

The Scottish Finance Secretary Mr Swinney stated that the UK government's spending review has placed unprecedented pressure on Scotland's public expenditure, arguing that cuts since 2010 mean Scotland's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than in 2010-11. He committed to protecting schools, hospitals and police services despite facing over £1bn in cuts still to come by 2020. The UK government countered that Scotland will have £390m more in spending available next year, with a block grant of almost £30bn, arguing this is better than independence given current oil prices. Labour's Jackie Baillie criticized both positions, calling for a long-term budget and a real alternative to austerity. Mr Swinney was due to present his 2016-17 spending plans on Wednesday.

Many people with severe disabilities require specialized toilet facilities beyond standard accessible toilets, needing equipment like hoists, changing benches, and space for two carers. Changing Places toilets provide these enhanced features and extra space, with 893 currently in the UK serving potentially over 250,000 people. While specifications have been included in Building Standards guidelines since 2009, they remain recommendations rather than compulsory requirements. Families describe the distress of changing loved ones on dirty floors or in cars when suitable facilities are unavailable, leading to social isolation. Campaigners, including parents like Lorna Fillingham, are petitioning to make Changing Places mandatory in building regulations for larger new buildings such as shopping centres, cinemas, and leisure facilities. Though logistical and financial barriers exist, particularly regarding the larger 12 square metre size requirement, some venues like Arsenal Football Club have successfully installed these facilities by adapting existing spaces, demonstrating that implementation is possible with proper planning and support.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, sign longer-than-average contracts that prevent switching to competitors, and lease premises at above-market rates. The complaint, supported by the Service Employees International Union and European unions including the UK's Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, claims these practices abuse McDonald's dominant market position and result in poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned locations. McDonald's denies the allegations, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees through an approach that has been successful for many years. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if it finds the allegations credible. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, and the company received $9.27 billion in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

Thirteen-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors discovered a large primary cancer and five smaller growths during what was supposed to be an appendix operation at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on pastoral staff, started a #prayforjosh hashtag on Facebook and Instagram to gather prayer support. The campaign went viral, with one update shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people worldwide. A mystery donor paid for a large billboard with the phrase to be erected at Holywood playing fields. Josh's classmates at Bangor Grammar and people globally have joined in supporting him through social media during his recovery.

The UK government announced the closure of Brecon Barracks as part of a military buildings reorganization and regiment resettling. Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly opposed the decision, noting the barracks has existed since 1805 and housed troops who fought at Rorke's Drift. He launched a petition, citing concerns about high local unemployment and potential damage to military tourism. The barracks employs about 85 civilians and 90 military personnel, though jobs are not thought to be at risk. The nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school are expected to remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a specialist light infantry centre would be created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, while Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire will close in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for estate restructuring but expressed concern about the impact on local livelihoods.

The House of Lords European Union Committee report examines Brexit's impact on UK fishing. While the industry voted heavily to leave the EU and views Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters, the report warns fishing may be marginalized in negotiations despite its importance to coastal communities. The UK may need to grant EU boats access to British waters in exchange for tariff-free market access, since most UK fish are exported to the EU. The report recommends retaining elements of the Common Fisheries Policy, including scientific advice for quotas, and notes the UK remains under international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. A concern is that leaving the CFP could create four separate fisheries regimes across UK nations. The fishing industry remains optimistic, citing recent quota increases and anticipating better control as an independent coastal state. The government states it seeks maximum trading freedom while reviewing fisheries management for fair quota access and sustainable stocks.

Ed Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing that the US National Security Agency has massive-scale access to individual communications data, including chat logs, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The NSA requested millions of phone records from Verizon and allegedly accessed servers of nine major technology companies through a program called Prism, established in 2007. US officials, including Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, called the leaks extremely damaging to national security, while NSA Director Keith Alexander defended the operations as necessary to keep Americans secure. President Obama stated that complete security requires some sacrifice of privacy and convenience. Senator Dianne Feinstein claimed phone records were only accessed when individuals were suspected of connections to al-Qaeda or Iran. The companies named denied involvement, and experts debate Prism's actual capabilities. User data is often stored in the US regardless of users' locations, subjecting it to US Patriot Act and FISA Act provisions. UK Foreign Secretary William Hague refused to confirm whether British intelligence had Prism access and stated law-abiding citizens have nothing to worry about. The EU Justice Commission expressed concern and sought more details. Snowden said he leaked the information because he found the surveillance extent horrifying and didn't want to live in a society where everything is recorded.

OpenAI is a venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services that has received $1 billion in pledged funding. The organization aims to conduct AI research focused on positive human impact, free from financial obligations. While scientists like Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned that AI advances could threaten humanity, with Hawking suggesting AI could outpace biological evolution by redesigning itself, other experts believe this risk remains remote. OpenAI's stated goal is to advance digital intelligence to benefit humanity without being constrained by profit requirements, ensuring AI serves as an extension of individual human wills and is broadly distributed. Only a small fraction of the pledged funds will be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan that caused brain injury affecting his speech, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June in Doncaster. He walked for nearly half an hour with assistance, flanked by hundreds of supporters. Since then, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the platform's 5,000-friend limit for personal pages. Despite his injuries, he maintained his personality and humor, regained unaided speech, and now spends 12 hours daily in gym and rehabilitation while raising money for military charities as patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His mother reported phenomenal public response, including over 5,000 friend requests, 19,000 page hits, increased mail (some addressed simply to "Ben, please Mr Postie"), and hundreds of requests for torch visits. Facebook guidance suggests he should create a public figure page instead of a personal profile.

The poverty rate in the US was 15% in 2011, affecting 46.2 million Americans, remaining flat after three years of increases. Real median household income fell 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality rose 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. The uninsured rate decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The 25-year-old Jos Buttler has signed a new contract with Lancashire until 2019, having joined from Somerset in 2013. The short-format specialist holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler as one of the game's most talented cricketers, highlighting his contribution to Lancashire's T20 Blast final victory and his positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler will return from playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians to play for Lancashire against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates - HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall - are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and being sold by the government's Disposal Services Authority. Bidders registered interest by 23 January, with no preservation proposals submitted. Viewings are scheduled for late February and March, with a final decision expected in spring. The government wants at least one frigate awarded to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic recycling capacity. Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers opportunity but hopes at least one ship could be saved, suggesting use as a reef and diving attraction for tourism. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options for best financial return. Type 22 frigates were specialist anti-submarine ships that evolved into powerful surface combatants with crews of about 280, known for command, control and communication capabilities.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced racial and political tensions causing instability and international isolation. Indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition in 1987, followed by another coup in 2000 led by George Speight that held the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister hostage. These events damaged the economy and tourism industry. A fourth coup occurred in 2006, leading to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. After agreeing to hold elections in 2014, diplomatic ties were restored and Commonwealth membership reinstated. Fiji's population, residing mainly on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, descendants of Indian indentured laborers. Thousands of Indo-Fijians fled due to coups and agitation, making indigenous Fijians the majority. The two groups remain largely segregated. The former British colony's economy relies on sugar and tourism, with additional sectors including mining, services, and light manufacturing, though persistent trade and budget deficits make it a major per capita aid recipient.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated Syria is doing its best to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons stockpile, though it missed Wednesday's deadline. He said a weapons shipment was attacked twice by terrorist groups while being transported from Damascus to Latakia port. Mekdad rejected US criticism of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, claiming Syria is defending against terrorists and never targets civilians. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports 246 people, including 73 children, were killed in Aleppo over five days from barrel bomb attacks. Syria also denied reports that rebels seized Aleppo's central prison, though opposition sources claim rebels control it. Of Syria's 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, only 30 tonnes (4%) have left the country. Russia suggested a new March 1 deadline for transferring weapons to the coast, with final destruction due by end of June.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist features six novels, with Nayan Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" as the 5/2 favorite. This is the first year the prize is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, and one other), two Americans (Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler), and one Australian (Richard Flanagan). Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" is the best-selling shortlisted novel with over 55,000 copies sold. The announcement caused sales spikes for all shortlisted books. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night, with the judging panel chaired by AC Grayling. Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book.

A celebrity known as PJS is appealing to the Supreme Court against a ruling that lifted a ban preventing media in England and Wales from naming him. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal, with an interim injunction remaining in place until the hearing concludes. The case involves the Sun on Sunday wanting to publish details of alleged extra-marital sexual encounters between PJS and another person (AB), including a three-way encounter with AB's partner (CD) in 2011. PJS, who has young children and a spouse also in the public eye, argues for privacy rights. Initially, a High Court refused an injunction, but Appeal Court judges imposed one preventing identification in England and Wales. However, News Group Newspapers successfully argued the ban should be lifted because the story had already been published in the US, Scotland, and spread widely on the internet and Twitter. The Appeal Court ruled that confidentiality had "probably been lost" as details were "so widespread," making efforts to remove online stories a "hopeless task," and that PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was purchased in August for £345.5m. The new owners are preparing plans to address parking and traffic congestion issues and improve the appearance of units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White confirmed the owners met with the council regarding planning matters, noting the park serves as a gateway into the city and currently presents an unappealing view of building backs. Crown Estates director Paul Clarke stated the park has become tired in recent years and they aim to improve common areas, parking facilities, and overall quality.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast was delayed in Malaysia for content review after controversy over a "gay moment" in the film. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the screening on Tuesday with a minor edit concerning the gay moment, granting it a P13 parental guidance classification. Homosexual activity is illegal in Muslim-majority Malaysia. The film features LeFou, sidekick to antagonist Gaston, experiencing feelings for Gaston that swing between lust and admiration. A new release date has not been announced, and local cinemas have been offering refunds for advance ticket purchases. The decision to review the Disney film drew criticism from many who called it "stupid and laughable."

Southampton City Council requires landlords letting properties to more than three unrelated people to obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence costing £1,000, with fines up to £20,000 for non-compliance. The council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs exist in the area. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three or more storeys occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, licensing affects properties in specific areas: Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (since 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (since 2015). Shelter reports receiving five to six daily calls from HMO tenants concerned about eviction and poor property maintenance, attributing the issue to a shortage of affordable homes forcing people into unregulated rentals. While most landlords have cooperated, the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are attempting to avoid a second election following inconclusive results almost two months ago that left Fine Gael with 50 seats, Fianna Fáil with 44, Sinn Féin with 23, and Labour with seven. Fianna Fáil has agreed to facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. Water charges remain a major obstacle, with Fianna Fáil demanding immediate removal while Fine Gael supports maintaining them. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being proposed as a potential solution. No party has been able to form a majority government or elect a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento caught fire on a car deck while traveling to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon. The cause of the fire is unclear. All passengers and crew were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ferry, the Puglia, which transported them back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured, with one seriously hurt, and were airlifted to hospital. The Balearic Islands port authority warned the ship may sink. Initially, the captain did not believe evacuation was necessary, but the fire intensified, forcing a full evacuation after distress signals were sent at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about people, including students, potentially voting twice in the 8 June election, which is a criminal offence. A record 46.8 million people registered to vote, with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. However, duplicate registrations remain a significant problem. Of 4.9 million applications submitted between December 2016 and the May deadline, the net increase was only 1.4 million, suggesting duplicate applications ranged from 30-70% in different areas. The issue stems from electoral registers and the online registration system using different databases that cannot communicate directly, with no way for people to check if they're already registered. The Commission recommends better integration of the 381 separate electoral registers to identify duplicates and reduce double voting risk, and suggests people registered in two constituencies should choose in advance where to vote. While some may legally register in multiple places for local elections, voting twice in general elections carries an unlimited fine. Labour warned against making registration harder for young people and students who may legitimately need to register in two locations.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player, apparently killed himself in prison on Wednesday. He was a star at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s and played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, though his career was marked by ongoing troubles. After leaving the NFL, Phillips had continued legal problems, including convictions for driving his car into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend, resulting in a prison sentence exceeding 30 years. He was in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, 37, and a judge had just ruled there was sufficient evidence to try him for that death.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier, was promoted to lance corporal for good behaviour at a Mercian Regiment event in Chester marking the regiment's eighth anniversary. He is the 30th mascot ram in a lineage dating back to 1858 when the first Private Derby was acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot during the Indian Mutiny War. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined in February 2014, has an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season at Chatsworth Estate. His duties have included switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a dramatic Europa League quarter-final at Anfield, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winner in injury time. Dortmund took a commanding 2-0 lead in the opening nine minutes through Mkhitaryan and Aubameyang, and later led 3-1, requiring Liverpool to score three goals in 33 minutes. Manager Jurgen Klopp invoked the spirit of the 2005 Champions League final comeback against AC Milan, urging his team to believe the impossible was possible. Liverpool completed the turnaround with goals from Origi, Coutinho, Sakho, and Lovren. The match showcased Klopp's impact since arriving in October, fulfilling his stated aim to "turn doubters into believers." The atmosphere at Anfield was exceptional, with both sets of fans creating a memorable occasion that included an extended rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone" and a minute's silence for the 27th Hillsborough anniversary. The victory moves Liverpool into the semi-finals and closer to Champions League qualification through winning the Europa League, though defensive vulnerabilities remain a concern for the summer.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London to discuss Brexit negotiations. Mr Davis said the UK government would hold monthly meetings to keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland informed and share analysis as part of a "two-way information flow." He described the meeting as constructive despite different standpoints. Mr Russell acknowledged the involvement process was underway but criticized the UK government for lacking clarity on its strategic intentions over four months after the referendum, particularly regarding single market and customs union membership. He emphasized that single market membership is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal regarding how Article 50 will be triggered, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking to be heard in the case.

Thirteen cloned sheep, including four cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep, are undergoing extensive health monitoring at the University of Nottingham to determine whether cloned animals age normally. The study addresses concerns that arose after Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old with osteoarthritis, raising questions about whether the cloning process transfers "age-memory" from adult donor cells, causing premature aging. Researchers are examining the sheep for cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis through physical examinations, X-rays, and fMRI scans. The four sheep cloned from Dolly's original cell line are now approaching nine and ten years old and appear healthy. Results of this study, which could significantly impact the future of cloning science, were to be published the following week.

Shutter Speed, the unbeaten 4-7 favourite trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes at York by a length and three quarters despite very soft ground conditions. The filly will now head to the French Oaks at Chantilly rather than Epsom's Oaks, where Gosden's stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. In the Duke of York Stakes, Tasleet (14-1) won for trainer William Haggas and jockey Jim Crowley, beating Magical Memory. Gosden expressed concerns about the soft ground affecting his colt Cracksman's participation in Thursday's Dante Stakes, a Derby trial, and will walk the course before deciding whether to run him, noting the short 16-day gap between the Dante and the Derby.

The pound fell against major currencies amid increased uncertainty over the EU referendum, with the volatility index reaching levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. Sterling dropped 0.2% against the dollar to $1.4226, 0.6% against the euro to €1.2605, and 1% against the yen. Weekend polls showed the Leave camp ahead, with the probability of a Remain vote falling to 68.5% from 80% a week earlier. Analysts expect the pound to become more volatile as the referendum approaches, with hedge funds short-selling sterling in anticipation of further declines. Asian stock markets fell sharply on Brexit concerns, and London's FTSE 100 closed down 1.1%. Leave campaigners noted that sterling had risen since March and that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-offs. Manager Cowley reflected on their loss to Barrow, noting the difficulty of playing after a long journey and conceding early. Despite a three-game losing streak, Cowley remained positive about their achievements as a part-time team, acknowledging the challenge ahead while expressing determination to embrace it.

From April 2015, Northern Ireland councils will gain new powers including control over most planning decisions, shifting responsibility from the centralized Planning Service to elected local politicians. Supporters view this as democratizing the planning system and giving councils opportunity to develop their communities. However, critics warn of potential risks, citing Northern Ireland's 1960s history of discrimination in housing allocation by local councils that fueled the Civil Rights movement. Environmental group Friends of the Earth expresses concern about ensuring fair and transparent processes, particularly given close relationships between developers and political parties. They argue increased political control over financially significant planning decisions makes transparency about party donations more important, though some politicians oppose donation disclosure citing security concerns and claiming the £7,500 declaration threshold is irrelevant to Northern Ireland parties. The decision on revealing political donations rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air weapon in Winchburgh - twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which required amputation. The cat's owner found her injured on 14 March and took her to the Scottish SPCA. Teenie survived but is learning to walk again. The Scottish SPCA called the incident alarming and used it to argue for urgent implementation of air gun licensing in Scotland. The Scottish government had previously consulted on licensing air weapons, but 87% of respondents opposed the plan, calling it "draconian" and "heavy-handed." The proposed scheme would require air gun owners to demonstrate legitimate reasons for ownership. The Scottish SPCA is seeking information about the person responsible for shooting the cat.

Liverpool signed striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for £32.5m, making him the club's second most expensive signing. The 24-year-old Belgium international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012, becomes Liverpool's seventh summer signing on a long-term contract. The move addresses Liverpool's goal-scoring struggles last season following Luis Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injuries, with previous signings Balotelli and Lambert managing only three league goals between them. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury but returned to score 15 goals last season, helping Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final. Liverpool also signed forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and recalled Divock Origi from loan.

A study of 671 UK schools found that tablet devices are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with numbers expected to rise from 430,000 to 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. However, there is no clear evidence that tablets improve academic results, as researchers cannot isolate technology's specific impact on attainment. Head teachers reported positive effects, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement when devices are taken home. The study also revealed that many pupils, especially in schools with individual tablets, are heavily immersed in technology, with about two-thirds taking devices to bed for social media use and a quarter of secondary pupils describing themselves as internet "addicts". A separate study suggested touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read, with children from poorer households more likely to read on screens than printed books.

The Museum of Liverpool's exhibition "Growing Up in the City" features 25 photographs documenting children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to 1990s. The images provide both a glimpse into childhood and a social history of the city across decades. The oldest photograph from 1887 shows the Rollo children from a wealthy Waterloo Park family dressed for a fancy dress ball. The exhibition includes images of children at play and at work, including a young maid photographed around 1900. Curator Kay Jones selected the final 25 images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections, choosing photographs that captured both positive and negative childhood experiences, including those who had to work. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has joined a National League club after mutually terminating his Barrow contract and could face his former team on 18 February. The ex-Aldershot and Exeter player, who has also played in Italy, is described by manager Kevin Nicholson as a leader with the right stature and voice. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has also signed, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps. The club sits four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six matches.

The Bolivian law permits 12-year-olds to work for others with parental authorization. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera stated the legislation reflects Bolivia's needs as one of South America's poorest countries. The law also establishes harsher punishments for violence against children, including 30 years imprisonment for child homicide. Over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia to supplement family income, according to Unicef, with many cleaning shoes, selling food, or working in mines and agriculture. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty. While the International Labour Organisation recommends a minimum working age of 15 (or 14 for developing countries), it is reviewing whether Bolivia's legislation breaches international regulations on child labour. Garcia defended the law as necessary to match Bolivia's reality rather than simply conforming to international conventions.

A 50-year-old woman fell ill at home and searched online for women's heart attack symptoms, which matched her sudden nausea and aches. After taking aspirin, she saw a cardiologist the next day who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99 percent blocked. Her symptoms began after helping a woman from a car, and she experienced chest aches, nausea, and fever. She suffered what is known as a "widow maker" heart attack and did not call emergency services. She wrote about the experience in a blog post, warning women to know the symptoms and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton at about 00:30 GMT following a party on Saturday evening. He was pronounced dead an hour later. Police said there had been an earlier fight when a group of youths tried to gain entry to the party, but Che was not involved in that altercation and appeared to have been targeted in a later scuffle. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and remains in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed, and a 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganised cancer diagnosis after poor survival statistics 15 years ago showed it was underperforming compared to other European countries. The main problem was long waiting times, particularly for patients with vague symptoms or those needing tests to rule out serious illness - over 25% of 30,000 cancer cases fell into this category. Denmark introduced three diagnostic routes: fast-track pathways for patients with alarm symptoms of specific cancers, with a legal requirement that any physical illness be investigated within 30 days of GP referral; diagnostic centres at hospitals where patients with unclear symptoms receive quick tests and scans; and "yes-no" centres offering simple tests for patients with minor symptoms, where 1% are found to have serious disease. Previously, this last group might have waited four to six months. The changes improved organisation within existing resources without flooding the system with referrals, and Denmark's cancer survival rates are now improving faster than other Scandinavian countries. A Welsh delegation visited Aarhus to learn from the Danish model, which shares similarities with Wales' health system.

Powys council won a competitive bidding process to take over estate agent regulation from the disbanded OFT, receiving £170,000 annually. The council will issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. Local authority trading standards departments will continue handling complaints and prosecutions, but will refer cases to Powys when the Estate Agents Act has been breached. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team and hopes this demonstrates the council's capacity for additional contracts and external work.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the workforce by training staff to take on additional tasks, following a Nuffield Trust review. The review found examples of nurses performing hospital doctor duties and pharmacists covering for GPs. This approach aims to address junior doctor rota gaps and GP capacity issues within the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce. The report highlighted various experimental initiatives, including nurses prescribing and pharmacists managing minor ailments. Proponents argue this reflects changing care needs, with greater focus on managing long-term conditions rather than curing illness. However, unions have raised concerns, warning against using this as a quick fix. The BMA emphasized that years of doctor training cannot be substituted, while Unison noted funding constraints often prevent adequate training courses. Both unions stressed the need for proper investment rather than treating workforce development as a cheap solution to staff shortages.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at 03:00 GMT following a crash at Rackfield Place outside the First depot. The A36 closure, lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations into the collision are under way. First bus services were partially resumed, with managing director James Freeman stating they hoped to have full services running for the evening commute, thanking the public and staff for their support.

NRW estimated that the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually during migration. Tidal Lagoon Power disputed these figures, claiming they lack clear scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its calculation methodology. TLP's own computer modelling estimated a worst-case scenario of 2% mortality across all fish species. The £1.3bn project is intended as a test for larger lagoons around the Welsh coast. UK government ministers are reviewing the scheme's viability, with Wales' Environment Secretary calling for clarity on the government's position. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism, stating it has shared extensive information and methodology over 18 months of discussions, with assessments conducted by independent and technical experts using the best available evidence.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, modeled on Scotland Food and Drink. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board to provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing activities across government and private sector organizations. The agri-food industry supports almost 100,000 jobs in Northern Ireland including farming, fishing, retail and distribution. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting industry representatives identified a need for better coordination of marketing activities, though she acknowledged the plans could have implications for existing organizations including her department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event on Saturday afternoon at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. This is part of a four-year project to create four new woods across the UK, planting millions of native trees to commemorate those who died in WW1. At Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted to honor the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The project uses the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." Director Patrick Cregg encourages public participation in creating this living tribute, which will eventually feature wildflowers including poppies and serve as a place for wildlife and reflection. The site is located seven miles outside Derry city off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available. Volunteers are advised to wear appropriate footwear, and saplings will be provided.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence and honour crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Judge Alison Graham called it "emotionally exhausting and powerful," while festival programming chair Ann Cleeves praised its fine writing, atmosphere, and plotting. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about female private investigator VI Warshawski, who appeared in a 1991 film starring Kathleen Turner and BBC Radio 4 adaptations. Cleeves noted Paretsky was a "game changer" who transformed perceptions of female crime writers by creating a strong female protagonist when it was uncommon. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally. The awards were presented at the start of North Yorkshire's annual crime writing festival.

Worcestershire has re-signed New Zealand all-rounder Mitchell Santner for the 2017 season after his 2016 stint was cut short by a broken finger in his second game. The 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner will return following the ICC Trophy in June. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes stated Santner's injury was a significant setback to their qualifying hopes after a promising start. Santner, who debuted for New Zealand in 2015, expressed frustration over the injury and eagerness to contribute with bat and ball. Worcestershire has also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for 2017.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car on a dual carriageway hard shoulder in Kiev in 2008 while his wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant. A coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating the evidence was overwhelming that Pring was unlawfully killed. The car had stolen plates and did not stop. Pring's family believes he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run, noting his wife was 19 years younger, they married after a four-day engagement in 2007, and she attempted to claim his assets within days of his death, selling his property and moving funds. Evidence showed she was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. Witnesses described the killing as deliberate, with the car traveling at 75mph without lights. Ukrainian police closed then relaunched the case as a murder inquiry in 2011, which remains open but not actively pursued.

Charlie, a boy from Merseyside who has been ill since age three, needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital in America for experimental T-Cell Therapy unavailable in the UK. After experiencing a third relapse in April and the failure of his first T-Cell transplant, his parents were told there were no treatment options left in the UK. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment after specifically requesting to cover his costs. His parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns from Litherland, received confirmation from the hospital on Wednesday and described feeling ecstatic, overwhelmed, and extremely grateful. The treatment will begin as soon as possible, with the date expected to be confirmed next week.

Apple has extended its two-step verification system to iCloud after third-party software was allegedly used to steal celebrities' intimate photos. The security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password, preventing unauthorized access even with correct login credentials. Previously, hackers could bypass two-step verification to download complete iCloud backups using software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The software's developer confirmed Apple's implementation is secure and his program can no longer access user accounts this way. Users now receive email notifications when backups are downloaded. However, the feature remains optional rather than default. Security experts suggest two-factor authentication should be enabled by default across all platforms. Apple's CEO stated the company plans to encourage adoption more aggressively and improve user awareness, though concerns remain about recovery key management and potential theft.

Dan Groves stated that details of a deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town football club have not yet been released. According to The Sun, the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay currently sit eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind the play-off positions. Wright, who finished as runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who indicated he was willing to invest £10,000 weekly. Billericay also signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

Mr Ashley, owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been asked to give evidence to the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee about worker treatment at the company's Derbyshire warehouse following a BBC investigation into working practices. Committee chair Iain Wright wrote that while Mr Ashley invited the committee to meet at the company's Shirebrook base, he declined multiple alternative dates offered for a public meeting at Westminster. Wright gave Mr Ashley until 21 March to respond, warning that failure to agree to attend could result in a contempt complaint to the House of Commons. The committee is reviewing treatment of low-paid workers and national minimum wage enforcement. Sports Direct previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight but has not commented on the current request.

Russian opposition politicians, led by Ilya Yashin, completed a report entitled "Putin. War" that was begun by murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. The Russian-language report accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain, documenting evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in securing major victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk, despite Russia's denials of sending regular troops. The dossier includes testimony from volunteer soldiers admitting Russian generals directed main battles, with salaries reaching $2,000-3,000 monthly, and calculates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles. The report documents military unit names, numbers, and weaponry photos, though verification is difficult. Nemtsov began the work after learning relatives of dead Russian soldiers were denied promised compensation. The opposition had an initial print run of only 2,000 copies, with many publishers afraid to work with the material. The report's authors acknowledge it may fail to galvanize protests against Putin, as his previous reports on corruption and Sochi Olympics costs did, particularly since many Russians find their country's involvement in eastern Ukraine acceptable.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem examination determined he died from head injuries. South Yorkshire Police arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield, who remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, Wales' First Minister, criticized the UK government for not allowing him to see or contribute to Theresa May's Article 50 letter before its publication, calling this treatment of devolved administrations unacceptable and disrespectful. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the government, noting the Prime Minister had visited Wales three times in six weeks and discussed the letter's contents for months. May's letter to Donald Tusk promised consultation on which powers returning from the EU should go to Westminster versus devolved administrations, with an expectation of increased devolved decision-making. However, specific details about which powers (such as farming or economic aid) will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them remain unclear, with Jones expressing concern about post-2020 funding. A white paper on the Great Repeal Bill may provide more clarity, but the allocation of powers remains uncertain.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the mindless attacks on officers and the Newry community. Police appealed to parents to know their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In a San Francisco court filing responding to his defamation lawsuit, the board documented evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, stating he repeatedly violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies and would not return to the firm. His lawyer called the statements false and accused the company of invading his privacy to gain leverage. The company was granted a restraining order preventing him from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain's basketball team will face Greece at the Copper Box in London, with coverage on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website. Greece won their previous meeting in Patras 92-64, but three of their players will be absent for this match. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the venue in his hometown of Stratford. This will be Britain's only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the Greece match, coach Joe Prunty's team will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final preparation before EuroBasket. The game will be broadcast from 17:30-19:30 BST.

The passage recounts a journalist's experience covering the 2007 iPhone launch by Steve Jobs. Initially struggling to access the device for filming, the author obtained one from Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller. The coverage drew criticism for giving excessive prominence to a product launch, with the journalist defending it by comparing the iPhone's potential impact to the Model T Ford. A decade later, this comparison proved apt, as smartphones became the key transformative technology, putting powerful computers in over two billion hands and disrupting numerous industries. The author illustrates this through photography, showing how smartphone cameras evolved to match professional equipment while enabling instant social media sharing. While cameras and internet existed on phones before 2007, Steve Jobs' innovation was creating an attractive user interface that made people want to use these features beyond basic calls and texts. The journalist concludes that despite initial British skepticism about the launch's hyperbole, the event marked the beginning of the mobile connected era, preceding later innovations from companies like Amazon and Google.

Five cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze, with tests confirming the toxic substance in all cases. The most recent death was seven-month-old Meereen on Monday, who showed symptoms including shivering, foaming at the mouth, and vomiting after coming home on Friday evening. Three other cats died in the previous seven days, and another died two weeks earlier. The RSPCA is investigating but cannot confirm whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate, and is urging residents to store chemicals safely and clean up any antifreeze spills or leaks from vehicles.

Greece's tourism is booming with 25 million expected airport arrivals, possibly due to instability elsewhere, yet there are no street protests despite the Syriza government preparing to implement austerity and liberalization measures previously opposed. Prime Minister Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity, with Greece's July near-collapse—bank closures and economic downturn—apparently converting Syriza to accept "there is no alternative." The country now faces both fiscal and monetary austerity, with partially closed banks unable to lend, threatening retailers' ability to stock for Christmas. Greece is negotiating its third bailout worth €86 billion from the eurozone and possibly the IMF. For the bailout to succeed and offer hope of recovery, many argue creditors must forgive between one-third and one-half of Greece's unsustainable debt burden, requiring Brussels and Berlin to show restraint rather than triumphalism.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Dame Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Windsor's character Peggy returned to Albert Square to reveal her cancer has returned and will be killed off in spring episodes. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and in 2005-2006, said he couldn't turn down the opportunity to reunite with Windsor, a close friend, for the storyline. The return will see the Mitchell brothers reunited with their mother for the last time. Grant Mitchell was one of the soap's most memorable characters over its 30-year history, involved in major family dramas including affairs and relationship entanglements with his brother Phil.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles in October. When police informed her parents, they immediately knew Dhillon was responsible. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court heard Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and stalked her. Two days before the killing, Alice's mother reassured her daughter the police were aware and to ignore Dhillon, though her other daughter Emma warned he would kill her—a warning dismissed as overreaction. The mother expressed guilt, believing Alice might still be alive had she not given that reassurance. Alice's father said none of them, including Alice, realized how serious the situation was. Her parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers and want her remembered for her vibrant, cheeky personality. Dhillon, 26, denied murder but was convicted and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

The UK government has delayed final approval of the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant in Somerset, hours after French firm EDF's board voted to approve funding for the project. Business Secretary Greg Clark said the government will "consider carefully" before backing it, causing EDF's chief executive to cancel a planned trip to the site. EDF is financing most of the project, with one third of costs provided by Chinese investors. The plant is expected to provide 7% of UK electricity. The project faces criticism over environmental concerns, potential escalating costs, foreign government involvement, and EDF's financial capacity. EDF board member Gerard Magnin resigned calling it "very risky" financially, and the finance director had resigned earlier this year. Critics argue it represents poor value for money at the agreed price of £92.50 per megawatt-hour, approximately double the market rate when agreed in 2013. Industry representatives warn delays could cause energy supply problems and increased costs, while environmentalists advocate for more renewable energy investment instead.

The newly-designed divorce application form for England and Wales explicitly asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, which family lawyers say adds unnecessary conflict and complexity. While the form's guidance states it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party, lawyers are concerned the direct question encourages people to fill it in despite smaller print warnings. The previous form left space for "co-respondents" where appropriate, but the new version directly requests the name. Naming a third party makes them part of the court case, requiring they receive paperwork and potentially causing delays and additional costs if they don't respond. In 2015, there were over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales, with adultery cited in 12,148 cases and unreasonable behaviour in 46,815. Lawyers report that 80% of adultery clients initially want to involve the new partner, but they advise against it as judges view this unfavorably. The Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name third parties, noting this has always been possible on divorce forms and is now stated more clearly.

The forestry industry in Wales, worth over £450m annually, is facing challenges as at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001. Confor, representing the industry, argues that ministers prioritize environmental concerns over timber production, despite Britain being the world's third largest wood importer. The Welsh government seeks balance between environmental, economic, and social factors through its Woodlands for Wales strategy and Glastir scheme. However, only 90 hectares were planted last year, far short of the 20,000 hectares annually needed to meet long-term targets. The industry faces additional obstacles including difficult terrain, transportation conflicts with rural communities, and bureaucratic barriers to creating new woodland areas. There is tension between demands for commercial forestry and environmental policies favoring native broadleaf species and conservation.

A boy was badly injured after being struck by a vehicle on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at approximately 16:40. Emergency services responded to the incident and transported the boy to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where he remains in serious condition.

Russian Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91-year-old able seaman Charles Lewis from Hampshire. The Arctic Convoys consisted of vessels travelling from Britain to northern Russia during World War II to resupply the Soviet Union, facing constant threats from German U-boats, aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with more than 3,000 Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy initially sought to award the Medal of Ushakov in 2012, but the Foreign Office blocked it as rules prevented British soldiers receiving foreign medals for acts occurring more than five years prior. The Foreign Office later granted an exception, with President Putin presenting the first medals during his London visit in June 2013. The British Government had created the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize convoy veterans. The Russian Embassy stated the convoys provided crucial weapons and ammunition that enabled Soviet forces to defeat Germans on the Eastern Front.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant problems with unpaid work sentences, which can range from 40 to 300 hours for offences like shoplifting and theft. Around 70,000 offenders were ordered to do such work in 2014. An inspection of 100 cases revealed delays in starting work, too many offenders being excused for non-attendance, and one offender completing only 16 hours in 17 months. Problems included offenders being turned away despite reporting on time, and unpaid work being viewed merely as punishment rather than rehabilitation. While inspectors praised some high-quality work and noted many offenders viewed their sentence positively and gained skills, the chief inspector said much of the delivery was not good enough and lacked focus on enforcing court sentences. The report made 15 recommendations for improvement. The Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations and said it was taking action, stating it was unacceptable for offenders to skip court-enforced work.

The passage discusses accusations of hypocrisy against comedian Russell Brand for campaigning for economic revolution to help poorer people while living in a luxury London home. The Sun newspaper ran a front-page headline calling him a hypocrite. Brand was questioned by a Channel 4 News journalist about his rent while supporting east London estate residents facing eviction, which angered him and he walked off. Brand has previously addressed these accusations, acknowledging he is rich and famous but arguing that he recognizes the system needs to change, that wealth alone isn't the answer, and that he must change personally including sharing wealth. He suggests critics don't want inequality discussed because it's a real problem, and states the hypocrisy issue can be addressed incrementally.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur born in 1946, transformed human genome mapping into a competitive race, drawing criticism from the scientific community. After serving as a medical orderly during the Vietnam War's Tet offensive, he developed a sense of urgency about time. Working at the NIH in the 1980s, he pioneered faster gene sequencing methods by focusing on messenger RNA rather than entire genomes, though this approach was dismissed by some, including James Watson. Following funding rejection, Venter left the NIH in 1992 to establish a private research institute. In 1995, he sequenced the first complete genome of a free-living organism. In 1998, he founded Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in three years, competing with a public project; both published results in 2001. His approach to data access drew criticism but brought financial success. In 2006, he formed the J. Craig Venter Institute, which after over a decade created Synthia, the first synthetic life form, published in Science journal. He has also conducted ocean expeditions on his yacht to sequence marine microbial genomes. Venter believes synthetic microbes could create a new industrial revolution, helping reduce oil dependence and capture carbon dioxide.

A survey of approximately 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches tried foods at school they hadn't tried at home, with half of parents reporting their children requested these foods be cooked at home. The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, involved 628 parents whose children ate school lunches. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were least popular. The study was conducted after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents provided packed lunches believing their children were too fussy. Officials noted that school meals, which must comply with strict nutritional guidelines, can help children try new foods through peer pressure and desire to fit in. About 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, slightly more than secondary schools, while Scotland has about 46% participation.

Alvaro Morata, 23, is returning to Real Madrid from Juventus through a buy-back clause worth up to 30m euros (£23m). The Spanish striker, currently playing at Euro 2016 where he has scored three goals, originally joined Juventus from Real in 2014 after four seasons with the Spanish club. During his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in consecutive Champions League finals in 2014 and 2015. He had previously been linked with moves to Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, returned to Championship club Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He was released in May and has been without a team since. During his second stint at the City Ground, he made 51 appearances, having previously spent four seasons there before joining Celtic. His career also includes spells at Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles private equity firm run by Ron Burkle. Fresh & Easy operates 200 stores across California, Nevada and Arizona and has lost money since opening in 2007. Under the deal, around 4,000 of 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, with approximately 50 stores closing. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m and the disposal will cost £150m, though Tesco retains an option to buy back a stake if the business becomes profitable. In April, Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years.
A martial artist initially faced racial abuse but overcame it. After briefly considering representing France, he is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Research presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting shows that French Alps glaciers have shrunk significantly over the past 40 years. Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie and colleagues created a new inventory of roughly 600 glaciers across several massifs including Mont Blanc, using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs with manual verification. The study found that glacial coverage decreased from approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s, representing an average loss of 26%. The retreat is not uniform, with southern sectors experiencing greater losses than northern areas. In the Belledonne Massif, glaciers have almost completely disappeared, while retreat in the Ecrins Massif is more than three times stronger than in Mont Blanc. Researchers attribute the difference to lower elevations in the south and varying climatic conditions, with the north receiving more precipitation and cloud cover. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc, has decreased slightly from 31.5 sq km to just over 30 sq km.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with victory nearly securing their place at next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Both teams are unbeaten, with Iceland ranked 20th in the world, one place above Scotland. Forward Jane Evans, 24, who plays for Bayern Munich, expressed that missing out would be "devastating" after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the 2014 World Cup. With the best six of eight group runners-up also qualifying automatically, Scotland are well-positioned to reach the finals without needing a play-off. Evans recently won the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern and believes having 12 players from the 20-strong squad playing abroad, including in top leagues in England, Germany, Sweden, and the United States, benefits the national team as they pursue their first major finals appearance.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger who runs Wings Over Scotland and campaigns for Scottish independence, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in her 30s in south London. She alleged harassment over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail until mid-September, stated the complaint concerned tweets from his Twitter account, which remain publicly visible and are not threatening. He criticized media coverage for using innuendo to encourage speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) wants Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish-based alternative called "A Happy Plaice," arguing the current mascot evokes images of cruelty to animals. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned by Great Northern Railway in 1908 for 12 guineas with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing" and has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Peta claims the mascot represents fish being tricked into impaling themselves and animals crushed in nets, and suggests the change would rebrand Skegness as a progressive destination not celebrating the mutilation and killing of sea animals. Skegness mayor Carl Macey said the Jolly Fisherman is loved by adults and children, has never portrayed animal cruelty, and is accepted as happy and friendly. While the suggestion will go before council, the mayor indicated there would likely be little support for removing Jolly.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, winning 43-16. Georgia opened the scoring through scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze's try, but Scotland responded with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try (with Georgian lock Kote Mikautadze sin-binned for illegally stopping a maul), Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Scotland dominated possession with 91% in the first 30 minutes. Hamish Watson scored early in the second half to extend the lead to 38-11.
