Georgia fought back with Lobzhanidze's second try from a powerful scrum, and Scotland's Moray Low received a yellow card for scrum infringements. Hogg completed his second try late in the match following good work from substitutes Ali Price and Rory Hughes. Scotland head coach Vern Cotter praised his team's first-half performance and game management, particularly highlighting captain Greig Laidlaw's leadership.

Widnes defeated Castleford in a rugby league match, winning 38-30 after building a 38-12 lead. Widnes scored tries through Leuluai, Ah Van (2), Bridge, White (2), and Mellor, leading 14-6 at half-time. Castleford's Flynn scored a hat-trick against his parent club (he is on loan at Castleford from Widnes), with Patrick and Gale also scoring. Despite Castleford scoring three tries in four minutes late in the match, Widnes held on for victory. The win moved Widnes to seventh place, above Wakefield, while Castleford remained sixth, one point ahead of Widnes. It was Castleford's fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from Guantanamo Bay detention facility after a US review panel determined he was not a continuing significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies, claiming he traveled to the region to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. He challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. The Kuwaiti government had advocated for his release, and he now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release reduces the total number of Guantanamo inmates to 148. He is the first detainee freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl.

PPAP (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) is a viral song performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The minute-long song features simple, repetitive lyrics about fusing a pen with an apple and a pineapple, accompanied by a basic dance routine. Originally uploaded to YouTube, the video gained over 4 million views, while a Facebook version by 9GAG reached over 44 million views. The song's viral success is attributed to its addictive beat, silly lyrics, and simple choreography. Reactions have been mixed, with some finding it catchy and amusing while others find it annoying. The phenomenon has spawned numerous tributes and covers from various performers, including Japanese stars and international social media personalities. Despite international attention, mainstream Japanese news sites have given it limited coverage, and it hasn't significantly trended on Japanese social media. Some suggest it was deliberately designed to become a global phenomenon similar to Psy's viral success.

Thousands attended Anzac Day commemorations in London, including an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade of up to 400 people before wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, with another service held at Westminster Abbey. Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The commemorations have been held in London since 1916, when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service a year after the Gallipoli landings. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer addressed crowds, reflecting on the courage of Anzac troops at Gallipoli. The events honor the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand servicemen and women in all wars, with veterans, service personnel, families, and expatriates participating. The Gallipoli campaign was an eight-month allied operation attempting to force the Ottoman empire out of World War One and was one of the war's bloodiest battles.

Clarkson, 30, has joined St Mirren and could debut against Alloa on Saturday in the Championship. He previously scored nine goals at Dundee last season but has mainly been a substitute this term at Motherwell, where he rejoined in July. Clarkson, who has two Scotland caps and nearly 400 senior club appearances, says he has maintained his fitness through U20 games and training. St Mirren are eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom-placed Alloa, and Clarkson hopes to help the club win games and climb the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Following concerns about workers' pension schemes under new ownership, Unite union received guarantees that all current agreements would be honoured. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme closed in 2004, and the current alternative pension scheme remains unaffected by the takeover. Boparan Private Office confirmed existing pension arrangements will continue. The new owner plans to restore Bernard Matthews' profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and expanding production capacity to process chicken alongside turkeys.

The council is offering free ferry crossings at Cowes until 2 July following numerous problems with a new chain ferry vessel. Since its late launch on 14 May, the ferry has experienced breakdowns, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and damaged cars during boarding. Council leader Dave Stewart acknowledged the "frustrating and disappointing start" and ordered an auditor review of the project. Local businesses report significant trade losses, with one shopkeeper questioning whether she will survive after nearly six months of lost revenue and requesting compensation. The transport councillor defended the vessel as a prototype with expected teething problems, stating that electrical issues have been fixed, ramp extensions are being manufactured to prevent vehicle damage, and seamanship problems causing groundings have been resolved. Compensation for affected businesses is under discussion.

The House of Lords European Union Committee warns that Britain's fishing industry, despite voting heavily for Brexit, risks being marginalized in negotiations due to contributing only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 fishers. The report notes that most commercial fish stocks are in shared UK-EU waters, and Britain may need to grant EU boats access to UK waters in exchange for tariff-free market access, since most UK fish are exported to the EU. While the Common Fisheries Policy has been unpopular with the industry, the Lords recommend retaining some CFP elements, including science-based quotas and international cooperation. The report raises concerns about potential fragmentation into four separate UK fisheries regimes post-Brexit. However, fishing industry representatives remain optimistic, viewing Brexit as an opportunity for greater control over UK waters and fairer quota distribution.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting indecent images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014, mostly of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a sex offenders programme. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching register after the panel determined his conduct was fundamentally incompatible with being a registered teacher. The panel cited the lengthy duration of offending, volume of images, pattern of behaviour, and lack of remedial action as indicating a strong likelihood of recurring behaviour. He was found unfit to teach and prohibited from re-registering for two years. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, did not attend the hearing.

Firefighters responded to a fire on 2 March at a waste site in Duncan Street operated by Asset and Land Group for Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. Following the fire, the Environment Agency suspended and later revoked the company's environmental permit, preventing it from accepting waste and requiring removal of all waste from the site by 7 August, subject to appeal. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the premises nine times in the previous year and found the operators broadly compliant with fire safety law, though they raised concerns to the EA in February about potential fire impacts on residents, transport and the environment, leading to joint inspections and enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed a Wednesday deadline to surrender its chemical weapons stockpile, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stating that a weapons shipment came under attack twice by terrorist groups while traveling from Damascus to Latakia port. Only about 4% of Syria's 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons have left the country so far. Al-Mekdad rejected US criticism of government barrel bomb use in Aleppo, where the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports 246 people killed in five days, though Syria denies targeting civilians. The Syrian government also disputed reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, which reportedly holds at least 3,000 detainees, though fighting continues. Syria maintains it is committed to destroying all chemical weapons by the June deadline despite security challenges slowing the process.

England defeated Pakistan by 330 runs at Old Trafford to level the series, with a day to spare. England declared on 589-8 and 173-1, while Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second, also taking four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance at number three, calling it extraordinary. Pakistan batted for only 63 and 70 overs respectively on a pitch offering little assistance to bowlers. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledged the disappointment and lack of confidence, noting poor shot selection cost his team. The third Test begins at Edgbaston on 3 August.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is launching a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families and friends to share their experiences, which will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner has observed both positive impacts of high quality care and unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales, having received increasing correspondence about these issues. The review will examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships and care home environments, with input from residents, care providers, staff and public bodies. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft supports the review's aims but expressed disappointment that no provider expert with direct care home experience is included on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, 39, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen after serving as player-manager at Arbroath since 2010. Aberdeen manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin following a comprehensive process, with Arbroath chairman John Christison understanding Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin, a former Aberdeen midfielder who played for several Scottish clubs and in Sweden, won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s and led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title in 2011. Arbroath were relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013-14.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the club's first choice for permanent appointment. Curtis warns that avoiding relegation is crucial, as the Championship has strengthened and returning to the Premier League is not guaranteed, noting Swansea may struggle to retain top players unlike clubs like Newcastle. The former player believes Swansea has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure after successful spells under Martinez, Rodgers and Laudrup, with constant managerial changes diluting the "Swansea Way." Curtis, who experienced the club's rise from near-bankruptcy and potential Football League relegation in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, believes the current squad is capable of survival and ensures new signings understand the club's history and the importance of maintaining top-flight status.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping by turning it into a competitive race, though this brought criticism from the scientific community. Born in 1946, he initially pursued surfing but was drafted to Vietnam in 1967, where his experience as a hospital orderly inspired him to become a doctor and instilled a sense of urgency. During his research career at the NIH in the 1980s, he pioneered faster gene sequencing methods by focusing on messenger RNA rather than entire genomes, achieving unprecedented rates. After leaving the NIH in 1992 due to criticism and funding issues, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research and in 1995 sequenced the first complete genome of a free-living organism. In 1998, he formed Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in three years, competing with a public 10-year project; both published results in 2001. His approach, particularly regarding data access, drew criticism but brought financial success. He subsequently founded the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006, leading efforts to create synthetic life, resulting in an organism called Synthia published in Science after over a decade of work. He has also conducted ocean expeditions to sequence marine microbial genomes and believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industry by reducing oil dependence and capturing carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. Fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships are at level three (A-level equivalent), with over half below this level and three-quarters aimed at those over 25, many already employed. Only 20% of English employers offer apprenticeships compared to 51% in Germany, and England has 18,000 different vocational qualifications versus Germany's 330. The report calls for expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts annually, with most at level three or higher lasting at least three years, and limiting level two courses to 10%. The Sutton Trust chairman criticizes the "complicated patchwork" system and "cruel deception" about apprenticeship expansion. The Department for Education states it is reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, while the Association of Colleges notes some level two apprenticeships are industry-respected and warns that creating 300,000 places would be challenging given existing shortages for 16-year-olds.

The Briton won a cycling time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. The 37-year-old Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals across swimming and cycling, secured her 16th world title and can win a 17th in Saturday's road race. She has won 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals across six Paralympics, including four golds at London 2012, and is targeting success at the 2016 Rio Paralympics. Storey started in swimming at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

The Bulls have been expelled from the Conference following failure to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff and other clubs. The Conference extended the payment deadline four times from 5 June to 12 June, but new owner Tommy Agombar, who took over last week, could not meet the final deadline. Chester, who were relegated on the final day of the season when Hereford scored a late winner at Aldershot, have been reinstated to the Conference Premier. The club still owes over £70,000 in PAYE tax to HMRC, with total debts of approximately £225,000. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for £1, but this was rejected in favor of other bidders. Declining attendances since relegation from the Football League in 2012 have worsened the financial situation, with average gates falling from 3,270 to 1,758.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his 2009 debut. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner described the decision as common sense and wished success to manager Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters. He also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances from 2004, and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifying.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a several-month illness. A leading figure in the early-music movement, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it across six continents for 30 years and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah was named among the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held positions including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, along with academic roles at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Colleagues remembered him for his extraordinary generosity, his role as a founder of the historically informed music movement, and his influence on musicians worldwide. A private funeral will be held, with a memorial service planned for later.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream school in June because he was not coping. His parents requested a special school place but were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timeframe for availability. His mother had to quit her job to care for him, and he struggles with the isolation of not attending school like his siblings. The family has now been told an extra classroom assistant has been hired and their son may start at a local special school within weeks. However, the mother worries other families will face the same situation due to special needs schools operating at capacity. The Education Authority stated they are reviewing special school provision in Northern Ireland, with work ongoing to ensure places are available closer to where children live, designed to assist with placements from 2016.

Newport County AFC chairman Gavin Foxall has stated the club expects its lease at Rodney Parade to be honoured until 2023, despite the Welsh Rugby Union's takeover bid for fellow tenants Newport Gwent Dragons. The WRU views Rodney Parade "as a rugby venue" and intends to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. County has primacy of fixtures at the venue while in the Football League under their 10-year lease agreed in 2013 after promotion from the Conference. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirmed County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements, and the WRU has been informed. The WRU takeover vote is scheduled for 9 May. On sporting matters, County sits two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left after six wins in their last ten matches under caretaker manager Mike Flynn. Foxall described potential relegation to the National League as "devastating" for fans and the city.

The passage describes a Sierra Leonean man's journey from child soldier to Ebola response volunteer. Kidnapped by RUF rebels at 15 during the 1991 civil war, he was branded, forced to fight under drug influence, and witnessed extreme violence. After escaping to Freetown, he was jailed for pick-pocketing but was rehabilitated by preacher Richard Cole through the Lifeline Nehemiah project, which encouraged education and nation-building. When Ebola struck Sierra Leone in 2014, he led response efforts including educating over 10,000 people in local languages about the disease, distributing food to 11,000 people, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit with community support. A pregnant woman with suspected Ebola was a catalyst for creating the treatment clinic. The country was recently declared Ebola-free after the virus killed almost 4,000 people over 18 months. He now focuses on investing in young people to build the future.

About 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs from the Wedgwood collection faced auction to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt after Waterford Wedgwood plc collapsed in 2009 and the Wedgwood Museum went into administration in 2010. A public fundraising campaign launched in September reached its target within a month. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it to the Wedgwood Museum, where it will remain on display in Barlaston, Staffordshire. A 2011 high court ruling had permitted the sale to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

Dan Groves stated that details of a deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town football club have not yet been released. According to The Sun, the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay currently sit eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from the play-offs. Wright, who finished second on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who indicated willingness to invest £10,000 weekly, and signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, announced he would extend his term by one year until 2019, rather than leaving in 2018 as originally planned or staying until 2021 as many expected. The decision was primarily driven by personal family circumstances - his daughters will be finishing A-levels and GCSEs in 2018, making it an ideal time for the family to return to Canada. While Carney recognized the professional challenge of leaving during Brexit negotiations and wanted to avoid departing in the middle of Britain's EU exit process, he could only commit to one additional year beyond 2018 since his family would be returning to Canada as originally scheduled. He stated the decision was entirely personal, dismissing any suggestions of political pressure or disillusionment with Brexit's economic outlook. By 2019, the Article 50 process should be complete, allowing a new Governor to manage Britain's subsequent economic direction.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso's chip found Jamille Matt, who scored from three yards. Colchester equalized from a corner after 17 minutes through Kurtis Guthrie following a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made crucial saves, including denying George Elokobi before half-time, while Guthrie hit the bar from two yards. Tom Aldred missed a chance to win it for Blackpool, heading wide from eight yards with 15 minutes remaining. Colchester's Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, teaches P6 and P7 pupils how to cope with change, particularly the transition to secondary school and transfer test stress. After a pilot in five schools, the charity hopes for wider rollout across Northern Ireland. The programme consists of interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing awareness, encourage help-seeking, identify support sources, and provide teacher training. Launched at Carrick Primary School in Lurgan, the initiative addresses anxiety in pupils and parents about moving from the close-knit primary environment to larger secondary schools. Around 14,681 pupils sat unofficial transfer tests in 2016, a slight increase from 2015. Workshops teach breathing exercises and relaxation techniques. Northern Ireland's chief inspector of schools has identified strengthening young people's resilience as a key challenge, noting that the social context of children's lives has changed significantly and recommending stronger preventative education within the pastoral care curriculum.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as the centrepiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971 on Southampton Water's western side, closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation and could power one million homes. The 300-acre site was sold to developers in 2016, with plans showing a petal-shaped glass structure surrounded by a marina, housing, restaurants, and ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 198-metre chimney will be retained rather than demolished, with outline planning permission expected later this year and construction potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong Track Cycling World Championships, 23-year-old Latham won bronze in the men's scratch race, securing GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver. He finished behind Poland's Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Germany's Lucass Liss (silver). GB's men's team pursuit lost the bronze medal to Italy, while the women's team pursuit finished fifth and missed the bronze-medal ride. Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was knocked out in the first round of the women's sprint, though she has two more events scheduled. The young women's pursuit team, with an average age of 19, showed promise despite not medaling at their first World Championships.

Ross Kemp will return to EastEnders to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell for a brief period. The return comes as Dame Barbara Windsor's character Peggy Mitchell, who reappeared on Friday after leaving in 2010, will be killed off from cancer in spring episodes. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, said he couldn't turn down the opportunity to appear in Barbara's final episodes, describing her as a close friend. The storyline will reunite the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil (Steve McFadden), with their mother for the last time. Grant Mitchell, who originally appeared from 1990-1999 and briefly in 2005-2006, was involved in major storylines including an affair with his brother's wife Kathy and other family dramas. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins described the reunion as an opportunity to showcase both actors at their best.

Tottenham manager Pochettino criticized his team's performance after losing to Liverpool, with Sadio Mane scoring twice in 138 seconds. Pochettino stated his side showed a "lack of desire" and were "not ready to fight for the Premier League" in the first half, particularly struggling to cope with pressure. Second-placed Spurs have won only twice away since September, with just one victory in their past 17 away matches against top-six rivals. The defeat could allow Chelsea to extend their lead to 12 points if they win their next match. Former player Danny Murphy noted Spurs' defensive struggles and suggested they should have used a back three formation instead of four against top opposition.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in Saturday's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election last month to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, won only eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The party lost key northern states including Katsina and Kaduna for the first time, though it retained Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections saw 66 violent incidents at polling stations. The PDP's decline follows defections of governors and MPs to the APC, widespread corruption allegations, and criticism over its handling of the Boko Haram insurgency in the north-east. The results relegate the once-powerful PDP to a regional party, while the APC made historic gains with national spread.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19-22 July) will feature an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access videos and band interviews through their phones and tablets by scanning signs and posters on site. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. The app will be updated before and during the event, enabling both attendees and people worldwide to access festival information, purchase tickets, and experience the festival atmosphere remotely.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, potentially removing Park View Educational Trust from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. The schools were among 21 investigated following allegations of a hardline Muslim takeover plot. An anonymous head teacher from one school said parents tried to undermine her authority and she felt isolated from 2012 until the Trojan Horse letter emerged. Education minister Lord Nash cited deep concerns about how Park View was run, including failure to promote pupils' development and issues with discrimination and equality. Ofsted's report found Park View's safeguarding inadequate, noting external speakers weren't properly vetted and a guest with extremist views had addressed students. Sir Michael Wilshaw said a culture of fear and intimidation had taken grip in Birmingham schools through an organized campaign to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. Lord Nash demanded Oldknow and Golden Hillock end unfavorable treatment of non-Muslims, cease gender segregation, and ensure a broader curriculum. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School, the only local authority school in special measures, to install a temporary governing board. Parents criticized the Ofsted reports, claiming inspectors showed bias and came with loaded questions.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 38, was sentenced to five years in prison in September for allegedly plotting to topple the Iranian government, though the charges have not been disclosed. She was arrested at Tehran Airport last April and has spent time in solitary confinement. Her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran with grandparents after the government confiscated her passport. An appeal hearing is being held in Tehran on Wednesday, which her husband Richard Ratcliffe describes as a "secret trial" that the family cannot attend. He believes his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in a diplomatic dispute between Iran and the UK. The appeal outcome is unpredictable and could result in her sentence being quashed, reduced, or increased. Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe has felt suicidal and started a hunger strike during imprisonment but has shown more resilience since being moved from solitary confinement over Christmas. Amnesty International UK considers her a "prisoner of conscience."

Vincent Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Optometrist Honey Rose, 35, is on trial at Ipswich Crown Court charged with gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution alleges Rose failed to detect Barker's swollen optic discs during the test and did not refer him for further investigation. A build-up of fluid in his brain increased pressure in his skull, leading to his death. The prosecution claims his death was preventable had Rose performed her job properly, and that her conduct fell so far below expected standards it was criminal.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, formerly of Guthrie near Forfar, was convicted of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity with a man he found through an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014, which he filmed. He sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014 and was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. After denying the charges, he was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court, which remitted the case to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers. The victim testified she felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. As a first offender assessed as posing "a moderate risk" of sexual re-offending, he was placed on the sex offenders register, with the judge stating the sentence must reflect society's abhorrence of such conduct.

Ireland lost to Afghanistan by 6 wickets in a T20 match in Greater Noida. Stuart Thompson scored 56, with contributions from Gary Wilson (41 not out) and captain William Porterfield (39), as Ireland posted 165-5. Afghanistan chased down the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs remaining, led by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Porterfield acknowledged Ireland fell short of their 180-run target and didn't execute well with the ball. Paceman Boyd Rankin missed the match due to a back problem but is expected to return for the ODI series starting March 15. The teams play again on Friday.

Barcelona paid an additional £11.2m to Spanish tax authorities regarding Neymar's transfer from Santos, though the club insists no offence was committed. The payment aims to cover potential interpretations of contracts in the signing. Barcelona originally paid £48.6m for the 22-year-old striker, with £34m going to his parents. Total costs including fees, wages, and this tax payment now reach £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating money related to the transfer and faces investigation. A Spanish judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer, with allegations the actual cost exceeded the reported 57m euros. Barcelona denies any tax crime but made the payment to protect its reputation despite believing the original payment was correct. No confirmation exists on whether the case will be dropped following the payment.

The bodies of British tourists David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand on 15 September. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, are being held as suspects and are alleged to have confessed to the killings, though reports suggest they have since withdrawn their confessions. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, and face potential death penalty. Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and are now returning to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about DNA sample verification and alleged mistreatment of suspects. Post-mortem examinations showed Mr Miller died from drowning and head trauma, while Ms Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police claim DNA found on Ms Witheridge matched the suspects' samples.

VR technology is increasingly being used beyond entertainment in fields like journalism, education, healthcare, and retail. The National Autistic Society and Alzheimer's Research UK created VR films to help people understand autism and dementia by simulating the experiences of those with these conditions. Retailers like Ikea use VR apps to let customers virtually explore products, with their kitchen app proving unexpectedly popular among gamers. In healthcare, VR is used for medical training, including live virtual surgeries that reached 5,000 viewers across 14 countries, and for treating conditions like PTSD and phobias, with one study showing 83% improvement in arachnophobia patients. Google Expeditions takes schoolchildren on virtual field trips to locations like the Great Barrier Reef and Mars, while other educational VR apps aim to improve language learning through immersive experiences. Chinese firm NetDragon is testing VR headsets that can detect student engagement by monitoring head movements. However, the high cost of VR hardware and computing power remains a significant barrier, particularly for schools with limited budgets.

The Su-24 jet's black box was opened in Moscow on Friday, with the head of the Russian investigation stating that flight information appeared to be missing. The jet was shot down by Turkish F-16 fighters on 24 November, killing the pilot and a Russian marine during rescue operations. Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings after entering its airspace, while Russia maintains it was shot down within Syrian airspace. The incident has severely damaged Russia-Turkey relations, with Russia imposing sanctions including a ban on package holidays. An analysis of the black box data is expected next week.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five qualifiers and needs victory against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday to virtually secure their place at the European Championships. Forward Jane Evans, 24, says missing out would be "devastating" after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the 2014 World Cup. Iceland, ranked 20th (one place above Scotland), are also unbeaten with four wins. The best six of eight group runners-up qualify automatically, putting Scotland in strong position to reach the Netherlands finals without a play-off. Evans recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich in her first season and is one of 12 players in the 20-strong squad playing outside Scotland. She believes having players in top leagues benefits the national team, with Germany's competitive environment improving her game through daily training with elite players.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found no simple solution to fix defects in the local taxation system. Professor Kenneth Gibb from the University of Glasgow examined different taxation systems worldwide and found that property taxes, used by almost all OECD countries, are considered a "good tax" by academics due to stability and difficulty to avoid, but generate confusion about whether they tax wealth or charge for services. Some view property tax as unfair because it's not linked to current income. Local income tax, while perceived as fairer, creates problems with fluctuating income for local authorities and limited ability to vary rates for local priorities. The review concluded that council tax has many deficiencies but reform is a major undertaking. The commission will hold public consultation across Scotland before publishing its autumn report. The Scottish government considers the current council tax system unfair and awaits the commission's findings.

Apple has extended its two-step verification system to iCloud after third-party software was allegedly used to steal celebrities' intimate photos. The security measure adds a four-digit code requirement (sent via text or Find My iPhone app) when accessing iCloud from new devices, even after entering username and password. Previously, this verification didn't apply to iCloud backups, allowing tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download complete data backups with just stolen passwords. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed his software was likely used in the recent hacks but acknowledged Apple's changes now prevent this method. Users receive a 14-character recovery key for account access if trusted devices are lost. However, the feature remains optional rather than default. Security experts suggest two-factor authentication should be mandatory, while concerns exist about users losing recovery keys or having them stolen. Apple's CEO stated the company plans to encourage stronger adoption of two-factor authentication and better passwords, emphasizing user awareness as a key responsibility.

UKIP won May's European election after spending £2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815. Labour came second, spending £1,027,339. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 but lost all but one of their MEPs. The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending equated to 68p per vote, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, and Lib Dems £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP spent £267,372. The six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087 in total. All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has joined a National League club after leaving Barrow by mutual consent and could face his former team on 18 February. The ex-Aldershot and Exeter player is described by manager Kevin Nicholson as a leader despite limited playing experience. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has also signed following a recommendation from Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating previously played for Irish clubs including Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps. The club sits four points above the relegation zone with one win in their last six matches.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed he suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The BHA's acting chief veterinary officer stated such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across all equestrian disciplines. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, causing overheating and wobbling, but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on Saturday. The Trevor Hemmings-owned gelding, ridden by Leighton Aspell, had previously won the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup. The report concluded he died from a rare haemorrhage, with no significant underlying health issues linked to his death.

The passage describes emotional farewell speeches at the Scottish Parliament from MSPs standing down before the May 5th election. Alex Salmond, former first minister (2007-2014), delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and praising the parliament's strengthened position, though he criticized the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling referendum campaign pledges. He concluded by calling service in parliament the greatest honor in public life, saying "it's goodbye from me... for now." Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, serving since 1999, warned Holyrood must improve accountability and scrutiny, suggesting it should learn from Westminster's committee system. Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also departed, joking about Finance Secretary John Swinney's "faux indignation." Presiding officer Tricia Marwick, also stepping down, was visibly moved to tears during the speeches, particularly after McNeil's and Salmond's addresses, thanking Salmond for serving "with distinction."

The live-action Beauty and the Beast film will star Emma Thompson as Mrs Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice, joining previously announced cast members Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May, with a US release date of 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service will announce its charging decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a meeting with victims' families. Ninety-six football fans died in the disaster at an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest on 15 April 1989. Following inquests that concluded fans were unlawfully killed, evidence files on 23 suspects were referred to the CPS in January. Fifteen cases relate to the disaster's causes, while eight concern police conduct investigations. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, said families want accountability and remain determined despite the long struggle.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages containing contraband being thrown over its walls. A local resident reported witnessing this four times in two weeks, and the prison has invited residents to discuss the issue. A former inmate described the jail as "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged that staff work hard to prevent contraband but admitted more needs to be done, with the Justice Secretary requesting a review of tools to tackle the problem. New laws allow for up to two years imprisonment for smuggling packages over prison walls. While the former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, the Ministry of Justice stated there was no evidence of drone activity at Chelmsford.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, admits hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot remember if the traffic lights were red or green. The prosecution states Wright failed to stop for a red light while Mrs Blackburn, wearing appropriate clothing and on duty for 20 years, was escorting a woman and child across the road after traffic lights turned red. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court, saying he has thought of nothing else since the incident. The sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into his eyes.

Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to veterinary medicine exams in May. The 24-year-old middle distance runner, who finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, is completing her final year at university. Despite being disappointed to miss competing for Scotland, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir believes she has at least two or three more Olympics ahead and is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March in Birmingham. She set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m in London, her fifth race in 10 days, and expressed satisfaction with her performance and future potential.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after walking home from a Christmas party. Gardaí began searching a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, in a process expected to take several weeks. A six-detective team reviewed the case earlier this year, enhancing CCTV footage that shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street, where he had returned to retrieve an umbrella. The same man was captured on CCTV following Deely on Haddington Road shortly after. Police released the footage in April and continue to appeal for the unidentified man to come forward.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after missing over two years due to injury and three wrist operations, defeated Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open. The 27-year-old former US Open champion and 2013 Wimbledon semi-finalist will face either Pouille or Young next. In other matches, 15th seed Kyrgios came from behind to beat Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-affected match and will play Lopez, who also recovered from two sets down against Fognini. Berdych and Tsonga recorded straight-set victories. Del Potro, Kyrgios, and Lopez are all in the same half of the draw as Murray.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against Caf during the 2015 tournament, but avoided disqualification by apologizing. The dispute stemmed from Tunisia's quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea, where they contested a controversial 90th-minute penalty that led to their 2-1 extra-time defeat. Tunisia's federation wrote a critical letter to Caf, prompting demands for an apology by 31 March 2015 or face exclusion. The federation clarified it never accused anyone of corruption but criticized the referee selection. Following a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, the matter was resolved.

Morocco was also initially banned from the 2017 qualifiers after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns and requesting a postponement. The Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned Caf's ban and reduced Morocco's fine from $1 million to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea replaced Morocco as host with only 64 days' preparation.

Both nations successfully entered the 2017 qualifying draw, with Tunisia drawn in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

McLaren, a team with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, has fallen from past greatness and now aims for fourth row grid positions and decent points. The slump began in 2013 with chassis design issues, and while the team has improved the car, problems now lie with the Honda power-unit. This contrasts sharply with their previous Honda partnership era, when they won 15 of 16 races in 1988 with Senna and Prost. Their last constructors' title was in 1998 with Hakkinen. They were excluded from the 2007 constructors' championship despite scoring the most points, due to possessing illegal Ferrari technical information and receiving a $100m fine. Another scandal in 2009 involved Hamilton and sporting director Ryan misleading stewards. McLaren's history shows cycles of triumph and decline since Bruce McLaren founded the team, with their first title in 1974. Ron Dennis, who took control in the 1980s and returned after the disastrous 2013 season, insists McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance. Alonso rejoined in 2015 believing the Honda partnership offered his best chance at a third title, but currently the team relies on belief that progress will deliver future championships.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police found people still present and till receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The defence acknowledged licensing laws were not adhered to and the premises operated improperly into the morning. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, noting O'Neill had an appalling record and expressing regret he couldn't impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, hitting eight three-pointers to surpass his previous mark of 272 set two years ago. He scored 45 points as the Golden State Warriors overcame a 13-point deficit to defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Klay Thompson added 26 points in the victory. In another game, Pau Gasol recorded 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls erased a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78, damaging Miami's playoff hopes with a 39-8 run to start the second half.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic participated in what they believed was a meeting with a competition winner at Melwood. The supposed winner, Dutch free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen, was actually a YouTube star who initially pretended to be a regular fan receiving a dead-ball masterclass. Van Velzen then surprised the players by demonstrating his exceptional free-kick abilities. Van Velzen, who has gained YouTube fame through videos of his free-kick skills, described the experience as amazing and enjoyed deceiving the players about his abilities before revealing his true talent.

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations found that women with BRCA1 mutations who had their ovaries removed after diagnosis reduced their risk of dying from breast cancer by 62 percent. The research showed a 20-year survival rate of 77.4 percent for the entire group, with those having the procedure within two years of diagnosis experiencing a 73 percent reduction in death compared to those who never had it. The protective effect lasted for 15 years and was particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. However, the benefit was not observed in women with BRCA2 mutations. Nine deaths from ovarian cancer occurred among women who did not have the procedure. Women carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations face a lifetime breast cancer risk of up to 70 percent and increased risk of ovarian tumors. The study suggests oophorectomy should be discussed as part of treatment for BRCA mutation carriers with early stage breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed when struck by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am on tracks owned by Norfolk-Southern. The train, Carolinian No. 80, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City carrying 166 passengers, none of whom were injured, though one passenger became ill during the delay. Both victims were pronounced dead at the scene. An acquaintance who met them while collecting scrap metal indicated they may have lived in a homeless camp. The train resumed its route after a delay of approximately two hours and 45 minutes.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellin cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of US citizenship. He became one of the DEA's most important unpaid assets, helping carry out undercover stings worldwide and aiding in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. After declining health forced his retirement, Toro faces deportation as he is technically living in the US illegally, with the DEA refusing to help him obtain citizenship after he went public with his situation. His final temporary visa expired January 1, he cannot collect social security benefits without a green card or passport, and he fears he would be killed within hours if returned to Colombia.

ICANN, the US internet address regulator, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices involving the new '.sucks' domain name. The company charges approximately $2,499 annually for celebrities and trademark holders to secure these domains, with purchased names including youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, and bankofamerica.sucks. Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift are among celebrities who have paid to remove their names from these domains. An advisory panel representing major companies has called this a 'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory,' particularly since Vox Populi plans to offer the domains to general consumers for just $10 annually starting in September. ICANN has contacted US and Canadian regulators to determine if the company's actions are illegal and may declare Vox Populi in breach of contract if violations are found.

A woman was arrested 27 years after her baby's body was found in a Sainsbury's bag floating on a Norfolk village pond in 1988. Police exhumed the body during a case review and used DNA from the leg bone to trace the mother through the national database by matching a relative and examining the family tree. The woman explained she had concealed her pregnancy from everyone and the baby was stillborn. She placed the body in the pond days before teenagers discovered it. Police ruled out foul play and dropped the infanticide charge, though she remains on bail for possible charges of failing to register a birth and preventing lawful burial. The baby, originally buried without a name after villagers raised funds for the funeral, was reburied and named Peter after the local church. A stillbirth support charity provided a new headstone.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from Young's moving taxi in 2010. Young mistakenly believed the 23-year-old passenger planned to avoid paying the fare and drove him back to the taxi rank instead of his destination. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving for almost a mile, prompting Hicks to jump from the vehicle traveling at over 20mph. The High Court ruled Young unlawfully imprisoned his passenger. Hicks, now 27, sustained devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The judge determined damages should be reduced by 50 percent from the family's request, expected to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both sides have permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final compensation amount.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as multiple storms produced reported twisters, including one about 6 miles northwest of Goddard near Wichita that moved northeast. Additional tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. A possible tornado also touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, with reports of wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and roof damage. Baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. More storms were forecast Thursday for the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes regions. Nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous and deadly.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to fight in a middleweight bout in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold is seeking his fourth consecutive win since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago and has a title shot in his sights. Rockhold plans to be aggressive, comparing himself to a bull against Machida's matador style, aiming to cut off the ring and force Machida to fight his fight. He believes he has advantages in wrestling, striking, and ground game, claiming Machida has limited paths to victory. Rockhold's last win was against Michael Bisping in November. Machida, coming off a victory against CB Dollaway, is confident he can win by applying his technique and strategy. Both fighters believe the winner deserves a title shot, and Machida reports having an eight-week training camp with quality sparring partners.

An aeroplane touched down on a runway at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida without deploying its landing gear, skidding along on its belly. The Aerostar plane's propellers ricocheted off the ground and the wings bounced from impact. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off. Despite the propellers being damaged from hitting the runway twice, the engines continued running and the pilot regained control. The 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, who has flown for almost 50 years, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale with his dog and landed safely. Gear-up landings are most commonly caused by human error when pilots forget to deploy landing gear, or by mechanical failure. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performances this season but pledged support for the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the campaign. Sportsmail revealed City will listen to offers for the Ivorian, who has two years remaining on a £220,000-a-week contract, as part of a squad overhaul. Pellegrini dismissed suggestions Toure needs rest and stated neither he nor the player are satisfied with his performances. City face West Ham on Sunday having taken just 18 points from the last 39 available, with defeat potentially allowing Liverpool to close within one point. Captain Vincent Kompany could miss the remainder of the season with a muscle injury. Goalkeeper Joe Hart said players must take responsibility for disappointing performances while maintaining support for Pellegrini. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce warned West Ham's Aaron Cresswell, linked with Chelsea and Manchester City, against making the same mistake as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who joined City but saw limited playing time.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive who lived in Britain for over 20 years under the name Marc Skinner, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. He was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of Cosa Nostra and lost his extradition battle in February. However, his case expired in October under Italian law, which states a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the penalty time has passed. The European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn, though the matter must still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore was arrested in August 2013 at his London home and was convicted in absentia for his role as a "man of honour" taking bribes from builders in Palermo. Legal experts criticized the waste of time and money on the case. The CPS admitted making an administrative error by failing to serve appeal papers on time in March 2014, which contributed to the delay that allowed the sentence to expire.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. The race will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One event, with his final day's rides to be confirmed Friday morning. McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February. The seven-runner field also includes Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter Marcia was raped and strangled to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. The 9-year-old's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, 150 yards from her home in a garage, sexually assaulted with a fractured neck bone and cookie money missing. Ritter's then-husband advised against viewing the body or crime scene photos, wanting to preserve memories of their living daughter. For decades Ritter declined to see the photos, but last year she insisted on viewing them with the lead investigator, seeing her daughter's swollen, blackened face and other injuries. The case remained Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA from Marcia's clothing matched his following his arrest for another 1975 murder. Barrett, who had been imprisoned for sex crimes between 1974 and 2002 except during the year Marcia disappeared, was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years at age 68.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable he won't win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, joining only five other players who have won all four major titles. The 25-year-old world number one has only one top-10 finish at Augusta in six appearances. He famously collapsed in the 2011 final round, blowing a four-shot lead with a closing 80, but considers it the most important day of his career as it taught him valuable lessons. He bounced back to win the US Open two months later and has since won four majors total. McIlroy's 2014 success came despite personal distractions including calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a costly legal dispute with his former management company. He views the golf course as his sanctuary from external pressures and looks forward to competing at Augusta.

This passage lists trending stories from a busy week, including: four rainbows photographed over New York after heavy rain; China cracking down on exotic dancers hired for wakes; Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview about his private life; a lip plumping trend inspired by Kylie Jenner involving sucking on jars; 102-year-old Alice Barker experiencing a time travel project with filmmakers; controversy over a bomb-referencing prom proposal accused of facing racist treatment; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp's appearance in the Black Mass trailer; and creative announcements including a Fresh Prince-themed pregnancy reveal and a military dad photobombing his son.

Hundreds of children were hospitalized in England last year after being born with brain damage from alcohol exposure in the womb. Official data shows 272 youngsters disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were admitted over 12 months, though experts warn actual numbers could be much higher. World Health Organisation research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies—approximately 7,500 yearly—could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems including deformed limbs from prenatal alcohol exposure. The condition is described as permanent and vastly under-diagnosed. Associated medical issues include liver, kidney and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Current government guidance advises pregnant women not to drink, or if they do, consume maximum two units no more than twice weekly, though some experts advocate for complete abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15. The masked McKerry burst into the store at 8pm wielding an axe and demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. Store owner Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him to the floor, and during the struggle, Dhillon's wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, forcing him to drop the weapon. Police arrived minutes later and arrested him. McKerry, who pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court, earned the nickname "boomerang boy" or "homing pigeon boy" in his youth because he always returned home after committing crimes. He began shoplifting at age 12 and by 15 had been arrested 80 times for various offenses including vehicle-taking, burglary, and stealing 22 charity boxes while dressed as a woman.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with gang rape of a woman at a party at a Canadian barracks and must remain in Nova Scotia until trial. The men - Joshua Finbow, 23, Craig Stoner, 24, Simon Radford, 31, and Darren Smalley, 35 - appeared in court in Dartmouth near Halifax and were granted bail exceeding £2,000 each. Their bail conditions require surrendering passports, living at Stadacona naval base in Halifax, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy while drawing their current pay. The sailors were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team at Shearwater naval base when the alleged assault occurred on April 10. The victim is a woman in her early 20s from Halifax. The men are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, offences carrying up to 14 years imprisonment. They must return to court on May 27 and are forbidden from contacting the victim and six witnesses or leaving Nova Scotia.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson from Las Vegas is one of only 70 people worldwide with Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that makes his skin appear red, inflamed, and scaly. His mother Valerie must apply creams to his body multiple times daily to prevent his skin from drying out. When RJ was born via emergency caesarean, his mother noticed a red rash on his chest that spread rapidly, and doctors initially couldn't diagnose the condition. After researching online, Mrs. Jackson found a Facebook group for Netherton's syndrome and confirmed her son's diagnosis. The family faces significant challenges, including cruel taunts from strangers, denial of entry to play facilities, and a police incident where armed officers surrounded them in a Walmart after a member of the public reported suspected child abuse, mistaking RJ's skin condition for burns. Despite the ignorance and bullying they encounter, Mrs. Jackson describes her son as a beautiful, bubbly boy who loves playing like any other child, though his condition causes him pain and requires constant care.

Transport for London is removing controversial Protein World 'beach body ready' advertisements from the London Underground featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield. The posters sparked backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, with a Change.org petition gathering over 50,000 signatures and the Advertising Standards Authority receiving more than 200 complaints. Several posters were defaced by protesters who objected to the perceived message that only women resembling the model are beach-ready. TfL confirmed removal after the three-week paid advertising period ended and stated they would consider customer reactions for future similar requests. Protein World defended the campaign on social media, claiming the unphotoshopped image promotes fitness and health. The company's head of marketing Richard Staveley told Good Morning Britain the brand aims to make the nation healthier, though he revealed the company received violent threats and a bomb threat under police investigation. A protest is planned for Hyde Park on May 2.

Rail firms are planning fare increases of up to 87 per cent, taking effect ten days after the general election, despite main party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western urgently review its decision to nearly double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route through his Witney constituency. Passengers from Charlbury station face an 87 per cent increase on off-peak returns to London, rising from £33.30 to £62.40 from May 17. Train companies can increase unregulated fares, which comprise about half their revenue, three times yearly. First Great Western claims the changes align the North Cotswolds route with other services and offers cheaper advance single tickets. Other significant increases include London Midlands and Virgin routes, with rises ranging from 22 to 24.5 per cent. Virgin states its overall West Coast fare increase is 1.65 per cent, below the industry average, with most hikes affecting Virgin-only fares that are already 20 per cent cheaper than rivals.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, was left permanently blind in one eye after thugs threw bricks at his Oldham home. Young and his wife Elaine, 54, were writing wedding thank-you cards three weeks after their marriage when attackers began pelting their front window with stones. When Young opened the door to confront them, he was struck in the left eye by a brick, causing an open forehead wound and serious eye injury. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. The retired HGV driver, who served with the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers during the Irish troubles, says he no longer feels safe in his home. Police have launched an investigation but report no apparent motive, suggesting it may have been yobs "messing around." The couple, who met 14 months ago, are now moving away due to fear.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension through the 2016 season following his return from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident in April that killed his father Keith. After undergoing ankle surgery, he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's exceptional character and tireless work in preparing for his return.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford has been declared cancer-free after battling neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs and bones. During treatment, he decorated his protective radiotherapy mask to look like a ninja turtle, which helped him feel stronger and braver. His story gained international attention, prompting Nickelodeon to send him ninja turtle presents. Over the course of a year, Harley underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant with complications, and radiotherapy at Christie Clinic in Manchester. His parents Oliver and Stacey received the diagnosis after taking him to a doctor for stomach pain. Harley will require regular check-ups to monitor for recurrence and has become the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids and Teens campaign while receiving one of their Little Star Awards for his bravery.

Tim Sherwood has advised 19-year-old Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Grealish, who impressed in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, is being pursued by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood wants Grealish to concentrate on securing his place in Villa's first team before making an international decision. The manager praised Grealish's confidence and dribbling ability, noting that he is not overawed by first-team football. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season and is currently split between the two countries. His father Kevin agreed that club football should be the priority.

The passage discusses landing fees charged to private jets at various airports worldwide. Private jet travel is a growing luxury industry, worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe. Landing fees vary dramatically by location, with Japanese airports charging the highest rates: Haneda Airport in Tokyo tops the list at £4,559, followed by Narita International Airport at £3,728 and Kansai International Airport in Osaka at £3,594. Other expensive airports include Toronto Pearson, Darwin in Australia, Bristol in England, and Dublin. The busiest periods for private jet travel coincide with major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with round-trip costs reaching tens of thousands of dollars. Popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her two dogs, Cooper (a Labrador) and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy took small licks, Cooper ate the entire cone in one bite. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, says Cooper always eats quickly, so she ensures Daisy eats first. The video has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized feeding dogs ice cream, but Gallegos defended the practice, stating Cooper is healthy and athletic, and noting her previous dog lived to 19 years old while having weekly ice cream treats. Daisy only gets occasional licks due to her smaller size. The dogs also visit Starbucks for "pup-uccinos," which contain only whipped cream.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year contract. The 41-year-old former Hearts boss joined as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer and became interim manager when Johnston left in early February. Locke has lost only once in seven matches since taking charge at Rugby Park.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, says her five-year-old autistic son Logan faced suspension threats from Seminole County Elementary School for wearing essential oils from doTERRA. Kemp applies the oils to his head and neck, believing they help keep him calm and focused. School officials claimed the oils smelled and distracted other students, though Kemp says Logan had been using them all year until a teacher's aide complained. She received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. Kemp questioned why natural oils were prohibited while chemical medications would be acceptable. On Thursday, Lake County School District stated they would not suspend Logan, calling it a health issue. The family uses lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood scented oils.

A fire destroyed 90 condos at the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday at 3 pm. Twelve fire teams responded but could not enter the summer homes, and the building eventually collapsed. The blaze was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings and smoke was visible from three miles away. The cause is unknown, though investigators are examining claims it started near a parked car. Building manager Rob Taber, who lived and worked there, lost everything. The complex operates as holiday homes between May and November.

The Queen, aged 88 and approaching her 89th birthday, was spotted riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park accompanied by a groom. She rode without a helmet, wearing a silk scarf instead, reportedly due to concerns about her hairstyle. The Queen has been an equine enthusiast since receiving her first Shetland pony, Peggy, at age four and has owned numerous horses throughout her life. Though she has reduced riding in recent years due to a knee injury that also ended her horseback participation in Trooping the Colour, she remains actively involved with her horses and breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral. Some of her horses are now ridden by her grandchildren, Lady Louise and James, Viscount Severn. Fell ponies are an ancient British breed from Cumbria, dating to the Neolithic period, known for being docile, hardy, and typically black, grey, or bay in color, standing 13-14 hands high.

A 55-year-old Brisbane man, Leon Yeaman, died after being punched by his 28-year-old neighbour Phillip Pama during a dispute over noise levels on Thursday night. Yeaman was making noise in his yard around 9 pm while Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift, was trying to sleep. Pama's lawyer stated Yeaman was known for getting drunk and playing loud music. During the confrontation, Pama allegedly struck Yeaman once in the head, killing him. Paramedics pronounced Yeaman dead at the scene around 11 pm. Pama has been charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail, including passport surrender, curfew, and twice-weekly police reporting. He has no history of violence and was reportedly devastated. The case returns to court May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, who had ended their relationship for a classmate. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) and instructed that the boy's arms and legs be broken and his kidneys damaged so he would slowly bleed to death, after which she wanted to "finish him together" with the killer. Police conducted a sting operation using an undercover officer posing as a hitman, filming the exchange with a hidden camera. After Simonova handed over expense money, she was arrested in her car. She faces 15 years in prison on attempted murder charges. The teacher had previously showered the student with gifts and money during their year-long relationship.

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea football manager, revealed he prays and speaks to God daily but never about football and doesn't discuss the game with his wife. He attends church when he feels the need, particularly when in Portugal. Mourinho has worked as an ambassador against hunger with the World Food Programme and tries to separate his professional and family life. He claims to be a good family person and friend despite his competitive professional persona. Chelsea are currently top of the league. Earlier this season, Mourinho was fined £25,000 for claiming there was a campaign against Chelsea after Cesc Fabregas was booked for diving.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, returned to the show on April 1 for the first time in eight years.
