The 91-year-old handled the first price-guessing game before turning hosting duties over to current host Drew Carey, who took over the show in 2007.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested at 12:30 am Friday in Washington D.C. and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property after allegedly trying to break into a house on D Street SE. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the foreign missions branch, which works with the State Department on diplomatic activities. His arrest follows another Secret Service supervisor being placed on leave two days earlier for alleged misconduct under police investigation. These incidents add to ongoing problems for the agency, including a separate investigation by the Homeland Security Inspector General into two high-ranking officials accused of driving into a secure White House area after drinking on March 4.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, left his car at a safari park to photograph a male lion from approximately 10 feet away, armed only with a camera. The camera's shutter sound alerted the lion, which aggressively jumped towards him, forcing Saeed to quickly retreat to his car. While he laughed at the time, he later reflected that he wouldn't attempt such a close encounter again.

New York City police are seeking to identify a woman who died on a Brooklyn street on March 22. The woman, estimated to be 25-45 years old, was found unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend and could not be revived by paramedics. She had no identification but had a distinctive faded tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" on a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. Police have released images of the tattoo and are awaiting a medical examiner's report on the cause of death. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 without money to buy property. The year-and-a-half project involved welding a steel frame and constructing a wood and steel structure. They drove the completed truck home to their purchased lot in Nelson, New Zealand, where they now live nearly self-sufficiently. The solar-powered home cost approximately $25,000, with their first power bill only $25. Water comes from a nearby spring, while the stove and hot water are gas-powered. The home features cypress wood interiors, a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, a main bedroom, and a loft. The couple and their cat are surrounded by trees and a babbling brook, and they plan to build another similar home in the future.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year scored significantly higher on early literacy tests than peers with no iPads or individual devices. Shared iPad students scored approximately 30 points higher than the other groups. The study involved 352 students at a midwestern suburban school district. Blackwell suggests the collaborative learning around the technology, rather than collaboration alone, made the difference, and recommends schools reconsider how tablets are used in earlier grades to maximize effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters. The animal, belonging to farmer Ms Duan, was discovered to be missing its hind legs when feeding with its litter. Despite its disability, the piglet has mastered balancing on two legs, wobbling while foraging for food with its snout to the ground, though it comes close to tipping over at times. Villagers have flocked to see the animal since its birth. This follows a similar case in China where a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo became a star attraction after learning to walk on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car on lap 25 during a pit stop for tires and fuel. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, received stitches for a leg cut, and was released. Many cars experienced traction issues due to hours of rain before the race. Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

A 32-year-old man murdered his 29-year-old dancer wife in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, captured on CCTV footage. He dragged her into their apartment garden, smashed her head into concrete paving 11 times, punched her 10 times, then shot her in the face five times at point-blank range. The couple had been married only four days when neighbors heard him accusing her of being unfaithful. After the killing, he stole a neighbor's car but was arrested following a crash. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle. He confessed to the murder, stating he was jealous of men looking at his wife, who performed with a dance group. He faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, 41-year-old journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her struggle with mental illness and suicidal thoughts. She explained that anxiety led her to a point where she couldn't see the purpose of continuing her life. A combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family contributed to her feeling isolated, particularly as she hadn't married or had children. Wilson described feeling alone without a way out. Though she struggled in her younger years, feeling like she'd "missed out on a guide book to life" while watching others cope, she has recently found some peace. She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and calls anxiety the "new depression." Beyond Blue reports one in three Australian women experience anxiety in their lifetime, with the two conditions often leading to one another.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant Portland woman, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar when she found her using heroin in her bathroom. The ex-girlfriend refused to leave when asked. Prosecutors dropped the charge in 2015 because Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage," and Oregon law permits physical force against intruders who refuse to leave. Curtin's attorney stated the ex-girlfriend had harassed Curtin for two years and attempted to pull the boyfriend back into addiction. The boyfriend, father of Curtin's child, had struggled with heroin and shares a five-year-old with his ex. Curtin gave birth in January and now lives with her parents; the boyfriend is not involved with the new child. A conviction would have resulted in nearly six years in prison.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner who slipped a broccoli spear into the mix. The dog immediately showed disgust upon biting the vegetable and spit it out on the floor. She lives with two children, and there is concern they might imitate her dislike of vegetables. Other videos show Gemma sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologised after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic site. The link was originally for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was discontinued in 2011. After the awards ended, organisers allowed the website registration to expire, and a porn site subsequently took over the address. HSBC removed the hyperlink after discovering the error and stated it had no association with the external site. The bank confirmed its website remained secure despite the incident.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 after fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home on Sunday morning, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call shortly before 7 am, Marcus remained calm, provided firefighters with directions to their location, comforted his sister who feared they would die, and informed the dispatcher that his older brother, mother, and step-father were also in the home. Prince George's County firefighters rescued both children by entering through the home and breaking a window, with one firefighter giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while the three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae has lit up Australia's east coast, with images captured at Jervis Bay on the NSW south coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson documented the neon glow caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The phenomenon is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, typically due to natural causes. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, this carnivorous cell preys on diatoms and produces the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, with experts confirming there is no cause for concern.

Breast cancer patients may avoid chemotherapy through new genetic tests that analyze tumor cells after surgery to determine cancer aggressiveness and recurrence risk. The tests, such as EndoPredict, can identify women with recurrence risks as low as five percent within days, comparable to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. While most breast cancer patients routinely receive chemotherapy after tumor removal despite severe side effects including hair loss, nausea, and fatigue, experts believe many women may not need it. The tests cost approximately £2,500 and are mainly available privately, though specialists hope for NHS adoption, arguing costs would be offset by chemotherapy savings. Surgeons note the tests enable informed patient decisions rather than routine chemotherapy for nearly all patients.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over nine years, with HMS Ocean accounting for five emergency evacuations. At least 18 other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict 'no touching' rule exists at sea, suggesting women conceived before boarding or during leave. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, comprising around 9 percent of personnel in 2014. Additionally, 99 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between January 2006 and December 2013 after discovering they were pregnant, with a further 102 evacuated from Iraq. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence on Wednesday. The 50-centimeter drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, though the amount poses no immediate harm to humans. The discovery occurred the same day a court approved restarting two nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant, over four years after the Fukushima disaster. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed concerns about potential terrorism using drones at future events like the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drones near airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Abe was in Indonesia at the time, and police are investigating the drone's origin.

A security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother suffering from Alzheimer's to work with him daily on his motorbike. Lu Xincai began this routine after his father died earlier this year, as his wife works in another city and his son is in school, leaving no one to care for her. His mother previously got lost while collecting firewood in the mountains. Each morning at 5 am, he secures her on his motorbike with a sash around both their waists and rides slowly for an hour to cover the four kilometers to work. His employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother, and he regularly checks on her to ensure she hasn't wandered off. Lu says his mother devoted her life to caring for her children, and he now feels duty-bound to care for her in return.

A major study found that heavy drinking among Americans increased 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, with binge drinking also rising, particularly among women. Women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times faster than men's nationwide during this period. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers, with significant county-level variations. About 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010, with excessive drinking costs estimated at over $220 billion annually. Researchers attribute the increases to changing social norms making drinking more acceptable for women, decreased real costs of alcohol, increased advertising, weakened alcohol control policies, and demographic factors like affluent young professionals in certain areas. The study analyzed data from approximately 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting women and babies at risk. The World Health Organisation states the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections, complications, disability, or death. Over a quarter of women in England now have caesareans, more than double the rate since the early 1990s. WHO recommends rates should ideally be between 10-15 percent. The procedure costs the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for natural birth. This contradicts current NHS guidelines that allow caesareans for women anxious about childbirth or with certain medical conditions. Research shows up to one in ten caesareans cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17 after breaking into an $800,000 summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, where she lived for at least a week. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her sitting in his living room, and when confronted, she claimed to own the house before fleeing in a pickup truck. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket and arrested Filkins hours later when she attempted to re-enter the property. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. A construction worker reported seeing Filkins holding a yard sale with items from the home. Missing items include furniture from Crate & Barrel and Ethan Allen, a Weber grill, lamps, a painting, and various household goods. Police are asking anyone who received items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

Police in Albury, NSW-Victoria border, reunited a lost iPhone with its owner Bella Crooke from Melbourne after it was handed in on Sunday morning. Officers discovered the unlocked phone and posted selfies and humorous photos on Bella's Facebook page to locate her, including images of the phone in a holding cell with puns about it being "charged" and being a "cell" phone. Bella had lost the phone at a friend's birthday party the night before. When she arrived at the station, officers recognized her from Facebook and returned the phone. The posts received positive responses from friends praising police for their creative approach. Bella has since added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf's mother had stayed with her herd during the prolonged fight between the males, possibly believing it safer to remain at a distance. When one of the fighting adults grabbed the baby between its jaws, the calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface. The mother attempted to rescue her baby by attacking the hippo's neck, but this caused the adult to bite down harder and fling the calf into the air. The baby hippopotamus died from its injuries hours later. The incident was witnessed by tour operator Stacey Farrell, who noted the mother had been protecting the calf from younger hippos before the fatal encounter.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is being sold for £575,000 - significantly below the area's typical prices - but has only three years remaining on its lease. The unmodernised maisonette in Egerton Place spans 1,990 sq/ft and includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and utility room. The cost equates to £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, comparable to rental rates in the area. If a buyer extends the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million, though extending a 90-year lease would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million through negotiation with the freeholder, believed to be the Welcome Trust. A second, larger maisonette on the same street is also being sold for £595,000 with the same lease terms. Estate agents report significant interest from locals, developers, and end users, noting such opportunities are extremely rare. The historic Egerton Place properties were built around 1893 and originally housed high-status residents.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage Friday night affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, prompting baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods. The company announced the issue was resolved and stores would open normally Saturday. The outage, which began in the early evening on the East Coast, was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and prevented staff from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales. Some locations closed early to avoid giving away free products. The incident occurred one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion. Customers shared their excitement about the free drinks on social media, though some stores chose to close rather than continue the giveaway.

Terrorists are training in rural areas of west Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These locations are being used to radicalise Muslims, with participants engaging in seemingly ordinary community activities while having ulterior motives. Historical incidents include Abu Hamza allegedly sending extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons in 1998, two 7/7 bombers photographed white water rafting in Bala in 2005, and three would-be terrorists from Cardiff arrested in 2010 for plotting Mumbai-style attacks after holding secret meetings in a Welsh country park. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder. DC Jones emphasized that terrorism issues are not confined to large cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence.

A rare Omura's whale, a species feared extinct, washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia following tropical cyclone Olwyn. The 5.68-meter juvenile female represents the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. Department of Parks and Wildlife staff used DNA profiling to confirm its identity. The discovery is considered highly significant as Omura's whales were only first described scientifically in 2003 and little is known about them. The species is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, and has distinctive features including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried for future skeleton recovery for scientific study and possible museum display.

The passage discusses concerns about gender bias in presidential politics, sparked by a Texas businesswoman's claim that Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president due to hormones potentially causing irrational decisions. The author counters that male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' judgment, and studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The piece argues that despite women outnumbering men in education and the workforce, workplace gender bias remains pervasive in 2015, citing examples like corporate boards having more men named John, Robert, William, or James than women total, and professors being described as "geniuses" versus "nice" based on gender. The author contends this bias will make Clinton's presidential path more difficult and emphasizes that gender equality benefits everyone—improving corporate profits, child development, marriages, and team performance. The passage concludes that society must acknowledge and challenge these biases rather than simply telling daughters they can achieve anything.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, known for All Creatures Great and Small and portraying Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 antiques from his collection worth £100,000 as he downsizes his Cotswolds home. The 238 lots include a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt commissioned in the 1960s, a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, furniture, weapons, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating to the 17th century. Hardy, a keen military historian who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien at Oxford and is an expert on medieval longbows, expressed sadness at parting with his treasured collection. The auction takes place Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire. Hardy, who also appeared in Harry Potter films as Cornelius Fudge, retired from stage acting in 2013 after a fall but continues television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida on Saturday. Police became aware of him after he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son the same day his mother's body was discovered following a well-being check. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously involuntarily committed for attempted suicide. His wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors suggest his mother may have prevented him from attending the meeting with his son, and that divorce paperwork received Friday may have triggered the incident. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. He was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations Council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity to host the event for the first time in the USA. Eugene had previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which went to Doha, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of the city's capability. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated the decision allows them to access a key market through collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan was also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death. She targeted Hassan after seeing him with £50 notes at a London casino, befriending him and receiving gifts and cash. After a date at Nobu restaurant and Palm Beach Casino, she returned to his Islington flat and left the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29, to enter. They tied up and kicked Hassan to death while ransacking his home for gambling winnings, stealing £3,000, his TV and phone. Hassan, a divorced father of three who kept cash around his flat, was found with multiple broken bones in a pool of blood. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with minimum 36-year terms. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." All three were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a significant decline in form during the second half of the season, continuing a pattern from his Barcelona days. After a brilliant start at Chelsea following his £30million summer transfer, where he accumulated 15 Premier League assists by mid-January and appeared set to break Thierry Henry's record of 20, he has managed just one assist in his last five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. He struggled in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, receiving a four out of 10 rating from Spanish media. Barcelona's statement upon his departure noted this recurring trend of strong starts followed by fading contributions as seasons progress. Despite playing almost every minute for Chelsea and the team being close to winning the Premier League title after their Capital One Cup victory, questions persist about Fabregas' durability, with the intense campaign seemingly taking its toll on the 27-year-old.

West Ham are in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after a successful two-week trial with the club's academy. The skilful prospect, considered one of the Caribbean's hottest talents, has also attracted offers from Belgian clubs. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Premier League, as they prepare to move to the 54,000-capacity venue for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into an assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, just three months after the attack, despite video evidence and a dossier containing names and car registration numbers of suspected saboteurs. Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters with iron bars during a hunt following an artificial scent near Amesbury. He suffered concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, and ongoing memory loss, requiring £500 in dental treatment. Although police issued a photograph of the main suspect captured on video, no one has been identified or charged. Wiltshire Police cited insufficient evidence for shelving the investigation, a decision that has angered Lane, hunt supporters, and the Countryside Alliance, which is campaigning to ban face coverings at such events to enable prosecution of attackers.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation, though he was not specifically targeted. Born in 1978 as Pearlman in rural California, he converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, joining al Qaeda shortly after. He rose through the ranks in Pakistan's tribal areas and became known for appearing in numerous propaganda videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. presidents, and encouraging lone-wolf attacks in America. Indicted for treason and material support to al Qaeda in 2006, he was on the FBI's most wanted terrorists list. Gadahn also played an institutional role within al Qaeda, including advising on media strategy. He was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child.

A viral video shows five-year-old Mai Zizhuo demonstrating exceptional basketball skills in China. The boy, who has been playing since age two and a half, displays abilities including scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously while maintaining focus on the camera. His performance has attracted thousands of admirers across basketball-enthusiastic China, where Yao Ming previously stood as the country's biggest basketball star during his NBA career from 2002 to 2011. Chinese netizens have expressed disbelief at the child's talent, with some questioning if the video uses special effects and others feeling inadequate about their own abilities in comparison.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined supporters of media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer, attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. The organisation, established after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns for MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. PIE was formed in 1974 and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals. His support is considered an embarrassment to Hacked Off, whose spokesman noted the meeting was open to all members of the public.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The label, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss, produces unisex capsule collections of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop, showcasing minimalist, androgynous, monochrome designs suitable for day to night wear. The show took place on an unseasonably warm 28-degree day with guests enjoying nibbles and drinks while regular lap swimmers were displaced to the beach.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan visited a safari park in northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During the trip to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, Khan posed with and fed a rare white tiger, and also posed with giraffes and sea lions. The 28-year-old recently announced he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent despite pressure to face British rival Kell Brook.

A Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name was added to an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims, but will be removed following complaints. The 16-year-old was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His father objected, refusing his son's name be listed among occupation soldiers, and said no permission was requested. Almagor, a terror victims organization, also opposed the inclusion, calling it a rogue attack rather than terrorism. After complaints from the father, Israel's National Insurance Institute agreed to remove the name from both the memorial wall and website. Three suspects face trial for the killing.

A California father filmed his young son repeatedly trying to use the family cat as a pillow in the garden. The footage shows the boy lying on the cat's belly, but the cat keeps getting up and moving to different spots. After the boy follows and attempts this several times, the cat eventually goes indoors. A subsequent video shows the pair reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves witness Robert Kushner, 32, a former marijuana dealer who testified about undercover officers stealing $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Following his testimony, Kushner lost his varsity coaching position at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy in suburban Bryn Mawr. School officials were unaware of his criminal history, as he had passed a background check when hired in 2010; his 2007 charges were expunged under probation. However, cross-examination revealed he was arrested again in 2011, receiving four years probation, and pleaded guilty to DUI in 2008. Kushner is among over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government against six former drug squad officers facing racketeering charges. Defense lawyers claim the government's case relies on lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Six people were injured after an explosion at a paraxylene (px) chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, which sparked a large fire. The blast occurred Monday night at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, with five people hurt by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters responded and brought the fire under control. The plant produces paraxylene, a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. This facility previously experienced an explosion in July 2013 and was relocated from Xiamen to its current remote location in 2007 after protests over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager, wears his socks low just above his shinpads due to superstition he's maintained throughout his life, despite referees telling him to pull them up. He wears children's size shinpads and has no intention of changing his style. The Ireland under 21 international made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR on Tuesday, expressing pleasure at earning the manager's faith despite the challenging relegation battle context of the match.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. The 22-year-old is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive after nearly three months, does not respond to visitors or voices, and has a tracheostomy. Her father Bobby Brown stated she was awake and watching him, though his attorney clarified he was in an emotional state and that while doctors indicate she will have a long life, she is beginning a lengthy rehabilitation process and her quality of life will not be known for years. She has been moved out of ICU and opened her eyes.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup semifinal after Saturday's matches. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3 after saving a match point in the second set, while Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova recording 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Russia needs one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are being warned of another potential storm later this week, following last week's severe weather that caused widespread flooding and damage. Meteorologists indicate an east coast low could bring heavy rain from Thursday, particularly affecting the state's northern coastal areas. The State Emergency Service still has over 4,000 outstanding jobs from 24,196 requests received during last week's storm and is especially concerned about the Hunter region, which experienced significant flooding and wind damage. The SES warns that additional rainfall could raise flood levels on already saturated ground and winds could topple weakened trees. While the approaching system appears different from last week's three-day event—being further from the coast and likely to move more quickly—the Bureau of Meteorology expects rain to peak between Thursday and Saturday, with main impacts on the north east coast including Northern Rivers and mid north coast areas. Over 1,000 SES personnel are working to complete outstanding jobs before the next system arrives.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied reports that she attempted suicide over the weekend. She posted photos of bruising on her Instagram account and explained she was hospitalized Saturday night after a domestic accident where she fell and hit her head due to low blood pressure. Italian media had reported she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment, with her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso confirming suicide attempt claims. However, Moric stated she is recovering at home and only needs rest, expressing shock at the suicide reports. She was previously married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs, and they have a son together born in 2002.

A YouGov poll of 2,200 people reveals public preferences for the name of Kate and William's second child. If a girl, Diana is the top choice at 12 percent, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9 percent each. For a boy, James leads at 13 percent, with Alexander as second choice. A quarter of respondents hope for a girl, while only 3 percent want another boy. The poll also shows 68 percent support William's decision to take six weeks paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were heading to join a rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred. The Taliban denied responsibility and no other group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that was conditional on him participating in 60 percent of the club's matches. She stated the negotiations are over and expressed frustration that Barcelona waited until April to address his contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called for Italian players Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. The 29-year-old, who has scored three goals in six games, believes the duo would suit Boca's style with their South American approach to the game and thinks fans at La Bombonera would embrace them enthusiastically.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from favorite Merrion Square during the 4:20 pm race at Wincanton, which has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Despite the dramatic fall, Ferguson sustained only a cut on his nose and returned to work at Paul Nicholls's yard the next morning, mucking out stables and riding out as usual. Ferguson said the fall was a blur and he couldn't understand what happened until watching the replay in the weighing room with other jockeys. He acknowledged there was nothing he could do to avoid it and feels lucky given the severity, remaining undeterred about continuing to race.

England flanker James Haskell posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man to coincide with the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron. The London Wasps captain returned to the club in 2012 after previously playing there from 2002-2009, with subsequent spells at Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and Highlanders in New Zealand. Since rejoining Wasps, he has made over 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 England caps.

Wide leg trousers are emerging as a key SS15 trend, appearing in various styles including denim, cropped, printed and striped versions. The look offers an alternative to skinny jeans, which have dominated for years. To successfully wear the style, particularly for shorter individuals, the key is pairing with high heels and keeping the top half simple to maintain proportion. High-waisted, longer lengths can elongate the leg, while cropped styles require heels with exposed foot tops. Denim versions are the easiest entry point, with designers like Gucci reviving seventies-inspired flared jeans and high street retailers like Topshop offering accessible options. Celine and Stella McCartney presented dressier evening versions. The trend updates wardrobes without requiring warm weather.

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel a screening of "American Sniper" after initially pulling it due to student objections. Over 200 students had petitioned against showing the film, which depicts Navy SEAL Chris Kyle and the Iraq War, arguing it reflected negatively on the Middle East and its people—a concern in an area with the nation's largest Arab-American population. However, a counter-petition prompted reconsideration. University officials acknowledged canceling the movie was inconsistent with their commitment to freedom of expression and student choice, and reinstated the screening while offering "Paddington" as an alternative.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, allegedly set fire to a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia on April 3 by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter. The animal survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the men on Saturday and seized video evidence. Both were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a dancer who performed at venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s alongside performers such as Bill Robinson and Frank Sinatra, saw herself dancing on film for the first time. Though motion pictures of her existed, she had never viewed them, and her personal photographs and memorabilia were lost. Mark Cantor from jazz-on-film.com and volunteers compiled video "soundies" and showed them to Barker at her nursing home, which she found fabulous.

A study of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that washing your own car, once a traditional Sunday routine in Britain, is dying out. A third of men have never washed their own car, with only 12 percent doing so regularly, while three-quarters of women never wash their cars. Only five percent have asked their children to do it for pocket money. Contributing factors include Sunday shop openings, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicles like 4x4s being difficult to clean. Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield residents are most likely to wash their own cars weekly, while Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh are least likely. Audi, Toyota and BMW owners wash their cars most often, while Range Rover, Peugeot and Mercedes owners do so least.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact since Skrtel joined Liverpool in 2008, calling him one of the best players in the world and synonymous with the club. Gerrard helped Skrtel settle when he arrived from Zenit St Petersburg. The Liverpool captain is set to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday, with a potential final against Arsenal on May 30 (his birthday) before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel acknowledges Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes the club has players who can replace him with proper support. Both players could return to the lineup after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

Jack Nicklaus, at age 75, made a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus hit his shot past the flag before it spun back into the hole, marking his first ace on Augusta's grounds. The achievement was part of a record-tying day with five total holes-in-one, matching the 2002 record. Camilo Villegas made two aces that day on the fourth and eighth holes but lost the par-3 contest to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus won his first Masters green jacket in 1963 at the youngest age and claimed his sixth in 1986, and is one of five golfers to complete the career grand slam.

Multiple tornadoes were reported Wednesday night in Kansas and Missouri as severe storms moved through the region. Spotters confirmed a tornado northwest of Goddard, Kansas, near Wichita, with additional sightings in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. A possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. The storms also produced baseball-sized hail in some areas. Additional severe weather was forecast for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes regions.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris during an April 2 weapons sting operation. Bates claims he accidentally fired his gun instead of his taser when Harris fled from officers. The judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, which Harris's family criticized as showing apathy during their mourning. Harris's family lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations to the agency and friendship with the sheriff, and that supervisors were told to forge his training records, though the sheriff's office denies this. Bates's lawyers released training documents claiming he had proper law enforcement training. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. The 26-year-old Irishman has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla tattoo on his chest. This will be Aldo's eighth defense of his featherweight championship belt. McGregor claims Aldo lacks the same motivation and doesn't want the fight as much as he does. During a promotional tour in Dublin in late March, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it before 5,000 home supporters, highlighting the fractious relationship between the two fighters ahead of their upcoming bout.

Tony Abbott drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after skolling a beer at an Australian rules function. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert called it problematic, arguing the prime minister was glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with rapid alcohol consumption rather than social drinking. The incident occurred Saturday night when Abbott was asked to drink by a coach, taking about six seconds to down a schooner while players cheered. Critics said he should set a better example, though Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, citing his fitness regime. Opposition leader Bill Shorten made light of the incident. While former PM Bob Hawke also displayed skolling skills, Robert noted attitudes toward binge drinking have shifted, making such behavior more concerning now.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 the previous week. The outbreak, occurring among intravenous drug users primarily using the painkiller Opana, prompted Gov. Mike Pence to approve a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26. Since implementation, 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed to 86 participants and about 1,400 used syringes returned. Pence will decide early next week whether to extend the program beyond April 25. Separately, legislation allowing 23 Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates to establish needle-exchange programs passed the House 54-39 and awaits conference committee review. The program's future remains uncertain as Pence opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policy, and funding is unclear since federal law bans public funding for such programs and Pence's executive order included no dedicated money.

An Arsenal fan created a 50-question exam testing his girlfriend Saskia's knowledge of his favorite football club. The test included multiple choice questions, tables, and essay-style questions covering topics like player names, positions, match scores, and Arsenal history. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning an A grade. Her boyfriend marked the test with red pen, providing feedback that she "could have performed better" on certain questions and needed to "learn all player positions." He jokingly told her he would not dump her due to her passing grade. Saskia posted images of the test on Twitter, generating mixed reactions - some praised the boyfriend as a "legend" and called Saskia "proper gf material" for her football knowledge, while others criticized the boyfriend for taking things too far.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellin cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promise of US citizenship. He became one of the DEA's most important assets, helping carry out undercover stings worldwide without pay, and his information aided in prosecuting cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, the DEA refused to help him obtain citizenship after he went public about his situation, and he now faces deportation after declining health forced his retirement. His final temporary visa expired January 1, leaving him technically in the US illegally, unable to collect social security benefits, and fearing he would be killed within hours if returned to Colombia. A former DEA handler gave him $5,000 for an operation after the agency declined to help, calling the situation government bureaucracy at its worst.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. The attack occurred on Sunday when she went outside her house, and she immolated herself on Tuesday using kerosene. She is now in critical condition at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70 percent burns. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. Her brother discovered her in flames and doused her with water. The accused men have been arrested. The incident occurs amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India following recent high-profile cases and protests demanding better protection for women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw for Sunday's derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford, stating neither player is fit enough to play despite van Persie claiming he was ready. With City struggling after their defeat at Crystal Palace, United have an opportunity to finish second or third, avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal said he dreams of victory and that winning would make third place available, exceeding their pre-season goal of top four. The manager referenced United's 1-0 away loss to City earlier in the season, emphasizing the need to control aggression, though he downplayed revenge as motivation. Van Gaal expressed anticipation for his first Manchester derby at Old Trafford with home advantage and praised United fans for their support.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The demonstration followed the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14billion TV rights deal, with the cheapest tickets for the 12.45pm kick-off costing £64. Supporters from both clubs displayed banners reading '£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket' and 'football without fans is nothing' inside and outside the 60,000-capacity stadium. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, who described ticket prices as extortionate and called for tangible reductions in line with working class earnings, warning that football risks losing a generation of fans.

A newborn baby, Star Reader, was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. Her parents noticed her skin had a yellowy tinge that persisted for weeks, unlike typical jaundice. Doctors discovered her bile ducts were blocked, a potentially fatal condition affecting about 1 in 16,000 babies. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock the ducts, a liver transplant became necessary for survival. Neither parent was a suitable match, but her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader, volunteered without hesitation and proved an ideal candidate. Star underwent the transplant in November, spent six weeks in hospital, and has since made a good recovery at home. She requires weekly blood and liver function tests and will need anti-rejection medication for life, but can now live a normal life thanks to her aunt's donation.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge, competing in teams of two. The challenge consisted of three rounds: firing balls into a car boot from close range, playing over an Audi R8 V10 Plus positioned as a tennis net, and shooting footballs into convertible Audis from long range. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds 5-3 and took a 6-0 lead, but Remy and Willian won the final round. During the competition, Willian accidentally smashed a car's wing mirror with a long-range shot.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, was sentenced for causing a December 2013 highway crash that killed Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons, 29. Prosecutors said Dellinger told investigators he was attempting suicide when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph into the couple's oncoming SUV. During sentencing, Dellinger stated he was never suicidal. His attorneys claimed he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose effects, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis symptoms. Dellinger pleaded guilty in February to negligent homicide for the couple's deaths and one count of assault for the fetus's death. He faced 12 to 24 years in prison. The couple was killed instantly with injuries so severe the medical examiner compared them to a plane crash. Dellinger had held high-level positions at multiple major corporations and left his last position in 2011 with a severance package exceeding $1 million due to health reasons.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for killing her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube while he was hospitalized. She was convicted of second-degree murder and showed no emotion at sentencing. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook about his ex's sentence and lack of emotion. Prosecutors said Spears made her son ill for attention, forcing him through repeated hospitalizations and unnecessary medical procedures throughout his five years of life, while documenting his illnesses on social media. Her lawyer claimed she was innocent, blamed hospital negligence, and plans to appeal. The judge stated Spears suffers from mental illness and called the crime unfathomable in its cruelty.

The influenza vaccine in Australia is arriving a month late because scientists have modified it to include protection against two strains - influenza A H3N2 and influenza B B/Phuket - which caused increased deaths in Europe and the United States. The previous northern hemisphere vaccine did not adequately protect against these strains. High-risk groups will receive free government-funded flu shots from April 20. The modified vaccine, which also protects against H1N1, is expected to be a good match for circulating strains and help prevent deaths. Health experts recommend everyone get vaccinated, not just high-risk groups, to protect vulnerable people they may contact. The same vaccine formulation will be used in the next northern winter.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois are defending the historic site against criticism from National Geographic magazine, which described it as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and called it "a disappointment" with "incongruous art deco style." The criticism comes as Illinois faces budget cuts that threaten the state historic preservation agency managing the site, coinciding with the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. The tomb has already experienced reduced hours and staffing after $1.1 million in funding cuts. Despite over $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations, including interior restoration and waterproofing work, supporters worry about further cuts. The tomb, originally designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, was reconstructed twice due to foundation issues, most recently in 1930. Defenders of the site, including agency officials and volunteers, argue the National Geographic portrayal is unfair and that most visitors appreciate the monument.

The passage discusses nineties and noughties fashion trends that are making comebacks, despite being considered unflattering or impractical. Key trends highlighted include: JNCO wide-leg rave jeans with 50-inch leg openings; bucket hats, originally worn by fishermen but adopted by celebrities like Rihanna; camouflage print in various colors; extreme styling of trends like double denim; shapeless UGG boots; extremely short denim "Daisy Duke" shorts; Juicy Couture velour tracksuits in bright colors; colored and mirrored sunglasses; corsets worn as outerwear rather than undergarments; and baggy harem trousers. The article notes that while these styles were popular with celebrities like Britney Spears, Victoria Beckham, Paris Hilton, and Destiny's Child in the nineties and early 2000s, they are being revived by current young celebrities including Kylie Jenner, Miley Cyrus, Cara Delevingne, and Selena Gomez, though many question whether these trends should remain in the past.

This passage covers trending stories from a busy week, including: four rainbows photographed over New York after heavy rain; China cracking down on exotic dancers hired for funeral wakes; Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview about his private life; a social media trend of young people using jars to plump their lips to resemble Kylie Jenner; 102-year-old Alice Barker experiencing a nostalgic time-travel project with filmmakers; controversy over a bomb-referencing prom proposal accused of being handled with racism; casting news for "Beauty and the Beast" with Ewan McGregor; Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer; and creative announcements including a "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"-themed pregnancy reveal and a military father photobombing his son.

Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to reach the semi-finals. She was presented with a giant celebration cake, similar to Andy Murray who received one the previous day for his 500th win. Williams will face Romania's Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. Williams's potential match against her sister Venus was prevented by Venus's loss to Spain's Carla Suarez Navarro. The victory also served as revenge for Williams's shock defeat to Lisicki at Wimbledon 2013.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights advocate and cafe owner in Karachi, was shot dead by two gunmen on Friday night after hosting a discussion on disappearances in Baluchistan province. She was killed at point-blank range outside her cafe, The Second Floor, suffering five bullet wounds; her mother was also shot and hospitalized. Mahmud had organized the discussion after authorities shut down a similar event at Lahore University, despite knowing it was dangerous and having received previous death threats. She was known nationwide for promoting free speech, technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship in a country where such openness is perilous. Her cafe served as a haven for secular thought and progressive values, attracting young Pakistanis seeking freedom of expression. No one has claimed responsibility for the killing, and police have not identified a motive. Her death sparked widespread grief across Pakistan, where she was regarded as a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance.

Mangu Ram, 82, fled to Kashmir as a 14-year-old refugee during the 1947 partition of India, when around one million people were killed in conflict between India and Pakistan. Nearly 70 years later, he and approximately 100,000 other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) remain second-class citizens in Indian Kashmir, unable to own property, vote in state elections, or work in state government. The WPRs, predominantly Hindu, settled in India's only Muslim-majority state, where successive governments have refused to grant them full citizenship rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance. A pre-independence law only grants citizenship to descendants of those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. The estimated 18,000 WPR families live in abject poverty across three generations, with limited employment and education opportunities. However, refugees now have hope after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party won a share of power in Kashmir's December elections and pledged to normalize the WPRs' status. Activist Labha Ram Gandhi warns the community is prepared to take matters into their own hands if their hopes are disappointed again.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto has admitted he is considering whether to join Chelsea this summer after the club made an offer of around £4million for the 22-year-old Japan international. Chelsea would look to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season, but the player wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop. Muto's former coach Ranko Popovic praised him as an intelligent, fast, strong and confident player with amazing potential. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged knowing about Muto and stated that commercial interests play a part in the club's transfer policy, referencing Chelsea's £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, though he emphasized the club only signs good players or prospects.

Australia has reversed its policy of not selecting overseas-based players, making Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell available for the Wallabies despite playing for Toulon. England maintains a policy excluding overseas players from national selection, which the author argues is outdated and should change. Stuart Lancaster should be able to select England's best players regardless of where they play, similar to how football operates. Players like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon have improved since moving to France, with Armitage's performances for Toulon demonstrating world-class ability. The author contends that for a home World Cup, England needs its strongest possible squad and shouldn't risk "what ifs" by excluding talented overseas players. This policy doesn't serve England's chances of winning and leaves players doubting whether they're selected on merit or merely availability. Other nations like South Africa and Wales select overseas-based players like Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny from Toulon without issue.

Open Garden, developers of the FireChat app, have created Greenstone - a small egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster for wireless mesh networks. FireChat, downloaded over five million times since launching last year, enables messaging without internet or mobile signal by using Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework and similar Android Bluetooth features. The app creates wireless mesh networks where phones become nodes, passing data between them within approximately 30 feet range, with messages traveling up to 200 feet. Greenstone addresses this distance limitation by plugging gaps in the network. The device currently works with FireChat at around 20 feet range, stores up to 1,000 recent messages, and has a one-year battery life. It could be deployed at music festivals, protests, football matches, or other crowded events where networks often crash. Open Garden is working with manufacturers to design and sell Greenstone, though the device is still under development.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle from New Jersey advocates for reclaiming the word "fat" as a neutral, body-positive descriptor rather than an insult. In her TED talk, she argues that "fat" should be treated like other factual descriptors such as "short" or "wife." She notes that size discrimination in the workplace has increased 66 percent over 30 years, and girls aged 11-17 most commonly wish to be thinner. However, studies show that exposure to body diversity increases acceptance of different body types. Lillian, who weighs 240 pounds, began performing burlesque in 2012 to expose audiences to fuller figures in a positive way. Despite initial nervousness about her appearance, the experience proved empowering. Her TED talk video, posted three weeks ago, has garnered nearly 38,000 views with mostly positive responses, including messages from viewers saying it changed how they view their bodies.

Theo Walcott participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013, alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and runway model Olga Sherer. The photoshoot featured official portraits for Paris' oldest fashion house, with Arsenal's first team set to wear similar attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott has been largely overlooked this season, appearing as a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games, playing only six minutes in the recent Chelsea draw, and hoping for his first start since the March 14 West Ham match when Arsenal faces Hull on Monday.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection from Baker's Cinovation Studio includes 417 original items from more than 50 productions spanning his 30-year career, with an estimated total value of $746,100. Featured items include pieces from Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Gremlins 2, Harry and the Hendersons, An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker and Thriller. Individual items are expected to fetch between $1,500 and $40,000, with the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black valued at $40,000. This is the first time these items from the 64-year-old artist's collection will be offered to the public, with no reserve prices set for the live auction.

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died after falling 164ft while skiing with his family in the French Alps resort of Flaine. The competent skier, who had been skiing since age three, became separated from his mother Ceri when his sister lost a ski. He left the piste and entered woodland, apparently heading toward the resort visible through the trees. Police followed his footprints in the snow, which showed sliding marks on steep sections, leading to his body. His family from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, described him as daring and outgoing, saying his death left a "vast void in their hearts." The tragedy occurred on their last run after what had been a happy family holiday.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 after being bullied about her weight. She became obsessed with achieving a "size zero" figure, restricting her intake to approximately 100 calories daily—sometimes just one piece of fruit—and hiding food to deceive her mother. Her dramatic weight loss caused her heart rate to slow dangerously, and she eventually collapsed at home after eating virtually nothing for a week. Laura was hospitalized in intensive care and placed on a heart monitor for a week as her body began shutting down. Following discharge, she received support from eating disorder organizations and mental health services. Laura attributes her condition to widespread pressures on young girls to be thin, citing bullying and societal expectations. She has since recovered and reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive body image and confidence-building experiences away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool supporters made clear their expectation that Raheem Sterling remain at the club during the unveiling of the new 2015/16 home kit at Anfield on Friday. New Balance, replacing sister company Warrior, presented their first kit design under a record-breaking £300million four-year deal. Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet modeled the new gingham-design strip with the message "hold nothing back." This follows Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and his comments about being flattered by Arsenal links, though Liverpool insist the 20-year-old will not leave despite having two years remaining on his contract. Players also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with the new kit featuring all-white branding and a new collar style.

University of Manchester researchers have created the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4 per cent of the sky. The map was produced by Dr Sarah Bridle's team analyzing 130 million telescope images of galaxies over two years, measuring galaxy shapes with extreme precision using supercomputers. The data comes from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile as part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to map 12.5 per cent of the sky by 2018. Since dark matter cannot be directly observed, the map uses gravitational lensing - detecting how dark matter's gravity distorts light from distant galaxies. The map shows dark matter forms large filaments where visible galaxies cluster, supporting theories that galaxies form where dark matter concentrations are strongest. This represents three percent of the area DES will ultimately document, and analyzing dark matter clumpiness will help scientists understand dark energy and the universe's accelerating expansion.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, according to the Dutch club's technical director Marcel Brands. The 21-year-old winger has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. United manager Louis van Gaal, who worked with Depay during Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign where they finished third, is keen to make him one of his first summer signings. PSV have confirmed contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, with Brands stating Depay is now worth more than the £15 million Tottenham bid that was rejected last summer. Depay, who joined PSV at age 12 and made his debut in 2011, is known for his pace, dribbling ability, and powerful right-foot shooting.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 in the first leg of a youth cup final at the Academy Stadium. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half with volleys, taking his season tally to 36 goals, before being substituted due to injury. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalized for City, but Dominic Solanke added a late third goal for Chelsea. Chelsea dominated the midfield battle and their defense, particularly the Clarke-Salter and Tomori partnership, effectively contained City's attack. City's Brandon Barker, tipped for a first-team future, tried to make an impact but was guilty of overplaying at times. Chelsea take a commanding two-goal advantage back to West London for the second leg.

Marco Rubio stated that people are born with a sexual preference but believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman. The presidential candidate said same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that state legislators, not courts, should decide on marriage laws. Despite his opposition to gay marriage, Rubio said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect for them. He compared this to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but wouldn't stop him from loving someone who is divorced. Rubio announced his presidential candidacy last week and has reportedly received monetary commitments exceeding the $51 million needed for the primary campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, from Spain, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, from Latvia, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world with no fixed plans or timeline. In their first 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting from London and traveling through Western Europe, down to the Mediterranean, through the Balkans, Greece, and Turkey, and into Georgia and Armenia. They survive on less than three euros per person daily (10 euro cents per kilometer), with food as their only major expense at 2.74 euros each per day. They keep costs minimal by camping (161 nights), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and relying on kindness from strangers. Their diet consists mainly of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, wild fruits, and occasional free meals. They plan to continue across Asia, the Pacific, and throughout the Americas in the coming years.

A Texas couple is suing photographer James Evans and his company Premiere Photos for allegedly printing a racial slur ("poor n***** party") on photo booth pictures from their 2012 wedding. The bride's sister discovered the offensive captions but waited months to inform the couple to avoid ruining their celebration. When the groom contacted Evans about the incident, Evans allegedly refused to apologize and told them to "sue me." The couple is pursuing legal action under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied the allegations, claiming no evidence links his company to the captions and that the couple showed no signs of mental anguish. The couple's attorney states they primarily want an apology. Mediation is scheduled, with a potential trial in July if no agreement is reached.

Mike Brown, England full-back, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion. He pulled out of Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley after experiencing headaches following England's game against France, despite no single incident causing dizziness. Brown, who was previously knocked out cold against Italy in February and missed the Ireland match, wants to avoid an extended absence like those experienced by Johnny Sexton (12 weeks) and George North (advised not to play this season after four concussions). He credits World Rugby online modules for increasing his awareness of concussion symptoms, which helped him recognize when to withdraw. Brown emphasizes the importance of not rushing back and being honest about symptoms, stating that if he could pull out of a crucial England-Ireland match, anyone should prioritize their health over playing through concussion symptoms.

A leading expert suggests smartphone use may be contributing to declining sexual frequency among British couples. Research shows typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times monthly, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a Cambridge University statistician, attributes this decline to increased technological connectivity blurring boundaries between public and private life. People constantly check emails, eliminating quiet time previously available. While more people living alone is one factor, the primary explanation is that technology has made lives busier, eroding work-home boundaries and squeezing out time for partners. Researchers note that competing demands push sex down the priority list, with late-evening work emails preventing couples from focusing on each other at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs in China have experienced a dramatic fall from being luxury status symbols worth up to £1.2 million to being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which ended the practice of wealthy businessmen gifting the dogs to officials, and bans on dogs over 50kg in major cities including Beijing and Shanghai. The breed, which can weigh up to 80kg and was traditionally used for herding in Tibet, saw its boom begin in 2005. Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs heading to slaughter, finding a third already dead with survivors unfed for three days and suffering broken bones. The market collapse has been worsened by cross-breeding that deteriorated the dogs' quality, creating a glut of unsellable specimens. Gangs are also stealing mastiffs from streets to sell to slaughterhouses, and breeders are offloading imperfect dogs to abattoirs.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every female respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half first experiencing it before age 18. The harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behavior to sexual assault and rape. Six out of ten women fear being attacked on public transport compared to three out of ten men. These largely unreported incidents force women to alter their daily routines, including routes, transportation modes, schedules, and clothing, effectively limiting their freedom and excluding them from public spaces. The report, presented to France's women's rights ministry, prompted calls for campaigns to address sexist and threatening behavior on public transport. Officials emphasized that women need better education about recognizing harassment as abnormal, while attackers currently feel they can act with impunity by hiding in crowds.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix where design groups created prototype products to solve common everyday problems. After surveying 2,000 people about their top everyday emergencies, three products were shortlisted: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; Forget Me Lock, a key-fastening device that shows green when a door is open and red when locked; and Nipper, a compact mobile phone charger powered by household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag until April 46, with the winner being developed through a Kickstarter campaign. Other non-shortlisted designs included a cycling helmet with bone conduction headphones for navigation, a parking space alert device, and an app for message relay when phones die.

Vera Baird, Northumbria's police and crime commissioner, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after awarding £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity where she serves as director. Chief Constable Sue Sim also sits on the charity's board alongside Baird. The funding allocation followed a rule change allowing PCCs to commission victim services. Critics, including Labour MP Keith Vaz, have called the arrangement a conflict of interest and "inappropriate," describing the situation as a "soap opera" within the force. Baird defends her decision, stating all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The MoJ confirmed it will investigate whether conflict of interest rules were violated and has the power to cease funding if a conflict is established. Sim, who previously faced bullying allegations investigated by Baird, has announced her retirement in June.

Three people were imprisoned and two await sentencing for assaulting 53-year-old Greg Valecce over approximately 42 hours in late March 2014. Ringleader Corry Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had injured his cat Pebbles and stolen money and marijuana. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, beat Valecce in a Philadelphia basement, tied him to a chair, and forcibly tattooed him with offensive images including swastikas, racial slurs, and crude drawings. Valecce, who had been staying in the basement, suffered three broken ribs, two broken wrists, and facial fractures before escaping on April 1 and contacting police. Campbell and Halin each received 20-year sentences, while Ng received 23 months. Police found tattoo equipment, marijuana, prescription drugs, and Valecce's stolen debit card at the scene. Valecce has had the tattoos removed but reports lasting psychological trauma.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, according to the Dutch club's technical director Marcel Brands. The 21-year-old winger has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years. United manager Louis van Gaal, who worked with Depay during Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign where they finished third, is keen to make him one of his first summer signings. PSV have confirmed interest from Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, with Brands stating Depay is now worth more than the £15 million Tottenham bid that was rejected last summer. Depay, who joined PSV at age 12 and made his debut in 2011, is known for his pace, dribbling ability, and powerful right-foot shooting.

City's Brandon Barker was their standout player but tried to do too much at times, while several City players missed chances to level the score. Chelsea take a commanding lead back to West London for the second leg.

As of 12 March, Italy has the world's highest per capita rate of positive coronavirus cases among nations with at least one million citizens at 206.1 cases per million people, which is 3.6 times China's rate. Italy also has the second-highest number of total positive cases and deaths globally, after China.

As of 12 March, Italy has the world's highest per capita rate of positive coronavirus cases at 206.1 cases per million people among nations with at least one million citizens. Italy has more confirmed cases than all of mainland China excluding Hubei province, and ranks second globally in both total positive cases and deaths, after mainland China.
